entries.heading: Scimax VS Code
entries.content: Scimax VS Code is a comprehensive scientific computing extension for Visual Studio Code, inspired by the powerful [[https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax][Scimax]] package for Emacs. It brings literate programming, knowledge management, and scientific writing capabilities to VS Code users.

entries.heading: What is Scimax VS Code?
entries.content: Scimax VS Code transforms Visual Studio Code into a powerful environment for: - *Literate Programming* - Write documents that combine prose and executable code - *Scientific Computing* - Execute code in 30+ languages with Jupyter integration - *Knowledge Management* - Organize notes, tasks, and references in structured documents - *Academic Writing* - Manage citations, export to LaTeX/PDF, and write papers The extension provides first-class support for org-mode files (.org), with full structural

entries.heading: Document Structure
entries.content: Create hierarchical documents with collapsible headings, properties, and tags. Navigate efficiently with outline views, heading jumps, and fuzzy search. - Unlimited heading levels with folding support - Tags and inherited tags for organization - Properties drawers for metadata - Speed commands for rapid navigation See [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] for details.

entries.heading: Task Management
entries.content: Track tasks with TODO states, priorities, deadlines, and scheduling. - Multiple TODO states (TODO, DONE, WAITING, NEXT, HOLD, CANCELLED) - Priorities [#A], [#B], [#C] - Checkbox lists with progress tracking [2/5] - Deadline and scheduled timestamps with warnings See [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items]] for details.

entries.heading: Tables
entries.content: Create and edit tables with spreadsheet-like formulas. - Easy table creation and navigation - Column/row manipulation - Formula support (#+TBLFM:) - Import/export to CSV See [[file:04-tables.org][Tables]] for details.

entries.heading: Source Code Execution
entries.content: Execute code blocks in 30+ programming languages directly in your documents. - Python, JavaScript, Shell, R, Julia, and more - Jupyter kernel integration for rich output - Session support for stateful execution - Code tangling for extracting source files - Variable passing between blocks See [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Code Blocks]] for details.

entries.heading: Export
entries.content: Export documents to multiple formats with customizable options. - HTML with syntax highlighting - LaTeX with custom preambles - PDF via LaTeX compilation - Markdown (GitHub-flavored) See [[file:10-export.org][Export]] for details.

entries.heading: Timestamps and Planning
entries.content: Manage dates, deadlines, and scheduling with rich timestamp support. - Active and inactive timestamps - Date/time ranges - Repeating tasks (+1d, +1w, +1m) - Deadline warnings See [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] for details.

entries.heading: Links and References
entries.content: Create hyperlinks to files, URLs, headings, and more. - External links (https://, file:) - Internal links to headings and targets - Citation links with bibliography support - Custom link types See [[file:05-links.org][Links]] for details.

entries.heading: Agenda Views
entries.content: View and filter tasks across multiple files. - Day, week, month views - TODO list aggregation - Deadline and scheduled item views - Tag and priority filtering See [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda]] for details.

entries.heading: Journal System
entries.content: Maintain a daily journal with calendar navigation. - One file per day organization - Calendar-based navigation - Quick capture and logging - Full-text search across entries See [[file:14-journal.org][Journal]] for details.

entries.heading: Database and Search
entries.content: Full-text and semantic search across your documents. - SQLite FTS5 full-text search - Vector-based semantic search - Heading, source block, and hashtag search - Multiple embedding providers (local, Ollama, OpenAI) See [[file:18-database-search.org][Database and Search]] for details.

entries.heading: Citations and Bibliography
entries.content: Manage academic references with BibTeX integration. - Insert citations with multiple styles - DOI lookup for metadata - OpenAlex academic search - PDF management See [[file:19-references.org][References]] for details.

entries.heading: Quick Start
entries.content: 1. *Install the extension* from the VS Code marketplace or from a VSIX file 2. *Open or create an org file* with the `.org' extension 3. *Create a heading* by typing `* My First Heading' 4. *Add a source block* and execute it: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+BEGIN_SRC python :results output print("Hello, Scimax VS Code!") ,#+END_SRC #+END_SRC Press `C-<return>' or `C-c C-c' to execute. 5. *Explore the menus* with `C-c m' (main menu) or `C-c C-m' (context menu) See [[file:01-getting-started.org][Getting Start

entries.heading: Within VS Code
entries.content: - Press `C-c m' to open the main Hydra menu - Press `C-c C-m' for context-sensitive menus - Use `C-S-P' and search for "Scimax" commands - Hover over elements for tooltips and information

entries.heading: Online Resources
entries.content: - GitHub Issues: Report bugs and request features - Documentation: This documentation set

entries.heading: Keybinding Help
entries.content: Press `? ' at the beginning of a heading (with speed commands enabled) to see available speed commands. See [[file:24-keybindings.org][Keybindings]] for the complete reference.

entries.heading: Acknowledgments
entries.content: Scimax VS Code is inspired by: - [[https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax][Scimax]] - The original Emacs package by John Kitchin - [[https://orgmode.org][Org-mode]] - The powerful Emacs major mode for notes and planning - [[https://orgmode.org/worg/org-contrib/babel/][Org Babel]] - Literate programming in Org-mode

entries.heading: Getting Started
entries.content: This guide will help you install Scimax VS Code and get started with its core features. By the end, you'll be able to create structured documents, execute code, and navigate efficiently.

entries.heading: VS Code Version
entries.content: Scimax VS Code requires Visual Studio Code version *1.85 or later*.

entries.heading: Optional Dependencies
entries.content: While Scimax VS Code works out of the box, some features require additional software:

entries.heading: For Code Execution
entries.content: | Language   | Requirement                                    | |------------+------------------------------------------------| | Python     | Python 3.x installed and in PATH               | | JavaScript | Node.js installed                              | | Shell      | Bash or compatible shell                       | | R          | R installed with Rscript in PATH               | | Julia      | Julia installed and in PATH                    |

entries.heading: For Jupyter Integration
entries.content: - Jupyter installed (`pip install jupyter') - Jupyter kernels for desired languages

entries.heading: For LaTeX/PDF Export
entries.content: - TeX distribution (TeX Live, MiKTeX, or MacTeX) - pdflatex, xelatex, or lualatex compiler

entries.heading: For LaTeX Equation Preview
entries.content: - LaTeX distribution with dvipng or dvisvgm

entries.heading: From VS Code Marketplace
entries.content: 1. Open VS Code 2. Press `C-S-X' to open the Extensions view 3. Search for "Scimax" 4. Click *Install*

entries.heading: From VSIX File
entries.content: 1. Download the `.vsix' file from the [[https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax_vscode/releases][GitHub Releases page]] 2. Open VS Code 3. Press `C-S-X' to open the Extensions view 4. Click the `...' menu (top right) 5. Select "Install from VSIX..." 6. Choose the downloaded file

entries.heading: From Source (GitHub)
entries.content: The source code is available at [[https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax_vscode]]. To build and install from source: 1. Clone the repository: #+BEGIN_SRC shell git clone https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax_vscode.git cd scimax_vscode #+END_SRC 2. Install dependencies and build: #+BEGIN_SRC shell npm install make #+END_SRC 3. Install the generated VSIX: #+BEGIN_SRC shell code --install-extension scimax-vscode-*.vsix #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Updating the Extension
entries.content: To update to the latest version from within VS Code: 1. Open the Command Palette (`C-S-P') 2. Run "Scimax: Update from GitHub" 3. Confirm the update when prompted 4. Reload VS Code when prompted This downloads and installs the latest release from GitHub automatically.

entries.heading: Verify Installation
entries.content: After installation: 1. Open the Command Palette (`C-S-P') 2. Type "Scimax" 3. You should see Scimax commands listed

entries.heading: Opening an Org File
entries.content: Org files use the `.org' extension. To create your first file: 1. Press `C-n' to create a new file (note s-n on Mac) 2. Save it with `C-s' and give it a `.org' extension (e.g., `notes.org') 3. The file will automatically use org-mode syntax highlighting

entries.heading: Creating Your First Document
entries.content: Type the following to create a basic document structure: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TITLE: My First Document ,#+AUTHOR: Your Name ,#+DATE: 2026-01-13 ,* Introduction This is my first Scimax VS Code document. ,** A Subsection Content under the subsection. ,* Tasks ,** TODO Learn Scimax VS Code DEADLINE: <2026-01-20 Mon> ,** DONE Install the extension CLOSED: [2026-01-13 Mon] ,* Code Example ,#+BEGIN_SRC python :results output print("Hello from Scimax VS Code!") ,#+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Folding
entries.content: - Press `Tab' on a heading to cycle its visibility (folded/children/subtree) - Press `S-<tab>' anywhere to cycle global visibility *bold* /italics/

entries.heading: Moving Between Headings
entries.content: | Key         | Action                   | |-------------+--------------------------| | `C-c C-j'   | Jump to any heading      | | `M-<up>'    | Move heading up          | | `M-<down>'  | Move heading down        | | `M-<left>'  | Promote heading (level) | | `M-<right>' | Demote heading (level)  |

entries.heading: Executing Code
entries.content: 1. Place your cursor inside a source block 2. Press `C-<return>' or `C-c C-c' 3. Results appear below the block

entries.heading: Outline View
entries.content: The Outline view in VS Code's sidebar shows your document structure: 1. Click the Outline icon in the sidebar (or press `C-S-O') 2. See all headings hierarchically 3. Click a heading to jump to it

entries.heading: Tree Views
entries.content: Scimax VS Code adds several tree views to the Explorer sidebar:

entries.heading: Journal Tree
entries.content: Shows your journal entries organized by date. Access today's entry with `C-S-J' (or `s-S-J' on Mac).

entries.heading: Projects Tree
entries.content: Shows your registered projects for quick navigation.

entries.heading: Agenda Tree
entries.content: Shows TODO items, deadlines, and scheduled tasks across your files.

entries.heading: Status Bar
entries.content: The status bar shows: - Current journal date (when in journal files) - Kernel status (when using Jupyter)

entries.heading: Hydra Menus
entries.content: Hydra menus provide discoverable access to commands: - `C-c m' - Open main menu - `C-c C-m' - Open context-sensitive menu - `C-M-V' - Open database/search menu Menus show available commands with their keybindings. Press a key to execute a command or `Escape' to close the menu.

entries.heading: Document Commands
entries.content: | Key        | Command                         | |------------+---------------------------------| | Tab        | Cycle fold at heading           | | S-<tab>    | Cycle global fold               | | C-c C-j    | Jump to heading                 | | C-<return> | Insert new heading (at heading) | | C-c C-t    | Cycle TODO state                | | C-c C-c    | Context action (execute/toggle) |

entries.heading: Source Block Commands
entries.content: | Key        | Command                        | |------------+--------------------------------| | C-<return> | Execute current block          | | S-<return> | Execute block and move to next | | C-<up>     | Go to previous block           | | C-<down>   | Go to next block               |

entries.heading: Export Commands
entries.content: | Key         | Command                | |-------------+------------------------| | C-c C-e     | Open export dispatcher | | C-c C-e h h | Export to HTML         | | C-c C-e l l | Export to LaTeX        | | C-c C-e l p | Export to PDF          |

entries.heading: Navigation Commands
entries.content: | Key     | Command                       | |---------+-------------------------------| | C-c s   | Fuzzy search current file     | | C-c j c | Jump to character (Avy-style) | | C-c j w | Jump to word                  | | C-c j l | Jump to line                  |

entries.heading: Help Commands
entries.content: | Key   | Command                                      | |-------+----------------------------------------------| | C-h k | Describe key (type a key to see its command) | | C-h b | List all keybindings                         | | C-h f | Describe command (find command by name)      | | C-h v | Describe variable (view setting details)     | | C-h a | Apropos (search documentation for keywords)  |

entries.heading: Recommended Settings
entries.content: Open VS Code settings (`C-,') and search for "scimax" to see all options.

entries.heading: Essential Settings
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { // Enable speed commands (single-key at heading start) "scimax.speedCommands.enabled": true, // Set your journal directory "scimax.journal.directory": "~/Documents/journal", // Configure bibliography files for citations "scimax.ref.bibliographyFiles": ["~/references.bib"], // Enable image overlays "scimax.imageOverlays.enabled": true, // Auto-index files for search "scimax.db.autoIndex": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Python Configuration
entries.content: If Python isn't automatically detected: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.literate.pythonPath": "/usr/bin/python3" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: LaTeX Configuration
entries.content: For PDF export: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latexLivePreview.compiler": "pdflatex", "scimax.latexLivePreview.useLatexmk": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Migrating from Emacs
entries.content: If you're coming from Emacs Org-mode or Scimax, here are key differences:

entries.heading: Similar Features
entries.content: | Emacs          | VS Code                  | |----------------+--------------------------| | C-c C-c        | C-c C-c                  | | C-c C-t        | C-c C-t                  | | C-c C-e        | C-c C-e                  | | TAB on heading | Tab on heading           | | S-TAB          | S-<tab>                  | | M-RET          | C-<return> (at heading)  | | M-left/right   | M-<left>/Right           | | M-up/down      | M-<up>/Down              | | Speed commands | Same keys (when enabl

entries.heading: Different Behaviors
entries.content: - *Completion*: Uses VS Code's completion system, triggered automatically - *Folding*: Uses VS Code's native folding with org-specific ranges - *Buffer management*: VS Code tabs instead of Emacs buffers - *Customization*: JSON settings instead of Emacs Lisp

entries.heading: Missing Features
entries.content: Some advanced Emacs features may not be available: - Org-mode's full capture/refile system (simplified version available) - Column view - Some specialized agenda views - Custom link types (limited set supported)

entries.heading: Next Steps
entries.content: Now that you're set up, explore these topics: 1. [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Master headings, folding, and navigation 2. [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items]] - Learn task management 3. [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Code Blocks]] - Execute code in your documents 4. [[file:24-keybindings.org][Keybindings]] - Learn all keyboard shortcuts

entries.heading: Code Blocks Not Executing
entries.content: 1. Check that the language is installed (e.g., Python, Node.js) 2. Verify the language is in your PATH 3. Check the Output panel (`C-S-U') for errors 4. Run `scimax.org.checkExecutors' to verify available executors

entries.heading: LaTeX Preview Not Working
entries.content: 1. Ensure LaTeX is installed (`latex --version' in terminal) 2. Check that dvipng or dvisvgm is available 3. Run `scimax.checkLatexTools' to verify installation

entries.heading: Search Not Finding Results
entries.content: 1. Run `scimax.db.reindex' to rebuild the search index 2. Check that files aren't in excluded patterns 3. Verify the search scope (`scimax.db.setScope')

entries.heading: Journal Not Opening
entries.content: 1. Check that `scimax.journal.directory' is set correctly 2. Ensure the directory exists and is writable 3. Try creating the directory manually if needed

entries.heading: Disable Option-Key Accents on macOS
entries.content: M-<key> combinations may produce accented characters instead of the intended commands on a Mac. To fix this, you can change your keyboard input settings: - Add Unicode Hex Input System Settings  Keyboard  Input Sources  click "+"  select Other  add "Unicode Hex Input" - Remove U.S. Input (optional) System Settings  Keyboard  Input Sources  select "U.S."  click "" * Navigation - Previous: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Ne

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] Org-mode uses a lightweight markup syntax that stays readable as plain text while providing rich formatting when rendered. This document covers the fundamental syntax elements you'll use in everyday writing. The philosophy is simple: markup should be intuitive and unobtrusive. When you read an org file as plain text, the meaning is clear. When exported or rendered, the formatting appears polished.

entries.heading: Text Markup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] Text markup in org-mode uses paired delimiters around words or phrases. The key rule: markup delimiters must be adjacent to the text they format, with whitespace or punctuation on the outside.

entries.heading: Emphasis Styles
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] Here's how to emphasize text in your writing: When you want to make a point *strongly*, use asterisks for *bold text*. This draws the reader's attention to key concepts or important warnings. For a gentler emphasis, /italic text/ works well for /introducing new terms/, book titles like /The Art of Computer Programming/, or adding subtle stress to a phrase. Sometimes you need to mark text as _underlined_ to indicate _titles_ or _special significance_. Underlines app

entries.heading: Literal Text
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] When writing about code or technical content, you need text that renders exactly as typed: Use =verbatim= for file paths like =/usr/local/bin=, environment variables like =PATH=, or any text that should appear in a monospace font without interpretation. The ~code~ markup is similar but semantically indicates program code: ~print("hello")~, variable names like ~myVariable~, or command names like ~grep~. The difference is subtleboth render similarly, but =verbatim=

entries.heading: Markup Rules
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] Markup only works when the delimiters are properly placed: - The opening delimiter must follow whitespace or punctuation: start of line, space, or characters like =(=, =[=, ={= - The closing delimiter must precede whitespace or punctuation: end of line, space, period, comma, etc. - No whitespace immediately inside the delimiters These work: *bold*, /italic/, text with *bold* inside, (*bold in parens*) These don't: * bold * (spaces inside), *bold * (trailing space),

entries.heading: Combining Markup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:42] You can nest markup for combined effects, though keep it readable: This is */bold and italic/*. Or try _/underlined italic/_ for something different. The outer delimiter is processed first, so */bold italic/* has bold as the primary emphasis containing italic text.

entries.heading: Lists
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:43] Lists are fundamental to organized writing. Org-mode supports three types: unordered (bullet), ordered (numbered), and definition lists.

entries.heading: Unordered Lists
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:43] Start a line with a dash, plus, or asterisk followed by a space: - First item in the list - Second item continues the thought - Third item wraps up You can also use =+= or =*= as bullets (though =*= can conflict with headlines at the start of a line): + Alternative bullet style + Some prefer this look + It's a matter of taste

entries.heading: Ordered Lists
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:43] For sequences where order matters, use numbers followed by a period or parenthesis: 1. First, gather your materials 2. Next, prepare the workspace 3. Then, begin the actual work 4. Finally, clean up when done The numbers auto-increment conceptually, and you can use letters too: a. Option A: the simple approach b. Option B: more complex but powerful c. Option C: advanced users only

entries.heading: Nested Lists
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:43] Indent items to create hierarchy. Use consistent indentation (typically 2-3 spaces): - Main topic - Subtopic one - Detail about subtopic one - Another detail - Subtopic two - Another main topic - With its own subtopics You can mix ordered and unordered: 1. First major step - Consider this aspect - And this one too 2. Second major step - More considerations - Final thoughts

entries.heading: Definition Lists
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:43] When you need to define terms, use the =::= separator: - term :: The word or phrase being defined - definition :: An explanation of what something means - org-mode :: A major mode for Emacs that provides outlining, task management, and literate programming Definition lists are perfect for: - glossaries :: Collections of term definitions - parameter docs :: Explaining function arguments - feature lists :: Describing capabilities with explanations The term appears be

entries.heading: Checkboxes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:35] Add checkboxes to list items for task tracking: - [ ] Task not yet started - [-] Task in progress (partially complete) - [X] Task completed Toggle checkboxes with =C-c C-c= when the cursor is on the line. Parent items can show progress: - Project tasks [2/3] - [x] Design the interface - [X] Implement the backend - [ ] Write documentation The =[1/3]= updates automatically as you check off subtasks. You can also use percentage format =[33%]=. You can use an attribute

entries.heading: Paragraphs and Line Breaks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:36] Paragraphs are simply blocks of text separated by blank lines: This is the first paragraph. It can contain multiple sentences that flow together naturally. The text wraps based on your editor settings. This is the second paragraph. The blank line above separates it from the first. Each paragraph represents a distinct thought or topic.

entries.heading: Preserving Line Breaks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:36] Normally, single line breaks within a paragraph are treated as spaces when exported. To force a line break, end the line with =\\=: | Line one of the address\\ | Line two\\ | City, State ZIP Or use verse blocks for poetry and formatted text: #+BEGIN_VERSE Roses are red, Violets are blue, Org-mode is lovely, And so are you. #+END_VERSE

entries.heading: Horizontal Rules
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] Create a horizontal divider with five or more dashes on a line by themselves: Some content above the rule. ----- Content continues below the rule. Horizontal rules help separate major sections or indicate a scene break in narrative writing.

entries.heading: Equations and Mathematics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] Org-mode supports LaTeX math notation for scientific and technical writing.

entries.heading: Inline Math
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] For mathematics within a sentence, use =$...$= or =\(...\)=: The famous equation $E = mc^2$ changed physics forever. Einstein showed that energy and mass are equivalent, with the speed of light $c$ as the conversion factor. In statistics, the mean $\mu = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i$ summarizes a dataset. The standard deviation $\sigma$ measures spread around that mean. The quadratic formula \(x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\) solves any quadratic equation.

entries.heading: Display Math
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] For equations that deserve their own line, use =$$...$$= or =\[...\]=: The Gaussian integral is remarkably elegant: $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^2} dx = \sqrt{\pi}$$ Maxwell's equations in differential form: \[\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E} = \frac{\rho}{\epsilon_0}\] \[\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0\]

entries.heading: Equation Environments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] For numbered equations or aligned systems, use LaTeX environments: #+BEGIN_EXPORT latex \begin{equation} f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{x} e^{-t^2} dt \end{equation} #+END_EXPORT Or for aligned equations: \begin{align} a &= b + c \\ d &= e + f + g \end{align}

entries.heading: Math Preview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] In Scimax VS Code, hover over math expressions to see a rendered preview. See [[file:11-latex-preview.org][LaTeX Preview]] for full details.

entries.heading: Footnotes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:45] Add footnotes for supplementary information that would interrupt the main flow: Org-mode[fn:1] provides excellent support for academic writing. You can place footnotes anywhere in the document[fn:2], and they render appropriately on export. [fn:1] Originally developed by Carsten Dominik starting in 2003. [fn:2] Footnote definitions can appear anywhere, but placing them near their reference aids readability.

entries.heading: Inline Footnotes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:36] For quick notes, use inline footnotes that combine reference and definition: The algorithm runs in O(n log n) time[fn:: This assumes a comparison-based sort; radix sort can achieve O(n) for integers.], making it practical for large datasets.

entries.heading: Named Footnotes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:36] Use descriptive names for footnotes you reference multiple times: As noted in the original paper[fn:smith2020], the results were reproducible[fn:smith2020]. [fn:smith2020] Smith et al., "Reproducibility in Science," Journal of Methods, 2020.

entries.heading: Block Elements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] Org-mode uses =#+BEGIN_...= and =#+END_...= pairs for special block content.

entries.heading: Quote Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] For quotations: #+BEGIN_QUOTE The only way to do great work is to love what you do.  Steve Jobs #+END_QUOTE

entries.heading: Example Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] For preformatted text that should render literally: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE This text appears exactly as typed. Indentation is preserved. *Markup* is not processed. #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Center Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] For centered text: #+BEGIN_CENTER This text will be centered when exported. Multiple paragraphs can be centered together. #+END_CENTER

entries.heading: Source Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] For code with syntax highlighting (covered in detail in [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]]): #+BEGIN_SRC python def hello(name): """Greet someone by name.""" return f"Hello, {name}!" #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Comment Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] For content that should not appear in exports: #+BEGIN_COMMENT TODO: Add more examples here before publishing. This entire block is hidden from exported output. #+END_COMMENT

entries.heading: Comments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] Individual lines can be commented out: # This line is a comment and won't export Regular text continues here. Everything after =# = at the start of a line is hidden from export but visible in the source. For inline comments that span part of a line, there's no direct syntaxuse comment blocks or restructure your content.

entries.heading: Entities
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] Org-mode supports named entities for special characters: - =\alpha=  , =\beta=  , =\gamma=   (Greek letters) - =\rarr=  , =\larr=  , =\harr=   (arrows) - =\deg=  , =\pm=  , =\times=   (symbols) - =\copy=  , =\reg=  , =\trade=   (legal) @@>VS Code does not render the entities like Emacs does.<@@

entries.heading: Escaping Markup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] To show literal markup characters without triggering formatting: - Use a zero-width space (not practical) - Use =verbatim= or =code= markup: the asterisk =*= creates bold - Use an example block for longer passages In source blocks and example blocks, all markup is automatically literal.

entries.heading: Putting It All Together
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] Here's a sample document fragment showing these elements working together: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE ,* Project Status Update The /alpha release/ is *complete*. Key achievements: 1. Core functionality implemented - Parser: 100% of syntax supported - Exporter: HTML and PDF working 2. Documentation written 3. Tests passing ,** Metrics | Metric        | Value   | |---------------+---------| | Code coverage | 85%     | | Open issues   | 12      | The velocity $v = \frac{\Delta x

entries.heading: Quick Reference
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:49] | Element        | Syntax                    | Example                    | |----------------+---------------------------+----------------------------| | Bold           | =*text*=                  | *important*                | | Italic         | =/text/=                  | /emphasis/                 | | Underline      | =_text_=                  | _underlined_               | | Strikethrough  | =+text+=                  | +removed+                  | | Verbatim

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 17:50] - [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Headlines, folding, and outline navigation - [[file:04-tables.org][Tables]] - Creating and formatting tables - [[file:05-links.org][Links]] - Hyperlinks and cross-references - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Code execution and literate programming - [[file:11-latex-preview.org][LaTeX Preview]] - Previewing mathematical notation - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - Converting to HTML, PDF, and o

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:01-getting-started.org][Getting Started]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]]

entries.heading: Document Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:25] Org documents are structured around *headlines*, which create a hierarchical outline that can be folded, navigated, and manipulated. This chapter covers how to create and work with document structure in Scimax VS Code.

entries.heading: Headlines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:25] Headlines are the backbone of org documents. They define the structure and allow for powerful outline-based navigation and organization.

entries.heading: Creating Headlines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:25] A headline starts with one or more asterisks (*) at the beginning of a line, followed by a space: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Top Level Headline ,** Second Level ,*** Third Level ,**** Fourth Level #+END_SRC There is no hard limit on headline levels, but most documents use 3-5 levels.

entries.heading: Headline Components
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:25] A headline can contain several components: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO [#A] Headline Title                                    :tag1:tag2: #+END_SRC | Component    | Description                      | Example       | |--------------+----------------------------------+---------------| | Stars        | Define the level (required)      | *, **, ***    | | TODO keyword | Task state (optional)            | TODO, DONE    | | Priority     | Importance marker (optional)     | [

entries.heading: Headline Levels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:26] Headlines can be nested to any depth: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Level 1: Main Section ,** Level 2: Subsection ,*** Level 3: Sub-subsection ,**** Level 4: Paragraph grouping ,***** Level 5: Fine detail #+END_SRC Use consistent levels throughout your document. Skipping levels (e.g., going from * to ***) works but may cause confusion.

entries.heading: Visibility Cycling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:26] One of the most powerful features of org documents is the ability to fold (collapse) and unfold (expand) sections to manage complexity.

entries.heading: Folding with Tab
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:26] Press Tab on a headline to cycle through visibility states: | State    | Shows                                    | |----------+------------------------------------------| | Folded   | Only the headline, children hidden       | | Children | Headline and immediate child headlines   | | Subtree  | All content under this headline          | Example cycle: 1. * Heading... (folded - ellipsis shows hidden content) 2. * Heading with child headlines visible 3. * Heading wi

entries.heading: Global Cycling with Shift-Tab
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:26] Press S-<tab> anywhere in the document to cycle global visibility: | State    | Shows                                    | |----------+------------------------------------------| | Overview | Only top-level headlines                 | | Contents | All headlines at all levels              | | Show All | Everything expanded                      |

entries.heading: Visibility Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:26] | Key       | Command                             | |-----------+-------------------------------------| | <tab>       | Cycle visibility at current heading | | S-<tab> | Cycle global visibility             | Additional visibility can be controlled through speed commands (see [[file:23-speed-commands.org][Speed Commands]]): | Speed Key | Action              | |-----------+---------------------| | c         | Cycle visibility    | | C   | Show children       | | o

entries.heading: Motion Between Headlines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:27] Efficient navigation between headlines is essential for working with large documents.

entries.heading: Navigation Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:27] | Key                   | Command                         | |-----------------------+---------------------------------| | C-c C-j         | Jump to any heading (with menu) | | Next/Previous heading | Built-in VS Code outline        |

entries.heading: Using the Outline View
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:27] The VS Code Outline view provides visual navigation: 1. Open the Outline view (sidebar or Cmd/C-S-O) 2. Click any heading to jump to it 3. Use the filter box to search headings

entries.heading: Jump to Heading
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:27] Press C-c C-j to open a quick-pick menu of all headings. Type to filter and press Enter to jump.

entries.heading: Speed Command Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:27] With speed commands enabled (scimax.speedCommands.enabled: true), when your cursor is at the beginning of a headline, single keys navigate: | Key | Action                               | |-----+--------------------------------------| | n   | Next heading (any level)             | | p   | Previous heading (any level)         | | f   | Next heading (same level - forward)  | | b   | Previous heading (same level - back) | | u   | Up to parent heading                 |

entries.heading: Structure Editing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:28] Scimax VS Code provides commands to restructure your document without manual cut-and-paste.

entries.heading: Promote/Demote Headlines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:28] Change the level of a headline: | Key             | Command                          | |-----------------+----------------------------------| | M-<left>        | Promote heading (decrease level) | | M-<right>       | Demote heading (increase level)  | | M-S-Left  | Promote subtree                  | | M-S-Right | Demote subtree                   | *Promote* means moving toward the root (** -> *). *Demote* means moving away from the root (* -> **).

entries.heading: Single Heading vs Subtree
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:28] - *Promote/Demote Heading*: Changes only the current headline's level - *Promote/Demote Subtree*: Changes the headline AND all its children Example - promoting a subtree: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,** Parent                    * Parent ,*** Child 1          ->       ** Child 1 ,*** Child 2                  ** Child 2 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Move Subtrees Up/Down
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:39] Reorder sections without changing their level: | Key      | Command                              | |----------+--------------------------------------| | M-<up>   | Move subtree up (swap with previous) | | M-<down> | Move subtree down (swap with next)   | The entire subtree (heading and all its content/children) moves together.

entries.heading: Kill/Clone Subtrees
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:31] | Command                 | Description                   | |-------------------------+-------------------------------| | scimax.org.killSubtree  | Cut the current subtree       | | scimax.org.cloneSubtree | Duplicate the current subtree | Speed command keys (at heading start): | Key     | Action                    | |---------+---------------------------| | w       | Kill (cut) subtree        | | W | Clone (duplicate) subtree | | y       | Yank (paste) subtree

entries.heading: Insert New Headings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:31] | Key        | Command                      | |------------+------------------------------| | C-<return> | Insert heading at same level | The command scimax.org.insertHeading inserts a new heading. The behavior depends on context: - On a heading line: Insert new heading at same level - In body text: Insert new heading after current section For subheadings: | Command                     | Description                     | |-----------------------------+-------------

entries.heading: Document Keywords
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:32] Document keywords appear at the beginning of the file and configure document-wide settings.

entries.heading: Common Keywords
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:32] #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TITLE: Document Title ,#+AUTHOR: Author Name ,#+DATE: 2026-01-13 ,#+EMAIL: author@example.com #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Options Keyword
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:32] The #+OPTIONS: keyword controls export and display behavior: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+OPTIONS: toc:2 num:t H:4 ^:nil #+END_SRC | Option | Values         | Description                    | |--------+----------------+--------------------------------| | toc    | t, nil, number | Table of contents depth        | | num    | t, nil         | Section numbering              | | H      | number         | Headline levels for export     | | ^      | t, nil, {}     | Subscript/super

entries.heading: Startup Keyword
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:18] Control initial visibility: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+STARTUP: overview    # Start with all headings folded ,#+STARTUP: content     # Show all headings, hide body ,#+STARTUP: showall     # Show everything #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Property Keyword
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 10:07] Set default properties for source blocks: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+PROPERTY: header-args :exports both ,#+PROPERTY: header-args:python :session *python* #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Properties Drawers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:32] Properties drawers store metadata about a headline in key-value pairs.

entries.heading: Creating Properties Drawers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:32] Properties appear in a :PROPERTIES: drawer immediately after the headline: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* My Headline :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: my-headline :CATEGORY: work :EFFORT: 2:00 :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Special Properties
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:33] Certain properties have special meaning: | Property    | Description                              | |-------------+------------------------------------------| | ID         | Globally unique identifier (UUID)        | | CUSTOM_ID  | Document-unique identifier for linking   | | CATEGORY   | Category for agenda views                | | EFFORT     | Estimated time (H:MM format)             | | COLUMNS    | Column view format specification         | | VISIBILITY | Initi

entries.heading: Adding Properties
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:33] To add a property via speed commands, press P at a heading start. You can also add properties manually by typing inside the drawer.

entries.heading: Inherited Properties
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:39] Some properties are inherited by child headlines. The CATEGORY property, for example, applies to all children unless overridden.

entries.heading: Drawers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:40] Drawers are collapsible sections that hide auxiliary information.

entries.heading: PROPERTIES Drawer
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:40] Stores headline metadata (see above).

entries.heading: LOGBOOK Drawer
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:40] Stores clock entries and state change history: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO My Task :LOGBOOK: CLOCK: [2026-01-13 Mon 09:00]--[2026-01-13 Mon 10:30] =>  1:30 - State "TODO"       from "WAITING"    [2026-01-12 Sun 14:00] :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Custom Drawers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:39] Create custom drawers for any purpose. These are not exported. :NOTES: These are private notes that won't be exported. - Reference: Smith et al. 2024 - Follow up with collaborator :END: :REFERENCES: cite:&kitchin-2018-machin-learn-catal cite:&kitchin-2015-examp-effec :END: Drawer names must be uppercase letters and can contain numbers and underscores.

entries.heading: Drawer Visibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:39] Drawers are typically displayed collapsed. Click or use fold commands to expand/collapse them.

entries.heading: Inline Tasks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:34] Inline tasks are special headlines at a very deep level (default: 15 stars or more) that are treated as inline content within a section rather than as document structure.

entries.heading: Creating Inline Tasks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:34] An inline task uses many stars (15+) and has a matching END marker: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Main Headline Content of the headline. ,*************** TODO Quick inline task This is an inline task that doesn't affect document structure. It's useful for small, self-contained TODOs within prose. ,*************** END More content continues here. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Inline Task Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:34] Inline tasks support the same features as regular headlines: | Feature     | Example                                      | |-------------+----------------------------------------------| | TODO state  | *************** TODO Task                   | | Priority    | *************** [#A] High priority          | | Tags        | *************** Task :urgent:work:          | | Body text   | Content between task and END                 |

entries.heading: When to Use Inline Tasks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] - Quick TODOs embedded in documentation - Small tasks that don't warrant their own section - Notes or reminders within prose - Tasks that shouldn't appear in document outline

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] The minimum headline level for inline tasks is configurable. By default, headlines with 15 or more stars are treated as inline tasks.

entries.heading: Footnote Definitions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] Footnotes allow you to add supplementary information without interrupting the main text flow.

entries.heading: Footnote Definition Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] Footnotes are defined with [fn:LABEL] at the start of a line: #+BEGIN_SRC org This paragraph has a footnote reference[fn:1]. [fn:1] This is the footnote content. It can span multiple lines if subsequent lines are indented. Another paragraph continues here. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Footnote Labels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] Footnotes can use numeric or named labels: #+BEGIN_SRC org See the paper for details[fn:1]. This is a key concept[fn:important-note]. [fn:1] Smith et al., 2024. [fn:important-note] A named footnote for easy reference. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Multi-line Footnotes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] Footnote definitions can span multiple lines with indentation: #+BEGIN_SRC org [fn:long-note] This is a longer footnote that spans multiple lines. All continuation lines must be indented to be included in the footnote. You can even have multiple paragraphs by leaving a blank line with proper indentation. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Inline Footnotes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] For short footnotes, use inline syntax: #+BEGIN_SRC org This has an inline footnote[fn:: This is the definition]. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] See [[file:05-links.org][Links]] for information on footnote references.

entries.heading: Dynamic Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] Dynamic blocks are special regions whose content is generated programmatically. They are defined with #+BEGIN: and #+END: markers.

entries.heading: Dynamic Block Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+BEGIN: block-name parameters Content that will be replaced when block is updated. ,#+END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: [#C]  Clock Table Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:35] The most common dynamic block is the clock table, which summarizes time spent: #+BEGIN: clocktable :maxlevel 2 :scope file | Headline | Time | |---+---| |---+---| | *Total* | 0:00 | #+END:

entries.heading: Column View Example  :columns:
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:40] Column view displays properties in a table format: #+BEGIN: columnview :hlines 1 | ITEM                             | TODO | PRIORITY | TAGS      | |----------------------------------+------+----------+-----------| |  Document Structure            |      |          |           | |  Headlines                     |      |          |           | |  Creating Headlines            |      |          |           | |  Headline Components           |      |          |

entries.heading: Dynamic Block Parameters
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:41] Common parameters for clock tables: | Parameter | Description                        | Example         | |-----------+------------------------------------+-----------------| | :maxlevel | Maximum headline depth             | :maxlevel 3     | | :scope    | Scope of clock data                | :scope file     | | :tstart   | Start time for report              | :tstart "<-1w>" | | :tend     | End time for report                | :tend "<now>"   | | :block    | Time

entries.heading: Updating Dynamic Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:41] Dynamic blocks are updated when explicitly requested (C-c C-c on the header). The content between #+BEGIN: and #+END: is regenerated based on the block type and parameters.

entries.heading: Document Organization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:38] 1. *Start with an outline* - Create your heading structure before adding content 2. *Use consistent levels* - Don't skip levels arbitrarily 3. *Keep headings concise* - Use brief, descriptive titles 4. *Use tags for cross-cutting concerns* - Don't rely solely on hierarchy

entries.heading: Heading Depth Guidelines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:38] | Level | Typical Use                              | |-------+------------------------------------------| | 1     | Major sections/chapters                  | | 2     | Subsections                              | | 3     | Topics within subsections                | | 4     | Detailed points                          | | 5+    | Rarely needed; consider restructuring    |

entries.heading: Navigation Efficiency
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:38] 1. *Use C-c C-j* for direct jumps to any heading 2. *Use outline view* for visual navigation in long documents 3. *Enable speed commands* for rapid single-key navigation 4. *Use S-<tab>* to get an overview before diving in

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:38] - [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items]] - Task states and priorities in headlines - [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] - Adding dates to headlines - [[file:05-links.org][Links]] - Linking to headlines - [[file:23-speed-commands.org][Speed Commands]] - Single-key commands at headlines - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - How structure affects exported documents

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:01.5-basic-syntax.org][Basic Syntax]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items]]

entries.heading: TODO Items
entries.content: Scimax VS Code provides a comprehensive task management system built into your documents. TODO items are headlines with a special keyword that indicates their status.

entries.heading: Creating TODO Items
entries.content: Add TODO after the headline stars to create a task: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Write documentation ,** TODO Complete first draft ,** TODO Review and edit #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Cycling TODO States
entries.content: Press C-c C-t on a headline to cycle through TODO states: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE (no keyword)  TODO  DONE  (no keyword) #+END_EXAMPLE Or use the command scimax.org.cycleTodo. With speed commands enabled, press t at the beginning of a headline.

entries.heading: TODO Keywords
entries.content: The default TODO keywords are: | Keyword | Meaning                    | |---------+----------------------------| | TODO    | Task that needs to be done | | DONE    | Completed task             | Additional states available: | Keyword     | Meaning                              | |-------------+--------------------------------------| | NEXT       | Next action to take                  | | WAITING    | Waiting for external input           | | HOLD       | On hold / paused                     | | CA

entries.heading: Logging Completion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:41] When you mark a task as DONE, a CLOSED timestamp is automatically added: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* DONE Write introduction CLOSED: [2026-01-13 Mon 15:30] #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Priorities
entries.content: Priorities help you identify the most important tasks.

entries.heading: Setting Priorities
entries.content: Add a priority cookie after the TODO keyword: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO [#A] Urgent and important task ,* TODO [#B] Important but not urgent ,* TODO [#C] Nice to have #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Priority Levels
entries.content: | Priority | Meaning                         | |----------+---------------------------------| | [#A]     | High priority - do first        | | [#B]     | Medium priority - do soon       | | [#C]     | Low priority - do when possible |

entries.heading: Priority Commands
entries.content: | Key/Command                | Action                    | |----------------------------+---------------------------| | Speed key 1               | Set priority A            | | Speed key 2               | Set priority B            | | Speed key 3               | Set priority C            | | Speed key 0               | Remove priority           | | Speed key ,               | Increase priority (CBA) | You can also set priority through the command palette: scimax.org.setPriority

entries.heading: Progress Indicators
entries.content: Track progress through subtasks using statistics cookies and checkboxes.

entries.heading: Fraction Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:42] Shows completed/total count:

entries.heading: Percentage Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:47] Shows completion percentage:

entries.heading: TODO Deployment
entries.content: Statistics cookies update automatically when child TODO states change.

entries.heading: Checkbox Lists
entries.content: For simpler task lists within a section, use checkboxes:

entries.heading: Shopping List [2/4]
entries.content: - [X] Milk - [X] Bread - [ ] Eggs - [x] Butter

entries.heading: Checkbox States
entries.content: | Syntax | State                                   | |--------+-----------------------------------------| | [ ]    | Unchecked / not done                    | | [X]    | Checked / done                          | | [-]    | Partially complete (has mixed children) |

entries.heading: Toggling Checkboxes
entries.content: Press C-c C-c with cursor on a checkbox line to toggle it. Or use scimax.org.toggleCheckbox.

entries.heading: Nested Checkboxes
entries.content: Checkboxes can be nested. Parent checkboxes show aggregate state: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Packing List [1/2] - [-] Clothes [2/3] - [X] Shirts - [X] Pants - [ ] Socks - [X] Toiletries [3/3] - [X] Toothbrush - [X] Soap - [X] Towel #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Inserting Checkboxes
entries.content: | Command                   | Description               | |---------------------------+---------------------------| | scimax.org.insertCheckbox | Insert checkbox at cursor | Type - [ ] followed by space to manually create a checkbox item.

entries.heading: Extended TODO Keywords
entries.content: Beyond TODO and DONE, use these states for workflow management:

entries.heading: NEXT
entries.content: Indicates the very next action to take: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* NEXT Call client about project requirements #+END_SRC Use NEXT for tasks you're actively working on or will work on immediately.

entries.heading: WAITING
entries.content: Task is blocked waiting for someone or something: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* WAITING Review from manager :PROPERTIES: :WAITING_ON: John Smith :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: HOLD
entries.content: Task is paused but not cancelled: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* HOLD Website redesign Paused until Q2 budget approval. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: CANCELLED
entries.content: Task won't be done (but kept for records): #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* CANCELLED Old feature request No longer relevant after product pivot. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Workflow Example
entries.content: A typical task progression: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE TODO  NEXT  WAITING  NEXT  DONE  HOLD  NEXT  DONE  CANCELLED #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Custom TODO Keywords
entries.content: You can define your own TODO workflow states for each file using the #+TODO: keyword. This is useful for project-specific workflows like code review, content publishing, or approval processes.

entries.heading: Defining Custom States
entries.content: Add #+TODO: at the top of your org file (before any headings): #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: DRAFT REVIEW | PUBLISHED REJECTED #+END_SRC The | separates active (incomplete) states from done (complete) states. When you cycle TODO states, they will follow this sequence: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE (none)  DRAFT  REVIEW  PUBLISHED  (none) #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Multiple TODO Lines
entries.content: You can define multiple workflow sequences: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: TODO IN-PROGRESS | DONE ,#+TODO: BUG INVESTIGATING FIXING | FIXED WONTFIX #+END_SRC All states from all #+TODO: lines are recognized.

entries.heading: Without Pipe Separator
entries.content: If you omit the |, the last state is treated as done: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: IDEA DRAFT REVIEW PUBLISHED #+END_SRC This makes PUBLISHED the done state.

entries.heading: Syntax Variants
entries.content: These keywords are all equivalent: | Keyword       | Usage                              | |---------------+------------------------------------| | #+TODO:      | Standard TODO keyword definition   | | #+SEQ_TODO:  | Sequential workflow (same as TODO) | | #+TYP_TODO:  | Type-based workflow                |

entries.heading: Code Review Workflow
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: DRAFT REVIEW APPROVED | MERGED REJECTED ,* DRAFT Implement new feature ,* REVIEW Fix login bug ,* APPROVED Update documentation #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Content Publishing Workflow
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: IDEA OUTLINE WRITING EDITING | PUBLISHED ARCHIVED ,* WRITING Blog post about org-mode ,* EDITING Tutorial on source blocks #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Project Management Workflow
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TODO: BACKLOG SPRINT IN-PROGRESS TESTING | DONE CANCELLED ,* IN-PROGRESS User authentication ,* TESTING Payment integration #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Logging State Changes
entries.content: Scimax VS Code can log when and how TODO states change.

entries.heading: LOGBOOK Drawer
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] State changes are recorded in the LOGBOOK drawer: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* DONE Complete documentation CLOSED: [2026-01-13 Mon 16:00] :LOGBOOK: - State "DONE"       from "TODO"       [2026-01-13 Mon 16:00] - State "TODO"       from "WAITING"    [2026-01-12 Sun 10:00] - State "WAITING"    from "TODO"       [2026-01-10 Fri 14:30] :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Timestamps on State Changes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:39] When enabled, each state change adds: - A timestamp showing when the change occurred - The previous state This creates a complete history of task progress.

entries.heading: Progress Logging for Repeating Tasks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] When a repeating task cycles back to TODO (e.g., a task with =DEADLINE: <2026-01-30 Fri +1w>=), you can optionally log the completion event with a timestamp and note.

entries.heading: Enabling Progress Logging
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] Progress logging is off by default. Enable it with:

entries.heading: Global Setting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:41] #+begin_src json { "scimax.org.logRepeat": "time"  // or "note" for note prompts } #+end_src

entries.heading: File-Level Override
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:42] Add a #+STARTUP keyword at the top of your org file: #+begin_src org ,#+STARTUP: logrepeat       ;; Enable with timestamp ,#+STARTUP: lognoterepeat   ;; Enable with note prompt ,#+STARTUP: nologrepeat     ;; Disable #+end_src

entries.heading: Heading-Level Override
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] Add a =:LOGGING:= property to individual headings: #+begin_src org ,* TODO Weekly review :PROPERTIES: :LOGGING: logrepeat :END: DEADLINE: <2026-01-30 Fri +1w> #+end_src

entries.heading: Priority Order
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] Settings are resolved in this priority order (highest to lowest): 1. Heading =:LOGGING:= property 2. File =#+STARTUP:= keywords 3. Global =scimax.org.logRepeat= setting

entries.heading: Log Output Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] When you mark a repeating task as done with logging enabled: #+begin_src org ,* TODO Weekly review DEADLINE: <2026-02-06 Fri +1w> :PROPERTIES: :LAST_REPEAT: [2026-01-23 Fri 07:31] :END: - State "DONE"       from "TODO"       [2026-01-23 Fri 07:31] #+end_src The log shows: - =LAST_REPEAT= property with when the task was last completed - State change entry showing the transition from TODO to DONE

entries.heading: Logging to Drawer
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] By default, log entries appear in the body text. To log into a drawer: #+begin_src json { "scimax.org.logIntoDrawer": true       // Use :LOGBOOK: drawer // or "scimax.org.logIntoDrawer": "MYLOG"    // Use custom drawer name } #+end_src Or use file-level =#+STARTUP: logdrawer= to enable. With drawer logging, the output becomes: #+begin_src org ,* TODO Weekly review DEADLINE: <2026-02-06 Fri +1w> :PROPERTIES: :LAST_REPEAT: [2026-01-23 Fri 07:31] :END: :LOGBOOK: - Sta

entries.heading: Note Prompts
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] When =logRepeat= is set to ="note"=, you'll be prompted to enter a note when completing a repeating task. The note is included in the log entry: #+begin_src org - State "DONE"       from "TODO"       [2026-01-23 Fri 07:31] \\ Completed early because of deadline change. #+end_src If you cancel or leave the note empty, the entry is logged without a note.

entries.heading: Configuration Summary
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:28] | Setting                  | Values                | Description                         | |--------------------------+-----------------------+-------------------------------------| | scimax.org.logRepeat     | "false"/"time"/"note" | Enable/disable repeat logging       | | scimax.org.logIntoDrawer | boolean or string     | Where to log (body or drawer)       | | #+STARTUP: logrepeat     | -                     | File-level: log with timestamp      | | #+STARTUP: l

entries.heading: Tags for TODO Items
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:39] Tags provide additional categorization beyond the headline hierarchy.

entries.heading: Adding Tags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:39] Tags appear at the end of the headline, enclosed in colons: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Review quarterly report                               :work:urgent: ,* TODO Buy groceries                                         :personal:errands: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Tag Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:39] | Key/Command        | Action               | |--------------------+----------------------| | Speed key ;  | Edit tags            | | scimax.org.setTags | Set tags via command |

entries.heading: Inherited Tags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:39] Child headlines inherit their parent's tags: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Work Projects                                              :work: ,** TODO Project A                                            :client1: This task has both :work: and :client1: tags. ,** TODO Project B                                            :internal: This task has both :work: and :internal: tags. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Common Tag Conventions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] | Tag       | Usage                   | |-----------+-------------------------| | @office   | Context: at office      | | @home     | Context: at home        | | @computer | Context: needs computer | | @phone    | Context: phone call     | | urgent    | Priority indicator      | | project   | Part of larger project  |

entries.heading: Filtering by Tags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] Use agenda views or search to filter tasks by tag: - scimax.db.searchByTag - Search for specific tags - scimax.agenda.filterByTag - Filter agenda by tag

entries.heading: Scheduling and Deadlines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] Assign dates to tasks for planning.

entries.heading: SCHEDULED
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] When you plan to start or work on a task: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Write report SCHEDULED: <2026-01-15 Wed> #+END_SRC

entries.heading: DEADLINE
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] When a task must be completed by: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Submit proposal DEADLINE: <2026-01-20 Mon> #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Both Together
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Complete project SCHEDULED: <2026-01-15 Wed> DEADLINE: <2026-01-25 Sat> #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Adding Dates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] | Speed Key | Action                  | |-----------+-------------------------| | s         | Add/edit SCHEDULED date | | d         | Add/edit DEADLINE date  | | .         | Insert timestamp        | Or use commands: - scimax.org.schedule - scimax.org.deadline See [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] for more on date formats.

entries.heading: Time Tracking
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:40] Track time spent on tasks using clock entries.

entries.heading: Clock Entries
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Clock entries are stored in the LOGBOOK drawer: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Working on documentation :LOGBOOK: CLOCK: [2026-01-13 Mon 09:00]--[2026-01-13 Mon 10:30] =>  1:30 CLOCK: [2026-01-12 Sun 14:00]--[2026-01-12 Sun 16:00] =>  2:00 :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Total Time
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] The total clocked time appears in the properties or can be calculated for reports.

entries.heading: Effort Estimates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Estimate how long tasks will take.

entries.heading: Setting Effort
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] :PROPERTIES: :Effort: 0:30 :END: Add an EFFORT property: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO Review document :PROPERTIES: :EFFORT: 1:30 :END: #+END_SRC | Speed Key | Action              | |-----------+---------------------| | e         | Set effort estimate |

entries.heading: Effort Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Use H:MM format: - 0:30 - 30 minutes - 1:00 - 1 hour - 2:30 - 2 hours 30 minutes

entries.heading: Agenda Integration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] TODO items appear in agenda views for planning and review.

entries.heading: Viewing All TODOs
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Use scimax.agenda.todoList or scimax.db.showTodos to see all tasks.

entries.heading: Deadline View
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Use scimax.agenda.deadlines to see upcoming and overdue deadlines.

entries.heading: Filtering Options
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] - By priority (A, B, C) - By tag - By date range - By TODO state See [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda]] for complete agenda documentation.

entries.heading: Task Granularity
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Make tasks actionable: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* TODO "Write documentation"           ; Too vague ,* TODO Write introduction section      ; Better - specific and actionable #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Use NEXT for Clarity
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Always have at least one NEXT task to know what to work on: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Project: New Feature ,** DONE Design architecture ,** NEXT Implement core module           ;  Clear next step ,** TODO Write tests ,** TODO Deploy to staging #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Regular Review
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Periodically review tasks to: - Move stale TODO items to HOLD or CANCELLED - Update WAITING items - Identify next actions

entries.heading: Tags vs Hierarchy
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] Use hierarchy for project structure, tags for cross-cutting concerns: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Work                                                       :work: ,** Project A ,*** TODO Task requiring phone                                :@phone: ,*** TODO Task requiring computer                             :@computer: ,** Project B ,*** TODO Another phone task                                  :@phone: #+END_SRC Now you can filter by @phone to see all phone tasks across p

entries.heading: Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:41] | Key           | Action           | |---------------+------------------| | C-c C-t | Cycle TODO state | | C-c C-c | Toggle checkbox  |

entries.heading: Speed Commands (at heading start)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] | Key     | Action             | |---------+--------------------| | t       | Cycle TODO state   | | 1/2/3   | Set priority A/B/C | | 0       | Clear priority     | | ,       | Increase priority  | | s       | Schedule           | | d       | Deadline           | | e       | Set effort         | | ; | Set tags           | | I | Clock in           | | O | Clock out          |

entries.heading: Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] | Command                   | Description             | |---------------------------+-------------------------| | scimax.org.cycleTodo      | Cycle TODO state        | | scimax.org.toggleCheckbox | Toggle checkbox         | | scimax.org.insertCheckbox | Insert checkbox         | | scimax.org.schedule       | Add SCHEDULED timestamp | | scimax.org.deadline       | Add DEADLINE timestamp  | | scimax.db.showTodos       | Show all TODO items     | | scimax.agenda.todoL

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:42] - [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] - Date formats for scheduling and deadlines - [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda]] - Viewing and filtering tasks - [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Headlines and organization

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:04-tables.org][Tables]]

entries.heading: Tables
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:07] Org-mode tables provide spreadsheet-like functionality directly in your text documents. Scimax VS Code supports creating, editing, navigating, and calculating with tables.

entries.heading: Manual Creation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:07] Type a table using pipe characters (|) as column separators: | Name  | Age | City     | |-------+-----+----------| | Alice | 30  | New York | | Bob   | 25  | Boston   | When you press Tab after entering content, the table auto-aligns.

entries.heading: Table Creation Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:07] Press =C-c |= or use `scimax.table.create' to insert a table template. You'll be prompted for the number of columns and rows.

entries.heading: Converting Text to Table
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:26] Select comma-separated or tab-separated text, then use =C-c |= to convert it to a table. 1,2 3,4 leads to | 1 | 2 | | 3 | 4 |

entries.heading: Moving Between Cells
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:43] | Key        | Action                                 | |------------+----------------------------------------| | <tab>      | Move to next cell (creates row at end) | | S-<tab>    | Move to previous cell                  | | Arrow keys | Move in that direction                 |

entries.heading: Quick Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:43] | Command                | Description           | |------------------------+-----------------------| | scimax.table.nextCell  | Go to next cell       | | scimax.table.prevCell  | Go to previous cell   | | scimax.table.gotoNamed | Jump to a named table |

entries.heading: Adding/Removing Rows
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:41] | Key/Command                 | Key Binding         | Action                   | |-----------------------------+---------------------+--------------------------| | scimax.table.insertRowAbove | M-S-Up        | Insert row above current | | scimax.table.insertRowBelow | M-S-Down      | Insert row below current | | scimax.table.deleteRow      | M-S-Backspace | Delete current row       |

entries.heading: Adding/Removing Columns
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:41] | Key/Command                    | Key Binding     | Action                     | |--------------------------------+-----------------+----------------------------| | scimax.table.insertColumnRight | M-S-Right | Insert column to the right | | scimax.table.insertColumnLeft  | M-S-Left  | Insert column to the left  | | scimax.table.deleteColumn      |                 | Delete current column      |

entries.heading: Moving Rows/Columns
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:37] | Command                      | Key Binding | Action            | |------------------------------+-------------+-------------------| | scimax.table.moveRowUp       | S-up        | Move row up       | | scimax.table.moveRowDown     | S-down      | Move row down     | | scimax.table.moveColumnLeft  | S-left      | Move column left  | | scimax.table.moveColumnRight | S-right     | Move column right |

entries.heading: Separator Lines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:36] Insert horizontal separator lines to divide table sections: | Key      | Action                  |         |   | |----------+-------------------------+---------+---| | C-c - | Insert separator line ( | ---+--- | ) | Example with separators: #+BEGIN_SRC org | Item     | Price | |----------+-------| | Widget A | 10.00 | | Widget B | 15.00 | |----------+-------| | Total    | 25.00 | #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Automatic Alignment
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:15] Tables auto-align when you press Tab. Column widths adjust to fit content.

entries.heading: Column Width Specification
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:43] Specify fixed column widths using <N> in a cell: |                   <l>                   |  <l>  | | Long text you don't want showing all of | Short | | More long                               | More  | |                   <5>                   |  <l>  | | Long text you don't want showing all of | Short | | More long                               | More  | Text exceeding the width is truncated in display (but preserved internally).

entries.heading: Horizontal Alignment
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 15:32] Specify alignment using <l>, <c>, or <r>: |     <l>      |     <c>     |      <r>      | |--------------+-------------+---------------| | Left aligned | Center text | Right aligned | | More left    |  Centered   |    More right | | Marker | Alignment | |--------+-----------| | <l>    | Left      | | <c>    | Center    | | <r>    | Right     | Combine with width: <l10> for left-aligned, 10 characters wide.

entries.heading: Table Formulas
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:44] Tables can include formulas for calculations, similar to spreadsheets.

entries.heading: Column References
entries.content: | Reference | Meaning                     | |-----------+-----------------------------| | $1        | First column                | | $2        | Second column               | | $N        | Nth column                  | | $0        | Current column              | | $+1       | Next column (relative)      | | $-2       | Two columns back (relative) | | $<        | First column                | | $>        | Last column                 | | $#        | Total number of columns     |

entries.heading: Row References
entries.content: | Reference | Meaning                       | |-----------+-------------------------------| | @1        | First row                     | | @2        | Second row                    | | @N        | Nth row                       | | @0        | Current row                   | | @+1       | Next row (relative)           | | @-1       | Previous row (relative)       | | @<        | First row                     | | @>        | Last row                      | | @I        | First hline

entries.heading: Combined References
entries.content: | Reference | Meaning               | |-----------+-----------------------| | @2$3      | Row 2, column 3       | | @3$>      | Row 3, last column    | | @>$4      | Last row, column 4    | | @0$0      | Current cell          | | @0$3      | Current row, column 3 | | @2$0      | Row 2, current column | | @+1$-1    | Relative reference    |

entries.heading: Ranges
entries.content: | Reference  | Meaning                     | |------------+-----------------------------| | @2$1..@5$1 | Column 1, rows 2 through 5  | | @2$1..@2$4 | Row 2, columns 1 through 4  | | @2$1..@5$4 | Rectangle from @2$1 to @5$4 | | $2..$5     | Columns 2-5 in current row  |

entries.heading: Formula Syntax
entries.content: Formulas use the syntax: `target'expression= #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TBLFM: $4=$2*$3 #+END_SRC This sets column 4 to the product of columns 2 and 3. Multiple formulas separated by `::': #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TBLFM: $4=$2*$3::@>$4=vsum(@2$4..@-1$4) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Built-in Functions
entries.content: | Function | Description              | |----------+--------------------------| | vsum     | Sum of values in range   | | vmean    | Average of values        | | vmin     | Minimum value            | | vmax     | Maximum value            | | vcount   | Count of values          | | vprod    | Product of values        | | sdev     | Standard deviation       | Example: | Value | |-------| | 10    | | 20    | | 30    | |-------| | 60    | #+TBLFM: @5$1=vsum(@2$1..@4$1) #

entries.heading: Recalculating Formulas
entries.content: | Key/Command              | Action                   | |--------------------------+--------------------------| | C-c C-c (on TBLFM) | Recalculate all formulas | | scimax.table.recalculate | Recalculate table        | Place your cursor on the `#+TBLFM:' line and press `C-c C-c' to apply all formulas.

entries.heading: Named Parameters and Constants
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:29] Named parameters let you use meaningful names instead of cell references.

entries.heading: Table Parameters ($ rows)
entries.content: Define parameters directly in the table using a row where cells contain =$name=value= assignments: | $tax=0.08 | $discount=0.10 | |-----------+----------------| | Price     | 0              | |-----------+----------------| | 100       | 108            | | 200       | 216            | #+TBLFM: $2=$1*(1+$tax)*(1-$discount) The =$tax= and =$discount= values are extracted from the first row and can be used as =$tax= and =$discount= in formulas.

entries.heading: Document Constants (#+CONSTANTS:)
entries.content: Define constants at the document level using the =#+CONSTANTS:= keyword: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+CONSTANTS: pi=3.14159 e=2.71828 tax_rate=0.075 #+END_SRC Then use them in any table formula in the document: | Radius | Area   | |--------+--------| | 5      | 78.54  | | 10     | 314.16 | #+TBLFM: $2=$pi*$1^2;%.2f Multiple =#+CONSTANTS:= lines can be used; all constants are combined.

entries.heading: Column Names
entries.content: Header row values can be used as column references. Given: | Price | Quantity | Total | |-------+----------+-------| | 10    | 5        | 50    | | 20    | 3        | 60    | #+TBLFM: $Total=$Price*$Quantity Column names are case-insensitive.

entries.heading: Duration and Time Calculations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:29] Tables can calculate with time/duration values in =HH:MM= or =HH:MM:SS= format.

entries.heading: Duration Format Flags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-24 Sat 17:48] | Flag | Output Format      | Example | |------+--------------------+---------| | ;T   | HH:MM:SS           | 2:30:00 | | ;U   | HH:MM (no seconds) | 2:30    | | ;t   | Decimal hours      | 2.50    |

entries.heading: Duration Calculation Example
