entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:05-links.org][Links]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]]

entries.heading: Source Code Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:04] Source code blocks are the foundation of literate programming in org-mode. They allow you to embed executable code within your documents, creating notebooks that combine narrative text, code, and results. This guide covers everything you need to know about working with source blocks in Scimax VS Code.

entries.heading: Introduction to Literate Programming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:04] Literate programming, pioneered by Donald Knuth, is a programming paradigm that treats programs as works of literature. Instead of writing code with comments, you write documentation with embedded code.

entries.heading: Benefits of Literate Programming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:04] - *Documentation and code stay synchronized* - Your explanations live alongside the code they describe - *Better understanding* - Force yourself to explain your reasoning - *Reproducible research* - Combine analysis, code, and results in one document - *Exploratory programming* - Test ideas interactively like a notebook - *Multiple outputs from one source* - Tangle code files and export documentation

entries.heading: Literate Programming in Org-Mode
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:04] Org-mode's Babel system brings literate programming to org documents: - Write code in source blocks with full syntax highlighting - Execute blocks and capture results inline - Pass data between blocks in different languages - Extract (tangle) code to external files - Include or exclude code/results in exports

entries.heading: Basic Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:04] A source block begins with #+BEGIN_SRC and ends with #+END_SRC: #+BEGIN_SRC python print("Hello, world!") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello, world!

entries.heading: Language Declaration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:05] The language comes immediately after #+BEGIN_SRC: #+BEGIN_SRC python # Python code here #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC javascript // JavaScript code here #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC shell # Shell commands here #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Header Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:55] Header arguments control block behavior and appear after the language: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results output :session *python* # This block prints results and uses a persistent session #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Results Section
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:55] When you execute a block, results appear immediately below in a #+RESULTS: section: #+BEGIN_SRC python print(2 + 2) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 4

entries.heading: Execution Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:52] | Keybinding                                                         | Action                              | Platform | | ----------------------------+------------------------------------- | ----------                          |          | | C-<return> / s-<return>                                            | Execute current block               | All      | | C-c C-c                                                            | Execute current block (Emacs style) |

entries.heading: Execution Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:11] | Command                     | Key Binding | Description                      | |-----------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------| | scimax.org.executeBlock     | C-c C-c     | Execute the current source block | | scimax.ob.executeAndNext    | S-Enter     | Execute and jump to next block   | | scimax.ob.executeAndNew     | M-S-Enter   | Execute and new                  | | scimax.ob.executeToPoint    |             | Execute all blocks

entries.heading: Execution Flow
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:26] 1. Place cursor inside a source block 2. Press C-<return> (or s-<return> on Mac) 3. Code executes using the appropriate language interpreter 4. Results appear below the block in a #+RESULTS: section 5. Previous results are replaced automatically

entries.heading: Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:11] #+BEGIN_SRC python import math result = math.sqrt(16) print(f"The square root of 16 is {result}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : The square root of 16 is 4.0

entries.heading: Supported Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:10] Scimax VS Code supports a wide range of programming languages through both direct execution and Jupyter kernel integration.

entries.heading: Direct Execution Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:10] These languages execute directly without requiring Jupyter: | Language   | Identifiers          | Requirement          | |------------+----------------------+----------------------| | Python     | python, python3, py  | Python 3.x in PATH   | | JavaScript | javascript, js, node | Node.js installed    | | TypeScript | typescript, ts       | TypeScript installed | | Shell/Bash | sh, bash, shell      | Bash shell           | | SQL        | sql, sqlite          | Datab

entries.heading: Jupyter Kernel Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:10] For enhanced interactive features, use Jupyter kernels by prefixing the language with jupyter- or relying on automatic Jupyter detection: | Language | Explicit Syntax | Auto-Detect | Kernel Required  | |----------+-----------------+-------------+------------------| | Python   | jupyter-python  | Yes         | ipykernel        | | R        | jupyter-r       | Yes         | IRkernel         | | Julia    | jupyter-julia   | Yes         | IJulia           | | Ruby

entries.heading: Jupyter Benefits
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:26] Using Jupyter kernels provides: - *Persistent state* - Variables persist between executions in the same session - *Rich output* - Display plots, images, HTML, and LaTeX - *Interactive widgets* - Use ipywidgets and similar libraries - *Automatic display* - Images from matplotlib, plots, etc. appear automatically

entries.heading: Example: Mixing Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:26] #+BEGIN_SRC shell echo "System: $(uname -s)" #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : System: Darwin #+BEGIN_SRC python import platform print(f"Python version: {platform.python_version()}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Python version: 3.12.11 #+BEGIN_SRC javascript console.log(`Node version: ${process.version}`); #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Node version: v25.2.1

entries.heading: Header Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:27] Header arguments customize how source blocks execute and how results are handled. They appear after the language name.

entries.heading: Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:33] #+BEGIN_SRC python :var arg1="value1" arg2=5 :results output print(arg1, arg2) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : value1 5

entries.heading: :results - Control Output Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:33] The :results argument controls how execution results are formatted and displayed.

entries.heading: Collection Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:33] | Value  | Description                              | |--------+------------------------------------------| | output | Capture stdout/stderr (default for most) | | value  | Capture return value (last expression)   |

entries.heading: Format Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:34] | Value    | Description                         | |----------+-------------------------------------| | table    | Format output as an org table       | | list     | Format output as a list             | | verbatim | Fixed-width verbatim text (default) | | file     | Result is a file path/link          | | html     | Wrap in #+BEGIN_EXPORT html block   | | latex    | Wrap in #+BEGIN_EXPORT latex block  | | drawer   | Wrap in :RESULTS: drawer            |

entries.heading: Handling Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:34] | Value   | Description                        | |---------+------------------------------------| | replace | Replace previous results (default) | | append  | Append to previous results         | | prepend | Insert before previous results     | | silent  | Don't insert results               |

entries.heading: Examples
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:34] #+BEGIN_SRC python :results output print("Line 1") print("Line 2") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Line 1 : Line 2 #+BEGIN_SRC python :results value 42 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results output table print("Name,Age,City") print("Alice,30,NYC") print("Bob,25,Boston") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: | Name | Age | City | | Alice | 30 | NYC | | Bob | 25 | Boston | #+BEGIN_SRC python :results output file :file _static/plot-file.png import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot([

entries.heading: :exports - Control What Gets Exported
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:52] | Value   | Description                            | |---------+----------------------------------------| | code    | Export only the code block             | | results | Export only the results                | | both    | Export both code and results (default) | | none    | Don't export anything                  | #+BEGIN_SRC python :exports code # Only this code appears in PDF/HTML export print("Secret result") #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python :exports results # Onl

entries.heading: :var - Pass Variables to Code
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:54] Define input variables for the code block: #+BEGIN_SRC python :var name="Alice" age=30 print(f"{name} is {age} years old") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Alice is 30 years old Multiple variables: #+BEGIN_SRC python :var x=40 :var y=20 result = x + y print(f"{x} + {y} = {result}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 40 + 20 = 60 Reference named blocks or tables: #+NAME: my-data | Name  | Score | |-------+-------| | Alice | 95    | | Bob   | 87    | #+BEGIN_SRC python :var data=my-data f

entries.heading: :session - Enable Stateful Execution
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:54] Use sessions to maintain state between block executions: #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *mysession* x = 42 print("x defined") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : x defined #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *mysession* print(f"x = {x}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : x = 42 Session names: - :session - Use default session for this language - :session *name* - Use named session - :session none - Disable session (each block is isolated)

entries.heading: :dir - Set Working Directory
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:54] Execute code in a specific directory: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :dir /tmp pwd #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : /private/tmp #+BEGIN_SRC python :dir ../.github :results ouput import os print(os.getcwd()) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : /Users/jkitchin/Dropbox/projects/scimax_vscode/.github

entries.heading: :tangle - Extract Code to Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:55] Control whether code is extracted during tangling: | Value        | Description                       | |--------------+-----------------------------------| | no           | Don't tangle this block (default) | | yes          | Tangle to default file            | | filename.ext | Tangle to specific file           | #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle tangled/utils.py def helper_function(): """This function will be extracted to utils.py""" return "helper" #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SR

entries.heading: :cache - Cache Execution Results
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:57] Cache results to avoid re-execution: | Value | Description                                     | |-------+-------------------------------------------------| | no    | Don't cache (re-execute each time)              | | yes   | Cache results (only re-execute if code changes) | #+BEGIN_SRC python :cache yes :results output import time time.sleep(5)  # Expensive operation result = 42 print(result) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS[32df583c8e5bb748096d6e32871246035470139b]: : 42 On

entries.heading: :eval - Control Evaluation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:35] | Value        | Description                     | |--------------+---------------------------------| | yes          | Evaluate normally (default)     | | no           | Never evaluate                  | | query        | Ask before evaluating           | #+BEGIN_SRC sh :eval query ls | head -n2 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : _minted : _static #+BEGIN_SRC sh :eval no ls | head -n2 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: :wrap - Wrap Results in Block
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:56] Wrap results in a custom block: #+BEGIN_SRC python :wrap QUOTE print("This will be wrapped in a quote block") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: #+BEGIN_QUOTE This will be wrapped in a quote block #+END_QUOTE

entries.heading: :prologue and :epilogue - Code Injection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:59] Add code before/after the main block code: #+BEGIN_SRC python :prologue "import sys" :epilogue "print('Done')" print(sys.version) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 3.12.11 (main, Jun 12 2025, 12:22:42) [Clang 20.1.4 ] : Done

entries.heading: :cmdline - Command Line Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:00] Pass arguments to the interpreter: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :cmdline -x # Shell script runs with -x flag (print commands) echo "Hello" #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello

entries.heading: Combining Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:53] Arguments can be combined: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results output :session *analysis* :exports both :dir data import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv('data.csv') print(df.head()) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 1  2  3 : 0  4  5  6

entries.heading: Automatic Result Insertion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:00] When you execute a block, results automatically appear below it in a #+RESULTS: section. Previous results are replaced unless you specify :results append or :results prepend.

entries.heading: Text Output (Verbatim)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:00] Most languages produce text output by default, formatted with : prefix: #+BEGIN_SRC python print("Hello") print("World") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello : World

entries.heading: Tables
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:54] Python/R code that produces tabular data can be formatted as org tables: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results table :results value data = [['Alice', 30], ['Bob', 25], ['Carol', 35]] return data #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: | Alice | 30 | | Bob | 25 | | Carol | 35 |

entries.heading: File Links
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:55] When using :results file or Jupyter with plotting libraries, results are file links: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :results file import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9]); #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768484533710-2.png]] Images are automatically saved to .ob-jupyter/ directory when using Jupyter kernels.

entries.heading: HTML and LaTeX
entries.content:
CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:02] Blocks can produce rich formatted output: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results html html = "

Title

Paragraph

" print(html) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: #+BEGIN_EXPORT html

Title

Paragraph

#+END_EXPORT

entries.heading: Drawers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:43] Use drawers to fold long output: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results drawer for i in range(20): print(f"Line {i}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: :RESULTS: Line 0 Line 1 Line 2 Line 3 Line 4 Line 5 Line 6 Line 7 Line 8 Line 9 Line 10 Line 11 Line 12 Line 13 Line 14 Line 15 Line 16 Line 17 Line 18 Line 19 :END:

entries.heading: Error Handling
entries.content: When execution fails, error messages appear in results: #+BEGIN_SRC python :results value undefined_variable #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Traceback (most recent call last): :   File "<string>", line 50, in <module> :   File "<string>", line 1, in <module> : NameError: name 'undefined_variable' is not defined

entries.heading: Clearing Results
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] | Command                   | Description                    | |---------------------------+--------------------------------| | scimax.ob.clearResults    | Clear results of current block | | scimax.ob.clearAllResults | Clear all results in document  | | scimax.babel.clearResults | Clear all results in document  |

entries.heading: What Are Sessions?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] Sessions maintain a persistent interpreter process that preserves state between executions. This is similar to how Jupyter notebooks work - variables, functions, and imports persist.

entries.heading: Enabling Sessions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] Add :session header argument: #+BEGIN_SRC python :session x = 42 y = 10 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: #+BEGIN_SRC python :session result = x + y print(result) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 52

entries.heading: Named Sessions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] Use different session names to maintain separate contexts: #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *analysis* import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv('data.csv') #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *testing* import unittest # Separate session for tests #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *analysis* # Can still access df here print(df.head()) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Session Scope
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] - Sessions are per-language and per-name - Default session name (when you just use :session) is language-specific - Use :session none to explicitly disable session for a block - Sessions persist for the duration of the VS Code window

entries.heading: Jupyter Sessions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] When using Jupyter kernels (e.g., jupyter-python), sessions automatically use Jupyter kernel instances: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *notebook* import numpy as np data = np.random.randn(100) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *notebook* import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.hist(data, bins=20); #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768484909875-0.png]]

entries.heading: Benefits of Sessions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:03] - *Avoid re-computation* - Load data once, use in multiple blocks - *Interactive development* - Build up code incrementally - *Shared context* - Split long workflows into logical chunks - *Testing* - Set up fixtures in one block, test in others

entries.heading: Session Limitations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:33] - Sessions consume memory until VS Code closes - Long-running sessions can accumulate stale state - Restart VS Code to clear all sessions - Session state is not saved to disk

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:50] Moving between source blocks efficiently is essential for productive literate programming.

entries.heading: Block Navigation Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:32] | Keybinding | Action                 | Platform | |------------+------------------------+----------| | C-<down>   | Next source block      | All      | | C-<up>     | Previous source block  | All      | | S-<return> | Execute and next block | All      |

entries.heading: Navigation Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:32] | Command                 |         | Description                      | |-------------------------+---------+----------------------------------| | scimax.ob.nextBlock     | C-c C-n | Jump to next source block        | | scimax.ob.previousBlock | C-c C-p | Jump to previous source block    | | scimax.ob.jumpToBlock   |         | Quick pick menu of all blocks    | | scimax.ob.jumpToResults |         | Jump to results of current block |

entries.heading: Quick Block Selection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:51] Use scimax.ob.jumpToBlock to see a searchable list of all source blocks: - Shows language and block name - Displays first line as preview - Filter by language or content - Jump instantly to any block

entries.heading: Example Workflow
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:51] 1. Write code in first block 2. Press S-<return> to execute and move to next block 3. Write code that depends on previous block 4. Press S-<return> again 5. Continue building up your analysis sequentially

entries.heading: Block Manipulation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:51] Scimax VS Code provides powerful commands for creating, modifying, and reorganizing source blocks.

entries.heading: Insert Block Above
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:55] | Command                    | Key Binding | Description                   | |----------------------------+-------------+-------------------------------| | scimax.ob.insertBlockAbove | Esc-a       | Insert new block above cursor | Prompts for language, creates block, and places cursor inside.

entries.heading: Insert Block Below
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:55] | Command                        | Key Binding | Description                     | |--------------------------------+-------------+---------------------------------| | scimax.ob.insertBlockBelow     | Esc-b       | Insert new block below cursor   | | scimax.ob.insertBlockBelowSame |             | Insert block with same language | The "same language" variant copies the language from the current block.

entries.heading: Split at Cursor
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:55] | Command              | Key Binding | Description                   | |----------------------+-------------+-------------------------------| | scimax.ob.splitBlock | Esc--       | Split current block at cursor | Place your cursor in the middle of a source block and split it into two blocks: Before: #+BEGIN_SRC python x = 1 y = 2 z = x + y print(z) #+END_SRC After splitting at line 3: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+BEGIN_SRC python x = 1 y = 2 #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python z = x

entries.heading: Merge with Previous/Next
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:04] | Command                     | Description               | |-----------------------------+---------------------------| | scimax.ob.mergeWithPrevious | Merge with previous block | | scimax.ob.mergeWithNext     | Merge with next block     | Combines code from two adjacent blocks into one. If languages differ, prompts for confirmation.

entries.heading: Clone Block
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:04] | Command              | Description                   | |----------------------+-------------------------------| | scimax.ob.cloneBlock | Duplicate current block below | Creates an exact copy of the current block including its header arguments.

entries.heading: Copy Block and Results
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:04] | Command             | Description                         | |---------------------+-------------------------------------| | scimax.ob.copyBlock | Copy block and results to clipboard | Copies the entire block including #+NAME: line (if present) and results section.

entries.heading: Kill Block
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:04] | Command             | Description                        | |---------------------+------------------------------------| | scimax.ob.killBlock | Delete block and copy to clipboard | Removes the block and its results, copying everything to clipboard for pasting elsewhere.

entries.heading: Move Up/Down
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:04] | Command                 | Description              | |-------------------------+--------------------------| | scimax.ob.moveBlockUp   | Swap with previous block | | scimax.ob.moveBlockDown | Swap with next block     | Swaps the current block (including results) with the adjacent block, maintaining all content.

entries.heading: Notebook-Style Development
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:05] 1. Insert block with scimax.ob.insertBlockBelow 2. Write code 3. Execute with S-<return> (executes and moves to next) 4. Repeat

entries.heading: Refactoring Code
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:05] 1. Split large block into logical pieces with scimax.ob.splitBlock 2. Add session to maintain state: :session 3. Execute sequentially to verify 4. Reorganize with move commands if needed

entries.heading: Experimenting with Variants
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:05] 1. Clone block with scimax.ob.cloneBlock 2. Modify clone to test alternative approach 3. Compare results 4. Kill the version you don't want

entries.heading: Inline Source Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:05] Sometimes you need to execute code inline within a paragraph rather than in a standalone block.

entries.heading: Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:05] #+BEGIN_SRC org src_LANGUAGE{CODE} src_LANGUAGE[HEADERS]{CODE} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Simple Inline Computation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 14:35] The answer is src_python{return 2 + 2} {{{results(=4=)}}} which equals 4. Result after execution: #+BEGIN_SRC org The answer is 4 which equals 4. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: With Headers
entries.content: Today is src_python[:results value]{import datetime; datetime.date.today()} {{{results(=datetime.date(2026, 1, 18)=)}}}.

entries.heading: Accessing Variables
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 14:34] Inline blocks can access session variables: You have to run this first to create a session: #+BEGIN_SRC python :session *calc* total = 100 tax_rate = 0.08 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: The total with tax is src_python[:session *calc*]{return total * (1 + tax_rate)} {{{results(=108.0=)}}}.

entries.heading: Use Cases
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] - Embedding calculations in text - Showing dates/times - Inserting computed values into sentences - Quick one-liners that don't need a full block

entries.heading: Limitations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] - No syntax highlighting - Results replace the inline block (can't keep both) - Less suitable for multi-line code - Harder to debug than regular blocks

entries.heading: Code Tangling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] Tangling is the process of extracting source code from your org document into separate source files. This enables the literate programming workflow where documentation is primary but you can still generate working software.

entries.heading: What Is Tangling?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] Tangling extracts code from source blocks marked with :tangle into external files: - Write narrative documentation with embedded code blocks - Extract all code to build/run your project - Keep docs and code in perfect sync

entries.heading: Enabling Tangling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:57] Add :tangle filename.ext to source blocks: #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle myapp.py #!/usr/bin/env python3 def main(): print("Hello from tangled code!") if __name__ == "__main__": main() #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Execute Tangle
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 08:58] | Keybinding      | Command             | Description               | |-----------------+---------------------+---------------------------| | C-c C-v t | scimax.babel.tangle | Extract all tangle blocks | This command: 1. Finds all blocks with :tangle headers 2. Groups them by target filename 3. Writes each file with concatenated code

entries.heading: Don't Tangle (Default)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] #+BEGIN_SRC python # Not tangled by default #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Tangle to Specific File
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle tangled/utils.py def utility_function(): return "useful" #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle tangled/utils.py def another_utility(): return "also useful" #+END_SRC Both blocks tangle to src/utils.py in order.

entries.heading: Tangle with Yes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:06] #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle yes # Tangles to default file (based on org filename) #+END_SRC If your org file is project.org, this tangles to project.py.

entries.heading: No-Web Style References
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:07] Use :noweb to reference other named blocks: #+NAME: imports #+BEGIN_SRC python import sys import os #+END_SRC #+NAME: helpers #+BEGIN_SRC python def helper(): return "help" #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle tangled/app.py :noweb yes <<imports>> <<helpers>> def main(): print(helper()) #+END_SRC When tangled, <<imports>> and <<helpers>> are replaced with the code from those named blocks.

entries.heading: Shebang Lines
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:07] Add :shebang for executable scripts: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :tangle tangled/script.sh :shebang "#!/bin/bash" echo "This will be executable" #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Comments in Tangled Code
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:08] By default, tangled code includes no comments about its origin. Some implementations add comments like: #+BEGIN_SRC python # [[file:literate.org::*Section Name][Section Name:1]] # code here # Section Name:1 ends here #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Library Development
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:08] Write a tutorial document that tangles to a working library: - README.org - Document with examples - Tangle to src/lib.py, tests/test_lib.py - Readers learn from docs, users import the library

entries.heading: Configuration Management
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:08] Document your configuration in config.org: #+BEGIN_SRC org

entries.heading: Database Configuration
entries.content: We use PostgreSQL with connection pooling. #+BEGIN_SRC toml :tangle tangled/config.toml [database] host = "localhost" port = 5432 pool_size = 10 #+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Build Scripts
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:08] #+BEGIN_SRC org

entries.heading: Build Process
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC makefile :tangle tangled/Makefile all: build test build: python setup.py build test: pytest tests/ #+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Tangling vs Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:09] | Feature  | Tangling              | Export                      | |----------+-----------------------+-----------------------------| | Purpose  | Extract code to files | Create documentation        | | Output   | Source code files     | HTML, PDF, LaTeX, etc.      | | Controls | :tangle               | :exports                    | | Respects | Code blocks only      | All org content             | | Use case | Build/run software    | Share/publish documentation |

entries.heading: Named Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:09] Give blocks names using #+NAME: so they can be referenced: #+NAME: square #+BEGIN_SRC python :var x=0 print(x * x) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Calling Named Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:28] Use #+CALL: to invoke a named block with arguments: #+CALL: square(x=5) #+RESULTS: square : 25 #+CALL: square(x=10) #+RESULTS: : 100 #+NAME: square-return #+BEGIN_SRC python :var x=0 :results value return x * x #+END_SRC #+CALL: square-return(x=11)

entries.heading: Inline Call Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 14:24] You can also call blocks inline: The square of 7 is call_square(x=7) {{{results(=49=)}}}. ## Using Named Blocks as Data Reference named blocks as variables: #+NAME: raw-data | Name  | Value | |-------+-------| | Alpha | 100   | | Beta  | 200   | | Gamma | 150   | #+BEGIN_SRC python :var data=raw-data :results output total = sum(row[1] for row in data[1:])  # Skip header print(f"Total: {total}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Total: 450

entries.heading: Call with Headers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 14:16] Override headers when calling: #+CALL: square(x=11) #+RESULTS: square : 121 # No output. You might do this for side effects. #+CALL: square(x=5)[:results silent] #+CALL: square(x=1)[:results table] #+RESULTS: square | 1 |

entries.heading: Library of Functions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 14:39] Build a library of reusable code blocks: #+NAME: mean #+BEGIN_SRC python :var numbers=[] import numpy as np return np.mean(numbers) #+END_SRC #+NAME: median #+BEGIN_SRC python :var numbers=[] import numpy as np return np.median(numbers) #+END_SRC #+NAME: dataset | 10 | | 20 | | 30 | | 40 | | 50 | #+CALL: mean(numbers=dataset) #+RESULTS: mean : np.float64(30.0) #+CALL: median(numbers=dataset) #+RESULTS: median : np.float64(30.0)

entries.heading: Best Practices
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] - Use descriptive names: load-data, calculate-statistics, generate-plot - Document block parameters in preceding text - Keep blocks focused and reusable - Use #+CALL: for parameterized re-execution - Consider blocks as functions in your literate program

entries.heading: Essential Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] | Keybinding | Action                   | |------------+--------------------------| | C-<return> | Execute current block    | | S-<return> | Execute and move to next | | C-<up>     | Previous block           | | C-<down>   | Next block               | | C-c C-v t  | Tangle all blocks        |

entries.heading: Common Header Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] | Argument | Values                       | Purpose           | |----------+------------------------------+-------------------| | :results | output, value, table, silent | Output format     | | :exports | code, results, both, none    | What to export    | | :session | name or none                 | Persistent state  | | :var     | name=value                   | Input variables   | | :tangle  | filename or no               | Extract to file   | | :dir     | path

entries.heading: Supported Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] Direct: python, javascript, typescript, shell, bash, sql Jupyter: jupyter-python, jupyter-r, jupyter-julia, jupyter-ruby, and many more

entries.heading: Basic Block
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] #+BEGIN_SRC python # Your code here #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Session Block
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] #+BEGIN_SRC python :session # Code with persistent state #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Data Processing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:11] #+NAME: input-data | A | B | |---+---| | 1 | 2 | #+BEGIN_SRC python :var data=input-data :results table # Process data return processed #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Tangled Library
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] #+BEGIN_SRC python :tangle tangled/mylib.py def my_function(): """Documented function""" pass #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Organization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Use headings to group related blocks - Name important blocks with #+NAME: - Add #+CAPTION: to blocks that produce key results - Use sessions to connect related blocks

entries.heading: Performance
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Use :cache yes for expensive computations - Close unnecessary sessions to free memory - Use :results silent when you don't need output - Limit output size for large datasets

entries.heading: Reproducibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Specify exact versions in documentation - Use :dir to set working directory explicitly - Document all dependencies in requirements/environment - Include data loading steps in the document

entries.heading: Debugging
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Execute blocks one at a time with C-<return> - Check session state in separate test blocks - Use :results output to see print statements - Clear results and re-execute from top to verify

entries.heading: Collaboration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Export to HTML/PDF for non-technical readers (:exports results) - Tangle to source files for developers (:tangle yes) - Use meaningful block names for #+CALL: references - Document assumptions and requirements in text

entries.heading: Common Pitfalls
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Forgetting to enable sessions when blocks depend on each other - Using :results value when you want printed output - Not clearing stale results before sharing - Referencing blocks that haven't executed yet - Mixing session names unintentionally

entries.heading: Emacs Org-Mode Documentation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] While Scimax VS Code implements its own version, the Emacs org-mode documentation is valuable for understanding concepts: - [[https://orgmode.org/manual/Working-with-Source-Code.html][Working with Source Code]] - [[https://orgmode.org/worg/org-contrib/babel/][Babel Introduction]] - [[https://orgmode.org/worg/org-contrib/babel/languages/index.html][Babel Language Reference]]

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] - Jupyter integration for rich interactive notebooks - Export system for generating documents - Database integration for storing and searching code blocks - Project notebooks for organizing research

entries.heading: Conclusion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:12] Source code blocks transform org documents into powerful literate programming environments. You can: - Write executable documentation - Build reproducible analyses - Create interactive notebooks - Develop software with embedded docs - Share knowledge with working examples Master the keybindings (C-<return>, S-<return>, C-<up>/Down), experiment with header arguments, and leverage sessions for interactive development. Happy literate programming!

entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:56] - Previous: [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:08-supported-languages.org][Supported Languages]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: Scimax VS Code supports code execution in source blocks through two mechanisms: 1. *Native Execution* - Direct language interpreters (Python, JavaScript, Shell) 2. *Jupyter Kernels* - Any language with a Jupyter kernel installed This document covers the primary supported languages. For Jupyter, any language with a kernel can theoretically be used, but these are the ones with tested support.

entries.heading: Native Execution
entries.content: Native executors run code directly using command-line interpreters: - Fast and lightweight - No additional setup beyond language installation - Limited session support (state doesn't persist between blocks) Supported natively: *Python, JavaScript/Node.js, Shell/Bash*

entries.heading: Jupyter Execution
entries.content: Jupyter executors use Jupyter kernels for code execution: - Full session support (variables persist between blocks) - Rich output (images, plots, formatted data) - Interactive features To use Jupyter for any language: 1. *Explicit syntax*: Use =jupyter-<language>= (e.g., =jupyter-python=) 2. Jupyter must be installed with the appropriate kernel

entries.heading: Choosing an Executor
entries.content: # Native Python (direct python3 command) #+BEGIN_SRC python print("Hello from native Python") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello from native Python # Jupyter Python (uses IPython kernel) #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python print("Hello from Jupyter Python") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello from Jupyter Python

entries.heading: Python
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ID: lang-python :END:

entries.heading: Language Identifiers
entries.content: - =python=, =python3=, =py=, =ipython=

entries.heading: Execution Modes
entries.content: - *Native*: Direct execution via =python3= command - *Jupyter*: Use =jupyter-python= or =jupyter-ipython=

entries.heading: Session Support
entries.content: - Native: No (each block runs in isolation) - Jupyter: Yes (full state persistence)

entries.heading: Dependencies
entries.content: - *Native*: Python 3.x installed and in PATH - *Jupyter*: Jupyter and IPython kernel installed

entries.heading: Basic Example (Native)
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC python # Native Python execution import math radius = 5 area = math.pi * radius ** 2 print(f"Circle area: {area:.2f}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Circle area: 78.54

entries.heading: Session Example (Jupyter)
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *py-session* # First block - define variables data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] print(f"Data initialized: {data}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Data initialized: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *py-session* # Second block - uses variables from first block import statistics mean = statistics.mean(data) print(f"Mean: {mean}") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Mean: 3.0

entries.heading: Plotting Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 100) y = np.sin(x) plt.plot(x, y) plt.title('Sine Wave') plt.xlabel('x') plt.ylabel('sin(x)') plt.grid(True) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768510006544-2.png]]

entries.heading: Installing IPython Kernel
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC bash pip install ipykernel python -m ipykernel install --user --name=python3 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Bash/Shell
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ID: lang-bash :END:

entries.heading: Language Identifiers
entries.content: - =sh=, =bash=, =shell=

entries.heading: Execution Modes
entries.content: - *Native*: Direct shell execution (default on Unix) - *Jupyter*: Use =jupyter-bash= (requires Bash kernel)

entries.heading: Session Support
entries.content: - Native: No - Jupyter: Yes

entries.heading: Dependencies
entries.content: - *Native*: Bash shell (standard on Unix/Linux/macOS) - *Jupyter*: Bash kernel (optional)

entries.heading: Basic Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC bash # List files in current directory ls -la | head -n 5 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : total 1728 : drwxr-xr-x@ 42 jkitchin  staff   1344 Jan 16 20:01 . : drwxr-xr-x@ 53 jkitchin  staff   1696 Jan 16 19:58 .. : drwxr-xr-x@  9 jkitchin  staff    288 Jan 15 15:46 .ob-jupyter : -rw-r--r--@  1 jkitchin  staff  28933 Jan 16 20:04 00-index.org

entries.heading: Command Pipeline
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC bash # Find large files find . -type f -size +1k 2>/dev/null | \ xargs ls -lh 2>/dev/null | \ awk '{print $5, $9}' | \ sort -hr | \ head -5 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Working Directory
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC bash :dir /tmp # Working directory can be set with :dir pwd #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : /private/tmp

entries.heading: Julia
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ID: lang-julia :END:

entries.heading: Language Identifiers
entries.content: - =julia=, =jl=

entries.heading: Execution Modes
entries.content: - *Jupyter*: Use =jupyter-julia= (requires IJulia)

entries.heading: Session Support
entries.content: - Yes (full state persistence)

entries.heading: Dependencies
entries.content: - Julia installed - IJulia: Install from Julia REPL with =using Pkg; Pkg.add("IJulia")=

entries.heading: Basic Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-julia # Julia execution function fibonacci(n) if n <= 2 return 1 else return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2) end end println("First 10 Fibonacci numbers:") for i in 1:10 println("F($i) = $(fibonacci(i))") end #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Array Operations
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-julia # Efficient array operations A = [1 2 3; 4 5 6; 7 8 9] println("Matrix A:") println(A) # Element-wise operations B = A .^ 2 println("\nA squared:") println(B) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Installing IJulia Kernel
entries.content: From Julia REPL: #+BEGIN_SRC julia using Pkg Pkg.add("IJulia") #+END_SRC

entries.heading: R
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ID: lang-r :END:

entries.heading: Execution Modes
entries.content: - *Jupyter*: Use =jupyter-r= (requires IRkernel)

entries.heading: Session Support
entries.content: - Yes (full state persistence)

entries.heading: Dependencies
entries.content: - R installed - IRkernel: Install from R with =install.packages('IRkernel'); IRkernel::installspec()=

entries.heading: Basic Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-r # R execution x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) y <- x^2 print(y) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Data Frame Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-r # Working with data frames df <- data.frame( name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"), age = c(25, 30, 35), score = c(85, 92, 78) ) print(df) summary(df) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Plotting Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-r :results file :file rplot.png # Create a plot x <- seq(0, 2*pi, length.out=100) y <- sin(x) png("rplot.png") plot(x, y, type="l", col="blue", main="Sine Wave", xlab="x", ylab="sin(x)") grid() dev.off() #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Installing IRkernel
entries.content: From R: #+BEGIN_SRC r install.packages('IRkernel') IRkernel::installspec() #+END_SRC

entries.heading: JavaScript/Node.js
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ID: lang-javascript :END:

entries.heading: Language Identifiers
entries.content: - =javascript=, =js=, =node=, =nodejs=

entries.heading: Execution Modes
entries.content: - *Native*: Direct execution via =node= command - *Jupyter*: Use =jupyter-javascript= (requires IJavascript kernel)

entries.heading: Session Support
entries.content: - Native: No - Jupyter: Yes (with IJavascript kernel)

entries.heading: Dependencies
entries.content: - *Native*: Node.js installed and in PATH - *Jupyter*: IJavascript kernel (=npm install -g ijavascript=)

entries.heading: Basic Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC javascript // JavaScript execution const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]; const sum = numbers.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0); console.log(`Sum: ${sum}`); #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Sum: 21

entries.heading: Working with JSON
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC javascript const data = { name: "Scimax", version: "1.0", features: ["org-mode", "jupyter", "references"] }; console.log(JSON.stringify(data, null, 2)); #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : { :   "name": "Scimax", :   "version": "1.0", :   "features": [ :     "org-mode", :     "jupyter", :     "references" :   ] : }

entries.heading: Other Languages via Jupyter
entries.content: Scimax VS Code can execute any language that has a Jupyter kernel installed. The general pattern is: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-<language> code here ,#+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Popular Jupyter Kernels
entries.content: | Language   | Kernel         | Install Command                                    | |------------+----------------+----------------------------------------------------| | TypeScript | TSLab          | =npm install -g tslab && tslab install=            | | Ruby       | IRuby          | =gem install iruby && iruby register=              | | Rust       | evcxr          | =cargo install evcxr_jupyter && evcxr_jupyter --install= | | Go         | gophernotes    | =go install github.com/gopherdata/gop

entries.heading: Checking Available Kernels
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC bash jupyter kernelspec list #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Common Header Arguments
entries.content: | Argument   | Values              | Description                          | |------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------| | :session   | name or none        | Session name for persistent state    | | :results   | output/value/silent | How to handle results                | | :exports   | code/results/both   | What to export                       | | :file      | filename            | Save output to file                  | | :dir       | path                | Working

entries.heading: Session Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org # Define variable in first block ,#+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *analysis* data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] ,#+END_SRC # Use variable in second block ,#+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session *analysis* import statistics print(f"Mean: {statistics.mean(data)}") ,#+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: File Output Example
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :results file :file output.png import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot([1,2,3], [1,4,9]) plt.savefig('output.png') ,#+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: "No executor available for language: X"
entries.content: *Cause:* The language interpreter or Jupyter kernel is not installed. *Solution:* 1. For native languages: Install the language (python3, node, etc.) 2. For Jupyter languages: Install the appropriate kernel 3. Verify: =jupyter kernelspec list=

entries.heading: "Jupyter kernel not found"
entries.content: *Cause:* Jupyter is not installed or kernel is not registered. *Solution:* #+BEGIN_SRC bash # Install Jupyter pip install jupyter # Install specific kernel (example for Python) python -m ipykernel install --user # Verify kernels jupyter kernelspec list #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Session state not persisting
entries.content: *Cause:* Using native executor instead of Jupyter, or session name not specified. *Solution:* - Use =jupyter-<language>= syntax - Add =:session <name>= header argument - Ensure all blocks use the same session name

entries.heading: Code executes but no output appears
entries.content: *Cause:* Results handling or silent mode. *Solution:* - Check =:results= header (use =:results output=) - Ensure =:eval= is not set to =no= - Add explicit print statements

entries.heading: Getting Help
entries.content: - View Babel output: =Scimax: Show Babel Output= - Check executor status: =Scimax: Check Available Executors= - View Jupyter kernel list: =jupyter kernelspec list= in terminal

entries.heading: Language Selection
entries.content: - Use native executors for simple, stateless scripts - Use Jupyter for interactive work requiring sessions - Use explicit =jupyter-<language>= when you need Jupyter features

entries.heading: Session Management
entries.content: - Name sessions descriptively (=:session *data-analysis*=) - Use separate sessions for independent workflows - Clear sessions when starting fresh work

entries.heading: Code Organization
entries.content: - One concept per block for clarity - Use named blocks (=#+NAME:=) for reusable code - Document complex blocks with comments

entries.heading: Performance
entries.content: - Cache expensive computations (=:cache yes=) - Use appropriate result types (=:results output= vs =value=) - Close unused Jupyter sessions

entries.heading: Execute Commands
entries.content: - =C-<return>= / =s-<return>=: Execute current block - =S-<return>=: Execute and move to next - =C-c C-c=: Execute (Emacs style)

entries.heading: Session Control
entries.content: - =:session <name>=: Use named session - =:session none=: Disable session - Sessions persist until VS Code restart or manual close

entries.heading: Result Handling
entries.content: - =:results output=: Capture stdout - =:results value=: Return last value - =:results silent=: No results - =:results file=: Save to file

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:09-jupyter.org][Jupyter]]

entries.heading: Jupyter Integration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:44] Scimax VS Code provides comprehensive integration with Jupyter kernels, allowing you to execute source code blocks using Jupyter's powerful kernel infrastructure. This enables interactive computing with support for multiple programming languages, rich output (plots, images, HTML), and persistent sessions with state management. This guide covers everything you need to know about using Jupyter kernels in Scimax VS Code org-mode documents.

entries.heading: What is Jupyter?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] Jupyter is an open-source project that provides interactive computing environments across dozens of programming languages. At its core, Jupyter uses "kernels" - language-specific execution engines that run code and return results.

entries.heading: What Jupyter Integration Provides
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] The Jupyter integration in Scimax VS Code brings the following capabilities: - *Multi-language support* - Execute Python, Julia, R, and 20+ other languages - *Interactive sessions* - Maintain kernel state across multiple code blocks - *Rich output* - Display plots, images, HTML, LaTeX, and other media types - *Automatic image saving* - Graphics automatically saved to .ob-jupyter/ directory - *ZeroMQ protocol* - Native communication with Jupyter kernels via ZeroMQ -

entries.heading: Jupyter vs Native Executors
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] Scimax provides two ways to execute code blocks: 1. *Native executors* - Direct execution via system commands (python, node, etc.) 2. *Jupyter executors* - Execution via Jupyter kernels (jupyter-python, etc.)

entries.heading: When to Use Jupyter
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] Use Jupyter kernels when you need: - Persistent sessions with shared state across blocks - Rich output like plots, images, or interactive visualizations - Kernel-specific features (IPython magics, R plots, Julia macros) - Code completion and introspection - Multiple parallel sessions

entries.heading: When to Use Native Executors
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] Use native executors when you need: - Quick one-off script execution - Minimal dependencies - Shell integration (pipes, redirects) - System-level operations

entries.heading: Prerequisites
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] Before using Jupyter kernels, you need: 1. *Jupyter* installed on your system 2. *ZeroMQ native module* (automatically included with Scimax) 3. *Kernel specifications* for your languages of interest

entries.heading: Python Users
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] If you have Python installed, install Jupyter using pip: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never # Install Jupyter and IPython kernel pip install jupyter ipykernel # Or using conda conda install jupyter #+END_SRC

entries.heading: System Package Managers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] On Linux systems, Jupyter may be available via package managers: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never # Ubuntu/Debian sudo apt install jupyter jupyter-core python3-ipykernel # Fedora sudo dnf install jupyter-core python3-ipykernel # Arch Linux sudo pacman -S jupyter jupyter-core python-ipykernel #+END_SRC

entries.heading: macOS with Homebrew
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never brew install jupyter #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Python (IPython Kernel)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:45] The IPython kernel is installed automatically with Jupyter: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never pip install ipykernel #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Julia
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:00] Install the IJulia kernel from Julia: #+BEGIN_SRC julia :eval never using Pkg Pkg.add("IJulia") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS:

entries.heading: R
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:00] Install the IRkernel from R: #+BEGIN_SRC r :eval never install.packages('IRkernel') IRkernel::installspec() #+END_SRC #+RESULTS:

entries.heading: Other Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:16] Jupyter supports many languages through community kernels: | Language   | Kernel Name | Installation                                           | |------------+-------------+--------------------------------------------------------| | JavaScript | ijavascript | npm install -g ijavascript && ijsinstall               | | TypeScript | tslab       | npm install -g tslab && tslab install                  | | Ruby       | iruby       | gem install iruby && iruby register

entries.heading: Verifying Installation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:00] Check which kernels are installed: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never jupyter kernelspec list #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Available kernels: :   ir            /Users/jkitchin/Library/Jupyter/kernels/ir :   julia-1.12    /Users/jkitchin/Library/Jupyter/kernels/julia-1.12 :   python3       /Users/jkitchin/Dropbox/uv/.venv/share/jupyter/kernels/python3 This will display all available kernels with their installation paths.

entries.heading: Troubleshooting ZeroMQ
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:46] If you encounter ZeroMQ-related errors, the native module may need rebuilding for VS Code's Electron version. Scimax will display instructions if this is required. The error message will look like: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE Failed to load ZeroMQ native module. This usually means the module was compiled for a different Node.js version. #+END_EXAMPLE Follow the on-screen instructions or consult the extension documentation.

entries.heading: Explicit Jupyter Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:47] To explicitly use a Jupyter kernel, prefix the language name with jupyter-: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python import numpy as np print(np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]).mean()) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 3.0 The jupyter- prefix forces Babel to use the Jupyter executor for that language.

entries.heading: Supported Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:47] The Jupyter executor recognizes these language prefixes: | Org Language       | Kernel Language | Common Kernel Names | |--------------------+-----------------+---------------------| | jupyter-python     | python          | python3, python     | | jupyter-julia      | julia           | julia-1.9, julia    | | jupyter-r          | r               | ir                  | | jupyter-ruby       | ruby            | ruby                | | jupyter-rust       | rust

entries.heading: Named Sessions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:47] Use the :session header argument to maintain persistent kernel state: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session my-analysis import pandas as pd data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [4, 5, 6]}) print("Data loaded") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Data loaded #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session my-analysis # The 'data' variable is still available from the previous block print(data.describe()) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : x    y : count  3.0  3.0 : mean   2.0  5.0 : std    1.0  1.0 :

entries.heading: Default Session
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:47] If no session name is specified, blocks use a language-specific default session: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session # Uses the default "python-default" session x = 42 #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session # Same session, x is still available print(x) #+END_SRC #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Multiple Sessions
entries.content:
CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:24] You can run multiple independent sessions simultaneously: # Session 1: Training model #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session training import time print("Training model...") time.sleep(5)  # Simulate training model = "trained_model" with open('data.csv', 'w') as f: f.write("id,value
1,10
2,20
3,30
") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Training model... # Session 2: Preprocessing data (runs in parallel) #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session preprocessing import pandas as pd data

entries.heading: Image Output
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:25] Jupyter kernels can produce rich output including images. When a code block generates an image (matplotlib plot, Julia plot, etc.), it is automatically saved to the .ob-jupyter/ directory in your document's folder.

entries.heading: Python Matplotlib Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:26] #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session :results file import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np x = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, 100) plt.plot(x, np.sin(x), label='sin(x)') plt.plot(x, np.cos(x), label='cos(x)') plt.xlabel('x') plt.ylabel('y') plt.title('Trigonometric Functions') plt.legend() plt.grid(True) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768663562237-0.png]] The image is automatically linked in the results, and you'll see it rendered in VS Code's

entries.heading: Julia Plots Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:16] #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-julia import Pkg; Pkg.add("Plots") using Plots x = 0:0.1:2 plot(x, [sin.(x) cos.(x)], label=["sin" "cos"], xlabel="x", ylabel="y", title="Trigonometric Functions") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768665825557-0.png]]

entries.heading: R Graphics Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:12] #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-r :session :results file x <- seq(0, 2*pi, length.out=100) plot(x, sin(x), type='l', col='blue', ylab='y', main='Sine Wave') lines(x, cos(x), col='red') legend('topright', c('sin(x)', 'cos(x)'), col=c('blue', 'red'), lty=1) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:.ob-jupyter/output-1768666364826-0.png]]

entries.heading: Supported Output Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:16] The Jupyter integration automatically handles these MIME types: - image/png - PNG images (most common for plots) - image/svg+xml - SVG vector graphics - image/jpeg - JPEG images - application/pdf - PDF documents - text/html - HTML content (saved as .html for complex output) - text/plain - Plain text output - text/latex - LaTeX equations

entries.heading: The .ob-jupyter Directory
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:50] All Jupyter output files are saved to .ob-jupyter/ in your document's directory: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE my-analysis.org .ob-jupyter/  output-1705171200000-0.png  output-1705171200001-0.svg  output-1705171200002-0.html #+END_EXAMPLE Files are named output-<timestamp>-<counter>.<ext> to ensure uniqueness. *Note:* Add .ob-jupyter/ to your .gitignore if you don't want to commit generated outputs to version control.

entries.heading: Header Arguments
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:51] Jupyter blocks support all standard Babel header arguments plus Jupyter-specific options.

entries.heading: :session
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:51] Controls which kernel session to use: #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session mysession # Code runs in the "mysession" kernel #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session # Code runs in default session #+END_SRC #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python # Code runs in a new temporary kernel (no session persistence) #+END_SRC

entries.heading: :results
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:51] Controls how results are collected and displayed: # Collect printed output #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :results output print("Hello") print("World") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Hello : World # Collect the last expression value #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :results value 2 + 2 #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 4 # Save image results as file links #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :results file import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9]) plt.show() #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[fi

entries.heading: :exports
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:33] Controls what gets exported to HTML/PDF/LaTeX: # Export both code and results #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :exports both print("This will show code AND output in exports") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : This will show code AND output in exports # Export only results #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :exports results print("This will show ONLY output in exports") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : This will show ONLY output in exports # Export only code #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :exports code

entries.heading: :dir
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:23] Set the working directory for code execution: #+BEGIN_SRC python :dir ../.github :results output import os print(os.getcwd())  # Prints: the working directory #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : /Users/jkitchin/Dropbox/projects/scimax_vscode/.github Or by absolute path: #+BEGIN_SRC bash :dir /Users/jkitchin/Dropbox/projects/scimax_vscode/.github ls #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : workflows

entries.heading: :var
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:37] Pass variables between blocks: #+name: people-data #+BEGIN_SRC shell :results output echo "Alice 30" echo "Bob 25" echo "Carol 35" #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: people-data : Alice 30 : Bob 25 : Carol 35 #+BEGIN_SRC python :var data=people-data :results value # The shell output is passed as a string lines = data.strip().split('\n') [line.split() for line in lines] #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : [['Alice', '30'], ['Bob', '25'], ['Carol', '35']]

entries.heading: :file
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:37] Explicitly specify output file path (overrides auto-naming): #+BEGIN_SRC python :file _static/my-plot.png import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np x = np.linspace(0, 20 * np.pi, 500) y1 = np.cos(x) * np.exp(-.2 * x) y2 = np.sin(x) * np.exp(-.2 * x) plt.plot(y1, y2) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: [[file:_static/my-plot.png]]

entries.heading: :cache
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:47] Cache results to avoid re-execution: #+BEGIN_SRC python :cache yes import time def compute_expensive_value(): time.sleep(10)  # Slow operation return 42 result = compute_expensive_value() print(result) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS[ea3f22131a9f09c9b08111cf9cab1cf3fbf5ea3e]: : 43 Results are cached based on code content. Changes to code invalidate the cache.

entries.heading: :async
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:38] Run block asynchronously (non-blocking): #+BEGIN_SRC python :async yes import time print("Starting...") time.sleep(30) print("Done!") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Starting... : Done! *Note:* Async support depends on the execution backend implementation. @@>Code blocks generally run in async mode in VS Code.<@@

entries.heading: :prologue / :epilogue
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:38] Add code before/after the block: #+BEGIN_SRC python :prologue "import numpy as np" :epilogue "print('Done')" :results output # numpy is already imported due to prologue x = np.array([1, 2, 3]) print(x.mean()) # "Done" will be printed due to epilogue #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 2.0 : Done

entries.heading: Automatic Start
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:07] Kernels start automatically when you execute a Jupyter block. The first execution creates the kernel; subsequent blocks reuse it.

entries.heading: Manual Start
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:41] You can manually start a kernel before executing code: *Command:* Jupyter: Start Kernel. [[cmd:scimax.jupyter.startKernel]] This command: 1. Detects the language of the current block (or file) 2. Finds an appropriate kernel 3. Starts the kernel in a default session

entries.heading: Selecting a Specific Kernel
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:41] *Command:* Jupyter: Show Available Kernels [[cmd:scimax.jupyter.showKernels]] This command: 1. Lists all installed Jupyter kernels 2. Allows you to select and start one 3. Shows kernel display name, language, and installation path

entries.heading: Viewing Running Kernels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:41] *Command:* Jupyter: Show Running Kernels. [[cmd:scimax.jupyter.showRunning]] This displays all active kernels with: - Session name - Language - Current state (idle, busy, starting) - Kernel ID From this menu you can: - Restart a kernel - Interrupt a kernel - Shutdown a kernel - View kernel information

entries.heading: Kernel States
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:40] Kernels can be in one of several states: | State    | Description                   | Status Bar Icon | |----------+-------------------------------+-----------------| | starting | Kernel is launching           | $(loading~spin) | | idle     | Kernel is ready and waiting   | $(check)        | | busy     | Kernel is executing code      | $(sync~spin)    | | dead     | Kernel has stopped or crashed | $(error)        | The kernel state is shown in the VS Code status ba

entries.heading: Restarting Kernels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:54] *Command:* Jupyter: Restart Kernel Restarting a kernel: - Terminates the current kernel process - Starts a fresh kernel with the same spec - Clears all session state (variables, imports, etc.) - Maintains the same session name Use restart when: - The kernel becomes unresponsive - You want to clear all state - You need to reload modified modules - Memory usage grows too large

entries.heading: Interrupting Kernels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:38] *Command:* Jupyter: Interrupt Kernel Interrupting sends a SIGINT (Ctrl+C) to the kernel: - Stops currently executing code - Preserves session state - Allows you to regain control of a long-running computation Use interrupt when: - Code is taking longer than expected - You notice an error in the running code - You want to stop an infinite loop

entries.heading: Stopping Kernels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:38] *Command:* Jupyter: Shutdown Kernel Stopping a kernel: - Gracefully terminates the kernel process - Frees system resources - Removes the session (state is lost) *Command:* Jupyter: Shutdown All Kernels Shuts down all running kernels simultaneously.

entries.heading: Changing Kernels
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:39] *Command:* Jupyter: Change Kernel This allows you to: 1. Select a new kernel spec 2. Choose which session to replace 3. Shutdown the old kernel 4. Start the new kernel in the same session Use this to switch languages or kernel versions without changing session names.

entries.heading: Mixing Languages
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:39] You can use multiple Jupyter kernels in a single document: # Generate data in Python #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session py-session :results output import json data = {'values': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]} with open('/tmp/data.json', 'w') as f: json.dump(data, f) print("Data saved to /tmp/data.json") #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Data saved to /tmp/data.json # Process data in Julia #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-julia :session jl-session import Pkg; Pkg.add("JSON") using JSON data = JSON.parse

entries.heading: IPython Magics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:39] When using Python kernels, you have access to IPython magic commands: # Line magics (single line) #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python %timeit sum(range(1000)) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 5.23 s  31.3 ns per loop (mean  std. dev. of 7 runs, 100,000 loops each) # Cell magics (entire block) #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python %%timeit total = 0 for i in range(1000): total += i #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : 11.9 s  85.7 ns per loop (mean  std. dev. of 7 runs, 100,000 loops each) # Load extern

entries.heading: Kernel Introspection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:39] Jupyter kernels support code introspection (when exposed via VS Code APIs): - *Code completion* - Auto-complete variable names, functions, methods - *Documentation* - Hover to see docstrings and signatures - *Inspection* - View source code and help text The level of support depends on the specific kernel implementation.

entries.heading: Custom Kernel Discovery
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:10] Jupyter looks for kernels in standard locations: *Linux/macOS:* - ~/.local/share/jupyter/kernels/ - /usr/local/share/jupyter/kernels/ - /usr/share/jupyter/kernels/ *Windows:* - %APPDATA%\jupyter\kernels - %PROGRAMDATA%\jupyter\kernels *Environment Variables:* - JUPYTER_DATA_DIR - Override default data directory - JUPYTER_PATH - Additional search paths (colon-separated) To make a custom kernel available, place its kernel.json in one of these directories.

entries.heading: Kernel Startup Time
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] First execution in a new session incurs kernel startup overhead: - Python: ~1-3 seconds - Julia: ~5-15 seconds (due to compilation) - R: ~1-2 seconds Keep sessions running to avoid repeated startup costs.

entries.heading: Memory Usage
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] Each kernel is a separate process with its own memory: - Monitor memory usage with system tools - Restart kernels to free memory - Use del (Python), clear (Julia), rm() (R) to free objects

entries.heading: Image Output
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] Large images increase document size: - Matplotlib: Use plt.savefig(dpi`..., bbox_inches''tight') to control size - Consider using SVG for vector graphics (smaller, scalable) - Use :results silent for intermediate plots

entries.heading: Kernel Not Found
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Error message "No Jupyter kernel found for language: <language>" *Solutions:* 1. Verify the kernel is installed: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never jupyter kernelspec list #+END_SRC 2. Install the kernel if missing (see Installation section) 3. Check that jupyter is in your PATH: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never which jupyter #+END_SRC 4. If using a virtual environment, ensure it's activated

entries.heading: Kernel Dies Immediately
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Kernel starts but immediately transitions to "dead" state *Solutions:* 1. Check the Jupyter output channel for error messages: - View  Output  Select "Jupyter Kernels" 2. Test the kernel outside VS Code: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never jupyter console --kernel=python3 #+END_SRC 3. Check kernel logs in Jupyter runtime directory: - Linux: ~/.local/share/jupyter/runtime/ - macOS: ~/Library/Jupyter/runtime/ - Windows: %APPDATA%\jupyter\runtime 4. Common issu

entries.heading: ZeroMQ Errors
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* "Failed to load ZeroMQ native module" *Solutions:* 1. The extension will display instructions to rebuild the module 2. This is typically only needed when VS Code's Electron version changes 3. Follow the on-screen instructions or rebuild manually: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never cd <extension-directory> npm run rebuild-zmq #+END_SRC 4. Restart VS Code after rebuilding

entries.heading: Connection Timeout
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* "Timeout waiting for kernel to start" *Solutions:* 1. Increase timeout if using a slow kernel (Julia) 2. Check firewall settings (kernels use localhost ports) 3. Verify ports are available (not blocked by other processes) 4. Check system resources (CPU, memory)

entries.heading: Output Not Appearing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Code executes but no results shown *Possible causes:* 1. :results silent header argument 2. :exports none or :exports code 3. Code doesn't produce output (no print/return) 4. Error occurred but was suppressed *Solutions:* 1. Remove :results silent 2. Check :exports setting 3. Add explicit print() statements 4. Check stderr in output channel

entries.heading: Images Not Saving
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Plots execute but no image file created *Solutions:* 1. Ensure :results file is set (or omitted, file is default for graphics) 2. Check .ob-jupyter/ directory exists and is writable 3. Verify the plotting library is properly configured: - Python: plt.show() or display(fig) - Julia: Just evaluate the plot object - R: Plotting functions automatically display 4. Check that your code actually generates graphics: #+BEGIN_SRC python :eval never import matplotl

entries.heading: Kernel State Confusion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Variables not found or unexpected state *Solutions:* 1. Verify you're using the same :session name 2. Check execution order (blocks may be out of sequence) 3. Restart the kernel to clear state 4. Use explicit session names to avoid confusion

entries.heading: Multiple Kernel Versions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Wrong kernel version selected *Solutions:* 1. List all kernel specs: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never jupyter kernelspec list #+END_SRC 2. Use specific kernel names in kernel.json (e.g., julia-1.9) 3. Remove unwanted kernel specs: #+BEGIN_SRC shell :eval never jupyter kernelspec uninstall <kernel-name> #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Session Conflicts
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] *Symptom:* Unexpected shared state between blocks This is by design! Blocks with the same :session name share state. *Solutions:* 1. Use different session names for independent computations 2. Use no :session for isolated executions 3. Restart the kernel to clear shared state

entries.heading: Session Naming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Use descriptive session names: :session data-preprocessing - Group related blocks in the same session - Use separate sessions for independent analyses - Omit :session for quick one-off computations

entries.heading: Image Management
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Add .ob-jupyter/ to .gitignore if outputs are generated - Use :file custom-name.png for important plots you want to keep - Periodically clean up .ob-jupyter/ to save disk space - Use SVG format for publication-quality vector graphics

entries.heading: Performance Optimization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Keep kernels running during active development - Shutdown unused kernels to free memory - Use :cache yes for expensive computations - Consider :results silent for intermediate steps - Break large computations into smaller blocks

entries.heading: Reproducibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Document kernel versions and dependencies - Use :session to ensure execution order - Include setup blocks with :exports none - Consider :prologue for common imports - Test the full document with a fresh kernel

entries.heading: Error Handling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Check the "Jupyter Kernels" output channel for detailed errors - Use explicit print() statements for debugging - Interrupt kernels rather than restarting when possible - Add try/except blocks for robust error handling

entries.heading: Literate Programming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Explain code intent before each block - Use :exports code for implementation details - Use :exports results to show only output - Group related blocks under headings - Use :tangle to extract code to files

entries.heading: Mixed Language Workflows
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] - Use JSON/CSV files to pass data between languages - Keep each language in its own session - Document data formats and conventions - Consider temporary files for large data transfers - Use each language for its strengths

entries.heading: Complete Data Analysis Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:11] Here's a complete example showing a data analysis workflow: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* Data Analysis: Sales Trends This analysis examines monthly sales data to identify trends and seasonality. ,** Data Loading First, load and clean the data: ,#+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-python :session analysis :exports both import pandas as pd import numpy as np # Generate sample sales data np.random.seed(42) dates = pd.date_range('2023-01-01', '2023-12-31', freq='D') sales = 1000 + np.random.nor

entries.heading: Julia Scientific Computing Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:52] Numerical Methods: Newton's Method #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-julia :session numerics :exports both # Define function and derivative f(x) = x^2 - 2 fp(x) = 2x # Newton's method implementation function newton(f, df, x0; tol=1e-6, maxiter=100) x = x0 for i in 1:maxiter fx = f(x) if abs(fx) < tol return x, i end x = x - fx / df(x) end return x, maxiter end # Find sqrt(2) root, iters = newton(f, fp, 1.0) println("Root: $root") println("Iterations: $iters")

entries.heading: R Statistical Analysis Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:52] Statistical Analysis: t-test #+BEGIN_SRC jupyter-r :session stats :exports both # Generate two samples set.seed(123) group_a <- rnorm(50, mean=100, sd=15) group_b <- rnorm(50, mean=105, sd=15) # Perform t-test result <- t.test(group_a, group_b) print(result) #+END_SRC #+RESULTS: : Welch Two Sample t-test : : data:  group_a and group_b : t = -2.4316, df = 97.951, p-value = 0.01685 : alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 : 95 percent conf
