entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:09] The Scimax Capture system provides a quick and efficient way to capture notes, tasks, ideas, and snippets without interrupting your workflow. Inspired by Emacs org-capture, it allows you to define templates that automatically format and file your captured content to the right location.

entries.heading: What is Capture?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:09] Capture is a fast note-taking system that: - Collects information quickly with minimal keystrokes - Uses templates to structure your notes consistently - Automatically files content to the appropriate location - Supports various capture types (TODOs, notes, journal entries, code snippets, etc.) - Includes context from where you initiated the capture (links, selection, clipboard)

entries.heading: Key Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:09] - *Template-based capture*: Define reusable templates for different types of content - *Flexible targeting*: Capture to end of file, under specific headlines, or in date trees - *Context awareness*: Automatically includes links to source location, timestamps, and selected text - *Quick capture commands*: Fast shortcuts for common captures (TODO, note) - *Preview before saving*: Optional preview of captured content before filing - *Custom variables*: Rich template l

entries.heading: Philosophy
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:09] The capture system follows the principle of "capture first, organize later." Instead of interrupting your flow to decide where something belongs or how to format it, you simply invoke a capture template and let the system handle the details. This reduces friction and helps you maintain focus on your primary task.

entries.heading: Your First Capture
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:54] The quickest way to capture a TODO is: 1. Press `C-c c' (or run `Scimax: Capture') 2. Select the "Todo" template (or press `t') 3. Enter your task description 4. Press Enter Your TODO is now filed to `todo.org' without leaving your current context.

entries.heading: Quick TODO Capture
entries.content: For even faster TODO capture, use the dedicated quick capture command: 1. Press `C-c t' (or run `Scimax: Quick Capture TODO') 2. Type your task 3. Press Enter This bypasses the template picker and goes straight to TODO capture.

entries.heading: Capturing with Context
entries.content: When you invoke capture with text selected: 1. Select some text in your editor 2. Press `C-c c' 3. Choose a template (e.g., "Code Snippet") 4. The selected text is automatically included in your capture The capture system also includes a link back to where you initiated the capture, making it easy to return to context later.

entries.heading: Built-in Templates
entries.content: Scimax comes with several built-in templates:

entries.heading: Todo Template (`t')
entries.content: Captures a TODO item to `todo.org': #+begin_src org ,* TODO Task description #+end_src

entries.heading: Note Template (`n')
entries.content: Captures a quick note to `notes.org': #+begin_src org ,* Note title [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] Note content here... #+end_src

entries.heading: Journal Template (`j')
entries.content: Captures a journal entry to `journal.org' in a date tree: #+begin_src org ,* 2026 ,** 2026-01 January ,*** 2026-01-13 Monday ,**** [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] Entry title Entry content... #+end_src

entries.heading: Meeting Template (`m')
entries.content: Captures structured meeting notes to `meetings.org': #+begin_src org ,* Meeting: Subject <2026-01-13 Mon 14:00> ,** Attendees Names... ,** Agenda ,** Notes ,** Action Items #+end_src

entries.heading: Code Snippet Template (`s')
entries.content: Captures code snippets to `snippets.org': #+begin_src org ,* Description :PROPERTIES: :CREATED: [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] :SOURCE: [[file:/path/to/source.ts::42]] :END: ,#+BEGIN_SRC python selected code here ,#+END_SRC #+end_src

entries.heading: Bookmark Template (`b')
entries.content: Saves bookmarks to `bookmarks.org': #+begin_src org ,* [[https://example.com][Page Title]] [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] Optional notes about the bookmark... #+end_src

entries.heading: Viewing All Templates
entries.content: To see all available templates: - Run `Scimax: List Capture Templates' - Or press `C-c c' to see the template picker Each template shows: - Its key (single letter shortcut) - Template name and description - Target file

entries.heading: Using the Template Creator
entries.content: The easiest way to create a template is with the interactive creator: 1. Run `Scimax: Create Capture Template' 2. Enter a key (e.g., `r' for "Research note") 3. Enter a name (e.g., "Research Note") 4. Specify the target file (e.g., `research.org') 5. Choose where to insert (end of file, under headline, date tree) 6. Enter the template content The template is saved to your VS Code settings and immediately available.

entries.heading: Manual Template Configuration
Template Structure
entries.content: Each template has these properties: | Property      | Type    | Required | Description                           | |---------------+---------+----------+---------------------------------------| | =key=         | string  | Yes      | Single character or short key         | | =name=        | string  | Yes      | Display name                          | | =description= | string  | No       | Longer description                    | | =file=        | string  | Yes      | Target file path

entries.heading: Template Syntax
entries.content: Templates use a powerful placeholder system to insert dynamic content.

entries.heading: Basic Placeholders
entries.content: | Placeholder | Description                              | Example                  | |-------------+------------------------------------------+--------------------------| | =%?=        | Final cursor position                    | =* TODO Task%?=          | | =%i=        | Initial content (selection or clipboard) | =Description: %i=        | | =%t=        | Date (inactive timestamp)                | =[2026-01-13 Mon]=       | | =%T=        | Date and time (active timestamp)         | =<2026-01-1

entries.heading: Interactive Prompts
entries.content: | Placeholder           | Description                     | Example                        | |-----------------------+---------------------------------+--------------------------------| | =%^{prompt}=          | Prompt for input                | =%^{Task description}=         | | =%^{prompt\vert{}default}= | Prompt with default value       | =%^{Priority\vert{}HIGH}=           | | =%^t=                 | Prompt for date                 | Asks for date input            | | =%^T=                 |

entries.heading: Link Placeholders
entries.content: | Placeholder | Description                         | Result                                       | |-------------+-------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------| | =%a=        | Annotation (link to source)         | =[[file:/path/to/source.ts::42]]=            | | =%A=        | Annotation with description         | =[[file:/path/to/source.ts::42][source.ts:42]]= | | =%l=        | Literal link                        | =file:/path/to/source.ts::42=

entries.heading: Simple TODO with prompt
entries.content: #+begin_src org ,* TODO %^{Task} #+end_src When captured, prompts for "Task" and creates: #+begin_src org ,* TODO Write documentation #+end_src

entries.heading: Note with timestamp and link back to source
entries.content: #+begin_src org ,* %^{Title} %U %i Source: %a #+end_src Creates: #+begin_src org ,* Meeting notes [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] Discussed project timeline Source: [[file:/home/user/project.org::25]] #+end_src

entries.heading: Meeting template with multiple prompts
entries.content: #+begin_src org ,* %^{Meeting subject} %T ,** Attendees %^{Attendees} ,** Agenda %? #+end_src Prompts for subject and attendees, places cursor under Agenda.

entries.heading: Capture Targets
entries.content: Capture targets determine where your captured content is inserted.

entries.heading: File Target (`file')
entries.content: Appends to the end of the file. #+begin_src json { "target": { "type": "file" } } #+end_src With `prepend: true', inserts at the beginning (after file-level keywords): #+begin_src json { "target": { "type": "file", "prepend": true } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Headline Target (`file+headline')
entries.content: Inserts under a specific headline. If the headline doesn't exist, it's created. #+begin_src json { "target": { "type": "file+headline", "headline": "Inbox" } } #+end_src This finds or creates a headline `* Inbox' and appends content as a child. With `prepend: true', inserts right after the headline: #+begin_src json { "target": { "type": "file+headline", "headline": "Inbox", "prepend": true } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Date Tree Target (`file+datetree')
entries.content: Creates a hierarchical date tree structure: #+begin_src org ,* 2026 ,** 2026-01 January ,*** 2026-01-13 Monday ,**** Your captured content here #+end_src #+begin_src json { "target": { "type": "file+datetree" } } #+end_src Perfect for journal entries and time-based organization.

entries.heading: Default Target
entries.content: If no target is specified, content is appended to the end of the file: #+begin_src json { "file": "notes.org", "template": "* %^{Note}\n%?" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Capture Command
entries.content: The main capture command opens the template picker: - *Command*: `Scimax: Capture' - *Keybinding*: `C-c c' This shows all available templates. Select one to begin capture.

entries.heading: Capture by Key
entries.content: If you know the template key, you can capture directly: - *Command*: `Scimax: Capture by Key' - Enter the template key (e.g., `t' for TODO)

entries.heading: Quick Capture Commands
entries.content: For common captures, use dedicated quick capture commands:

entries.heading: Quick TODO
entries.content: - *Command*: `Scimax: Quick Capture TODO' - *Keybinding*: `C-c t' Directly captures a TODO without showing the template picker.

entries.heading: Quick Note
entries.content: - *Command*: `Scimax: Quick Capture Note' Directly captures a note.

entries.heading: Capture Process
entries.content: 1. *Invoke capture*: Press `C-c c' or run a quick capture command 2. *Select template*: Choose from the picker (or skip if using quick capture) 3. *Fill prompts*: Enter values for any `%^{prompt}' placeholders 4. *Preview* (optional): Review the captured content 5. *Confirm*: Press "Capture" to file the content The captured content is inserted at the target location, and you receive a confirmation message.

entries.heading: Capturing with Selection
entries.content: When you have text selected: 1. Select text in the editor 2. Press `C-c c' 3. Choose a template The selected text is available as `%i' in your template. Perfect for: - Capturing code snippets - Quoting text - Collecting research excerpts

entries.heading: Capturing with Context Links
entries.content: Templates can include links back to where you initiated the capture: - `%a' creates a link to the source location - `%A' creates a link with description (filename:line) - `%l' creates a literal link string Example template: #+begin_src org ,* %^{Note} %U %i Source: %A #+end_src Creates: #+begin_src org ,* Important finding [2026-01-13 Mon 14:30] Selected text here Source: [[file:/home/user/research.org::42][research.org:42]] #+end_src

entries.heading: Capture Preview
entries.content: Enable preview to review content before filing: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.showPreview": true } #+end_src When enabled, you can: - See the expanded template content - Review formatting and placement - Cancel or confirm the capture

entries.heading: Auto-open After Capture
entries.content: Configure whether to open the target file after capture: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.openAfterCapture": true } #+end_src When enabled, the target file opens and the cursor jumps to the captured content.

entries.heading: Capture to Journal
entries.content: Capture integrates seamlessly with the journal system.

entries.heading: Journal Capture Template
entries.content: The built-in journal template (`j') uses date tree targeting: #+begin_src json { "key": "j", "name": "Journal", "file": "journal.org", "template": "* %U %^{Entry title}\n%?", "target": { "type": "file+datetree" } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Custom Journal Captures
entries.content: Create specialized journal capture templates:

entries.heading: Daily Reflection
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "d", "name": "Daily Reflection", "file": "journal.org", "template": "* Daily Reflection
** What went well
%^{Wins}
** What to improve
%^{Improvements}
** Tomorrow's focus
%?", "target": { "type": "file+datetree" } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Quick Log Entry
entries.content: #+begin_src json { "key": "l", "name": "Log Entry", "file": "journal.org", "template": "* %U - %^{What happened?}", "target": { "type": "file+datetree" } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Integrating with Journal Directory
entries.content: You can point capture templates to your journal directory: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.defaultDirectory": "~/scimax-journal", "scimax.capture.templates": [ { "key": "j", "name": "Journal Entry", "file": "2026/01/13/2026-01-13.org", "template": "* %T %^{Entry}\n%?" } ] } #+end_src Or use the journal's date structure dynamically with date tree targeting.

entries.heading: Capture to Inbox
entries.content: A common GTD workflow uses an "inbox" for quick captures that are processed later.

entries.heading: Inbox Setup
entries.content:
1. Create an inbox file (`inbox.org') 2. Define a capture template targeting it #+begin_src json { "key": "i", "name": "Inbox", "file": "inbox.org", "template": "* %^{Quick capture}
%U
%?

Source: %a" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Inbox with Categories
Settings Overview
entries.content: | Setting                            | Type    | Default | Description                       | |------------------------------------+---------+---------+-----------------------------------| | =scimax.capture.templates=         | array   | =[ ]=   | Custom capture templates          | | =scimax.capture.defaultDirectory=  | string  | =""=    | Default directory for capture files | | =scimax.capture.showPreview=       | boolean | =true=  | Show preview before capture       | | =scimax.capture.openA

entries.heading: Default Directory
entries.content: Set a default directory for all capture files: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.defaultDirectory": "~/org" } #+end_src Template file paths are resolved relative to this directory: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.defaultDirectory": "~/org", "scimax.capture.templates": [ { "key": "t", "name": "Todo", "file": "todo.org",  // Resolves to ~/org/todo.org "template": "* TODO %^{Task}\n%?" } ] } #+end_src

entries.heading: File Path Resolution
entries.content: Capture resolves file paths in this order: 1. *Absolute paths*: `/home/user/notes/todo.org' - used as-is 2. *Home directory*: ``/org/todo.org' - expands `'' to home directory 3. *Default directory*: `todo.org' - resolves relative to `defaultDirectory' 4. *Workspace*: `todo.org' - resolves relative to first workspace folder

entries.heading: Configuring Preview
entries.content: Control whether to show preview before saving: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.showPreview": true } #+end_src When enabled: - Preview shows the expanded template content - You can choose "Capture", "Preview", or "Cancel" - Preview opens content in a temporary editor When disabled: - Content is captured immediately - Faster workflow for trusted templates

entries.heading: Auto-open Behavior
entries.content: Control whether the target file opens after capture: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.openAfterCapture": true } #+end_src When enabled: - Target file opens in editor - Cursor jumps to captured content - Useful for immediately expanding on the capture When disabled: - Capture happens in background - You stay in your current file - Faster workflow for quick captures

entries.heading: Complete Example Configuration
Inbox Processing
entries.content: 1. *Quick capture everything*: Use `C-c c'  `i' to capture to inbox 2. *Process inbox regularly*: Review inbox.org daily 3. *Refile to projects*: Move items to appropriate project files 4. *Archive processed items*: Keep inbox clean

entries.heading: Inbox Template
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "i", "name": "Inbox", "file": "inbox.org", "template": "* %^{Capture}
%U
%?

Context: %a" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Collect Sources
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "r", "name": "Research Source", "file": "research.org", "template": "* %^{Source}
:PROPERTIES:
:URL: %^{URL}
:ADDED: %U
:END:

** Summary
%?

** Quotes
%i", "target": { "type": "file+headline", "headline": "Sources" } } #+end_src Usage: 1. Select a quote from a paper/article 2. Press `C-c c'  `r' 3. Enter source name and URL 4. The quote is captured in the "Quotes" section

entries.heading: Capture Code Examples
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "c", "name": "Code Example", "file": "code-snippets.org", "template": "* %^{Description}
:PROPERTIES:
:LANGUAGE: %^{Language|typescript|python|javascript}
:SOURCE: %a
:CREATED: %U
:END:

#+BEGIN_SRC %\2
%i
#+END_SRC

** Notes
%?", "tags": ["code", "example"] } #+end_src Usage: 1. Select code in editor 2. Press `C-c c'  `c' 3. Describe the code and specify language 4. Creates a documented code snippet with link back to source

entries.heading: Before Meeting
entries.content:
Capture meeting agenda: #+begin_src json { "key": "ma", "name": "Meeting Agenda", "file": "meetings.org", "template": "* MEETING %^{Subject}
SCHEDULED: %^t
** Attendees
%^{Attendees}
** Agenda
%?
** Notes

** Action Items
", "properties": { "MEETING_TYPE": "%^{Type|standup|planning|review|1on1}" } } #+end_src

entries.heading: During Meeting
entries.content: Use quick note capture for rapid notes: #+begin_src json { "key": "mn", "name": "Meeting Note", "file": "meetings.org", "template": "* %T - %^{Note}\n%?", "target": { "type": "file+headline", "headline": "Meeting Notes" } } #+end_src

entries.heading: After Meeting
Morning Review
Evening Review
Capture Learnings
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "l", "name": "Learning", "file": "knowledge.org", "template": "* %^{What did you learn?}
:PROPERTIES:
:TOPIC: %^{Topic|programming|design|business|other}
:LEARNED: %U
:SOURCE: %a
:END:

%?

** Related
", "tags": ["learning"] } #+end_src

entries.heading: Capture Questions
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "q", "name": "Question", "file": "questions.org", "template": "* QUESTION %^{Question}
%U

** Context
%?

** Potential Answers

** Resolution
", "tags": ["question"] } #+end_src When you find the answer, update the "Resolution" section.

entries.heading: Main Commands
entries.content: | Command                                | Description                          | Keybinding  | |----------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------| | =Scimax: Capture=                      | Open capture template picker         | =C-c c=  | | =Scimax: Capture by Key=               | Capture using template key           |             | | =Scimax: Quick Capture TODO=           | Fast TODO capture                    | =C-c t=  | | =Scimax: Quick Capture N

entries.heading: Template Management Commands
entries.content: | Command                              | Description                    | |--------------------------------------+--------------------------------| | =Scimax: Create Capture Template=    | Interactive template creation  | | =Scimax: List Capture Templates=     | Show all templates             | | =Scimax: Configure Capture Templates= | Open settings.json for capture |

entries.heading: Default Keybindings
entries.content: | Keybinding  | Action                   | Context        | |-------------+--------------------------+----------------| | =C-c c=  | Open capture picker      | Global         | | =C-c t=  | Quick TODO capture       | Global         |

entries.heading: Custom Keybindings
entries.content: Add custom keybindings in `keybindings.json' (`C-k C-s' to open):

entries.heading: Quick Capture Note
entries.content: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+c n", "command": "scimax.capture.note" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Capture to Inbox
entries.content: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+c i", "command": "scimax.captureByKey", "args": "i" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Journal Capture
entries.content: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+c j", "command": "scimax.captureByKey", "args": "j" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Context-aware Keybindings
entries.content: Capture only when editing org files: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+c c", "command": "scimax.capture", "when": "editorLangId == org" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Start Simple
entries.content: Begin with a few basic templates: - TODO capture - Note capture - Journal entry Add specialized templates as needs emerge.

entries.heading: Use Consistent File Organization
entries.content: Keep capture files organized: #+begin_example ~/org/  inbox.org          # Unprocessed captures  todo.org           # Active tasks  projects/          # Project-specific files     project-a.org     project-b.org  journal.org        # Journal entries  notes.org          # General notes  archive.org        # Completed items #+end_example

entries.heading: Process Inbox Regularly
entries.content: Set a schedule to process inbox.org: - Daily: Quick review and refile urgent items - Weekly: Deep review, refile everything

entries.heading: Leverage Context Links
entries.content: Always include `%a' or `%A' in templates to link back to source: #+begin_src org Source: %a #+end_src This makes it easy to jump back to context when reviewing captures.

entries.heading: Use Tags for Filtering
entries.content: Add tags to templates for easy filtering: #+begin_src json { "tags": ["meeting", "important"] } #+end_src Later, search for `:meeting:' to find all meeting-related captures.

entries.heading: Combine with Agenda
entries.content: Capture TODO items with timestamps to make them appear in the agenda: #+begin_src org ,* TODO %^{Task} SCHEDULED: %^t %? #+end_src

entries.heading: Create Domain-Specific Templates
entries.content: For specialized work, create focused templates:

entries.heading: Bug Report Template
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "bug", "name": "Bug Report", "file": "bugs.org", "template": "* BUG %^{Description}
:PROPERTIES:
:REPORTED: %U
:SEVERITY: %^{Severity|high|medium|low}
:COMPONENT: %^{Component}
:END:

** Steps to Reproduce
%?

** Expected Behavior

** Actual Behavior

** Environment
", "tags": ["bug"] } #+end_src

entries.heading: Feature Request Template
entries.content:
#+begin_src json { "key": "feat", "name": "Feature Request", "file": "features.org", "template": "* FEATURE %^{Feature}
:PROPERTIES:
:REQUESTED: %U
:PRIORITY: %^{Priority|high|medium|low}
:EFFORT: %^{Effort|small|medium|large}
:END:

** Description
%?

** Use Case

** Technical Notes
", "tags": ["feature"] } #+end_src

entries.heading: Disable Preview for Speed
entries.content: For templates you trust, disable preview for faster capture: #+begin_src json { "scimax.capture.showPreview": false, "scimax.capture.openAfterCapture": false } #+end_src This makes capture nearly instantaneous.

entries.heading: Use Keyboard-driven Workflow
entries.content: Memorize keys for your most common captures: - `C-c c'  `t'  Task description  Enter (TODO) - `C-c c'  `j'  Entry title  Enter (Journal) - `C-c t'  Task  Enter (Quick TODO) With practice, capture becomes muscle memory.

entries.heading: Template Not Appearing in Picker
entries.content: - Check `settings.json' for syntax errors - Ensure template has required fields: `key', `name', `file', `template' - Reload window (`C-S-P'  `Reload Window')

entries.heading: Capture File Not Created
entries.content: - Check file path in template configuration - Ensure directory exists or use absolute path - Check `scimax.capture.defaultDirectory' setting - Verify write permissions

entries.heading: Template Placeholders Not Expanding
entries.content: - Verify placeholder syntax: `%^{Prompt}' not `$^{Prompt}' - Check for typos in placeholder names - Some placeholders require context (e.g., `%a' needs source file)

entries.heading: Cursor Position (`%?') Not Working
entries.content: - Ensure `%?' is in template - Open file after capture (`scimax.capture.openAfterCapture: true') - The cursor jumps to `%?' position when file opens

entries.heading: Date Tree Not Creating Structure
entries.content: - Verify target type: `"type": "file+datetree"' - Ensure template is capturing to correct file - Check file for malformed existing date tree structure

entries.heading: Journal Integration
entries.content: Capture complements the journal system. Use capture templates with `file+datetree' targeting for seamless journal integration. See [[file:14-journal.org][Journal Documentation]] for details.

entries.heading: Agenda Integration
entries.content: Captured TODO items with timestamps appear in the agenda view. See [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda Documentation]] for details.

entries.heading: Database Search
entries.content: All captured content is indexed and searchable via the database. See [[file:18-database-search.org][Database Search Documentation]] for details.

entries.content: - [[file:01-getting-started.org][Getting Started Guide]] - [[file:26-configuration.org][Configuration Reference]] - [[file:24-keybindings.org][Keybinding Reference]] - [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items Documentation]]

entries.heading: Template Hooks (Future)
entries.content: Future versions may support JavaScript hooks for advanced template behavior: #+begin_src json { "beforeCapture": "return { customData: 'value' }", "afterCapture": "console.log('Captured!')" } #+end_src

entries.heading: Dynamic Template Selection (Future)
entries.content: Future versions may support conditional template selection based on context.

entries.heading: Template Inheritance (Future)
entries.content: Future versions may support template inheritance for sharing common configuration.

entries.heading: Complete Template Reference
entries.content: | Field           | Type     | Required | Description                              | |-----------------+----------+----------+------------------------------------------| | =key=           | string   | Yes      | Unique template key (1-5 characters)     | | =name=          | string   | Yes      | Display name                             | | =description=   | string   | No       | Long description                         | | =file=          | string   | Yes      | Target file path

entries.heading: Placeholder Reference
entries.content: | Placeholder                | Expansion                          | |----------------------------+------------------------------------| | =%?=                       | Cursor position                    | | =%i=                       | Initial content (selection)        | | =%a=                       | Annotation link                    | | =%A=                       | Annotation link with description   | | =%l=                       | Literal link                       | | =%c=

entries.heading: Target Type Reference
entries.content: | Target Type       | Description                           | |-------------------+---------------------------------------| | =file=            | End or beginning of file              | | =headline=        | Under specific headline               | | =file+headline=   | File then headline                    | | =file+datetree=   | Hierarchical date tree                |

entries.heading: Example Templates Library
entries.content: See `examples/capture-templates.json' in the Scimax repository for a collection of ready-to-use templates for various workflows.

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:15] The Scimax notebook system provides project-based document organization inspired by Emacs Scimax's `scimax-notebook' package. A notebook is a structured project directory that can contain research notes, documentation, code, data, and other project materials.

entries.heading: What is a Notebook?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:15] A notebook is a project directory with: - A `.scimax' configuration directory - Optional master/entry file (README.org, index.org, etc.) - Project markers (`.projectile', `.git', etc.) - Organized subdirectories for content - Metadata including collaborators, keywords, and custom settings Notebooks can be used for: - Research projects with notes, data, and analysis - Software development projects - Personal knowledge management - Course materials and teaching resou

entries.heading: Key Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:16] - *Project Templates*: Start with pre-configured structures for research, software, or notes - *Master Files*: Central entry point for each notebook - *Automatic Detection*: Discovers existing projects in your workspace - *Search & Navigation*: Full-text search and agenda views scoped to the notebook - *Collaboration*: Track collaborators with roles - *Integration*: Works with projectile markers and git repositories - *Archiving*: Create zip archives of committed f

entries.heading: New Notebook Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:16] Create a new notebook with `Scimax: New Notebook': #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: New Notebook #+end_src You'll be prompted for: 1. *Name*: The notebook directory name (e.g., "my-research-project") 2. *Description*: Optional brief description 3. *Parent Directory*: Where to create the notebook (defaults to `scimax.notebook.directory' setting) 4. *Template*: Choose from empty, research, software, or notes 5. *Initialize Git*: Whether to run `git init' in the

entries.heading: Empty Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:17] Minimal structure with a `README.org' file: #+begin_example my-notebook/  .scimax/     config.json  .projectile  README.org #+end_example The `README.org' contains: #+begin_src org ,#+TITLE: My Notebook ,#+DATE: 2026-01-13 ,* My Notebook [Project description] #+end_src

entries.heading: Research Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:17] For scientific research projects: #+begin_example research-project/  .scimax/     config.json  .projectile  README.org  references.bib  data/  figures/  scripts/ #+end_example The `README.org' is structured with research sections: #+begin_src org ,#+TITLE: Research Project ,#+AUTHOR: ,#+DATE: 2026-01-13 ,#+DESCRIPTION: Research project description ,* Overview ,* Literature Review ,* Methods ,* Results ,* Discussion ,* References #+end_src

entries.heading: Software Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:17] For software development projects: #+begin_example software-project/  .scimax/     config.json  .projectile  README.md  src/  tests/  docs/ #+end_example The `README.md' contains standard software documentation sections: #+begin_src markdown # Software Project ## Installation ## Usage ## Development ## License #+end_src

entries.heading: Notes Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:17] For note-taking and personal knowledge management: #+begin_example notes-project/  .scimax/     config.json  .projectile  index.org  journal/ #+end_example The `index.org' file: #+begin_src org ,#+TITLE: My Notes ,#+DATE: 2026-01-13 ,* Topics ,* Journal See [[file:journal/][journal entries]]. ,* References #+end_src

entries.heading: Manual Notebook Setup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:17] You can also manually create a notebook directory: 1. Create a project directory 2. Add a `.projectile' file (can be empty) 3. Optionally create `.scimax/config.json' 4. Add a master file (README.org, index.org, etc.) Scimax will automatically detect the project when you open it in VS Code.

entries.heading: Directory Layout
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] A typical notebook has this structure: #+begin_example notebook-name/  .scimax/                  # Scimax configuration     config.json          # Notebook metadata and settings  .projectile              # Projectile marker (can be empty)  .git/                    # Optional git repository  README.org               # Master file (entry point)  notes/                   # Subdirectories for content  data/                    # Project-specific di

entries.heading: Configuration File
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] The `.scimax/config.json' file contains notebook metadata: #+begin_src json { "name": "My Research Project", "description": "A study of molecular dynamics", "keywords": ["physics", "molecular-dynamics", "simulation"], "collaborators": [ { "name": "Dr. Jane Smith", "email": "jane@university.edu", "role": "Principal Investigator" }, { "name": "Bob Johnson", "email": "bob@university.edu", "role": "Graduate Student" } ], "masterFile": "README.org",

entries.heading: Configuration Fields
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] - `name' (string): Display name for the notebook - `description' (string, optional): Brief description - `keywords' (array, optional): Tags for searching and categorization - `collaborators' (array, optional): List of project collaborators - `masterFile' (string, optional): Path to the main entry file (relative to notebook root) - `journalDirectory' (string, optional): Directory for journal entries - `bibliographyFiles' (array, optional): Bibliography files for org

entries.heading: Master Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] The master file is the main entry point for your notebook. When you open a notebook, Scimax automatically opens this file. Scimax looks for master files in this order: 1. File specified in `config.json' (`masterFile' field) 2. `README.org' 3. `README.md' 4. `index.org' 5. `index.md' 6. `main.org' 7. `main.md' Best practices for master files: - Include project overview and goals - Link to other important files - Maintain a table of contents - Document the project st

entries.heading: Project Markers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] Scimax detects projects by looking for marker files: - `.projectile' - Projectile project marker - `.git' - Git repository - `.scimax' - Scimax configuration directory - `package.json' - Node.js project - `pyproject.toml' - Python project (PEP 518) - `Cargo.toml' - Rust project - `go.mod' - Go module - `pom.xml' - Maven project - `build.gradle' - Gradle project - `.project' - Eclipse project When you open a directory with any of these markers, Scimax automatically

entries.heading: Open Notebook Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] `Scimax: Open Notebook' shows a quick pick menu of all registered notebooks: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Open Notebook #+end_src The list shows: - Notebook name - Description - Full path - Git status indicator ($(git-branch) icon) Notebooks are sorted by last accessed time (most recent first).

entries.heading: Open Master File
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] Directly open the master file of the current or selected notebook: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Open Notebook Master File #+end_src If no current notebook, you'll be prompted to select one.

entries.heading: Notebook Detection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] Scimax automatically detects projects when: 1. VS Code starts (scans workspace folders) 2. You open a file in a project directory 3. You manually create a notebook To disable automatic detection: #+begin_src json { "scimax.notebook.autoDetect": false } #+end_src

entries.heading: Switching Notebooks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] Opening a notebook sets it as the "current notebook" which affects: - Scoped search results - Agenda views - Recent files list - Status bar indicators The current notebook persists across VS Code sessions.

entries.heading: Recent Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] View recently modified files in the current notebook: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Recent Files in Notebook #+end_src Shows up to 20 files sorted by modification time, with: - File name - Relative path from notebook root - File type icon

entries.heading: Listing Notebook Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 20:18] Scimax tracks all `.org' and `.md' files in the notebook, automatically excluding: - Hidden directories (starting with `.') - `node_modules/' - `dist/' and `build/' - `.git/'

entries.heading: Search in Notebook
entries.content: Search within a specific notebook using full-text search: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Search in Notebook #+end_src This command: 1. Prompts for a notebook (or uses current notebook) 2. Asks for search query 3. Sets database search scope to the notebook directory 4. Displays results with: - File name and line number - Context preview - Relative path Results are limited to 100 matches and use FTS5 full-text search with BM25 ranking.

entries.heading: Notebook Agenda
entries.content: View agenda items (TODOs, scheduled, deadlines) scoped to a notebook: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Notebook Agenda #+end_src Shows: - TODO items with state (TODO, DONE, etc.) - Scheduled items with dates - Deadlines with countdown/overdue indicators - Priority indicators ([#A], [#B], [#C]) The agenda includes items up to 2 weeks in the future and all unscheduled TODOs.

entries.heading: Notebook Index
entries.content: Index all files in a notebook for search: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Index Notebook #+end_src This recursively indexes all `.org' and `.md' files in the notebook directory, updating the Scimax database for fast full-text and semantic search. Progress is shown in a notification with a progress bar.

entries.heading: Adding Collaborators
entries.content: Track project collaborators with: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Add Collaborator #+end_src You'll be prompted for: - Name - Email address - Role (optional, e.g., "Principal Investigator", "Developer") Collaborators are stored in `.scimax/config.json' and can be viewed in: - Notebook tree view - Notebook info command

entries.heading: Viewing Collaborators
entries.content: Collaborators appear in: 1. *Notebook Tree View*: Expand a notebook  Collaborators section 2. *Notebook Info*: Run `Scimax: Notebook Info' 3. *Config File*: View `.scimax/config.json' Example collaborators in config: #+begin_src json { "collaborators": [ { "name": "Dr. Alice Chen", "email": "alice@institution.edu", "role": "PI" }, { "name": "Bob Martinez", "email": "bob@student.edu", "role": "PhD Student" } ] } #+end_src

entries.heading: Core Commands
entries.content: | Command                            | Description                           | |------------------------------------+---------------------------------------| | =Scimax: New Notebook=             | Create a new notebook                 | | =Scimax: Open Notebook=            | Open/switch to a notebook             | | =Scimax: Open Notebook Master File= | Open the master file                  | | =Scimax: Recent Files in Notebook= | View recently modified files          |

entries.heading: Search and Organization
entries.content: | Command                         | Description                              | |---------------------------------+------------------------------------------| | =Scimax: Search in Notebook=    | Full-text search within notebook         | | =Scimax: Notebook Agenda=       | View agenda items (TODOs, deadlines)     | | =Scimax: Index Notebook=        | Index files for search                   |

entries.heading: Management
entries.content: | Command                                    | Description                          | |--------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------| | =Scimax: Notebook Settings=                | Edit =.scimax/config.json=           | | =Scimax: Notebook Info=                    | Show notebook metadata               | | =Scimax: Add Collaborator=                 | Add project collaborator             | | =Scimax: Archive Notebook=                 | Create zip archive (git

entries.heading: Notebook Info
entries.content: View detailed notebook information: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Notebook Info #+end_src Displays: - Notebook name and description - File system path - Number of tracked files - Number of collaborators - Git repository status - Creation date - Last accessed date

entries.heading: Notebook Settings
entries.content: Edit notebook configuration: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Notebook Settings #+end_src Opens `.scimax/config.json' in the editor. If the file doesn't exist, Scimax creates a default configuration first. After editing, save the file to apply changes.

entries.heading: Archive Notebook
entries.content: Create a zip archive of all committed files (requires git): #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Archive Notebook #+end_src This runs `git archive' to create a zip file containing the current HEAD state. The archive is saved to the parent directory with the name: #+begin_example notebook-name-2026-01-13.zip #+end_example Only works for notebooks that are git repositories. Uncommitted files are not included.

entries.heading: Remove from Tracking
entries.content: Stop tracking a notebook without deleting files: #+begin_src Command Palette  Scimax: Remove Notebook from Tracking #+end_src This removes the notebook from Scimax's registry but leaves all files on disk unchanged. Use this to clean up notebooks you no longer work with.

entries.heading: Settings
entries.content: Configure notebook behavior in VS Code settings: #+begin_src json { // Default parent directory for new notebooks "scimax.notebook.directory": "~/notebooks", // Default template: empty, research, software, notes "scimax.notebook.defaultTemplate": "research", // Automatically detect projects in workspace "scimax.notebook.autoDetect": true } #+end_src

entries.heading: `scimax.notebook.directory'
entries.content: Default parent directory for new notebooks. If not set, defaults to `~/notebooks'. Example: #+begin_src json { "scimax.notebook.directory": "/home/user/projects" } #+end_src

entries.heading: `scimax.notebook.defaultTemplate'
entries.content: Default template for new notebooks. Options: - `empty' - Minimal structure with README.org - `research' - Scientific research project - `software' - Software development project - `notes' - Note-taking with journal Example: #+begin_src json { "scimax.notebook.defaultTemplate": "research" } #+end_src

entries.heading: `scimax.notebook.autoDetect'
entries.content: Whether to automatically detect projects in workspace folders. Default: `true'. Example: #+begin_src json { "scimax.notebook.autoDetect": false } #+end_src

entries.heading: Integration with Projectile
entries.content: The notebook system integrates with projectile project management:

entries.heading: Projectile Markers
entries.content: When creating a notebook, Scimax automatically creates a `.projectile' file, which: - Marks the directory as a project root - Works with projectile commands - Helps tools identify project boundaries

entries.heading: Compatible with Projectile
entries.content: All notebooks are compatible with projectile. The `.projectile' file can contain: - Ignore patterns (one per line, starting with -) - Include patterns (one per line) Example `.projectile': #+begin_example -node_modules -*.pyc -__pycache__ -.venv -dist -build #+end_example

entries.heading: Project Root Detection
entries.content: Scimax uses the same markers as projectile to detect project roots: 1. `.projectile' 2. `.git' 3. Language-specific markers (package.json, Cargo.toml, etc.) This ensures consistent behavior between scimax notebooks and projectile commands.

entries.heading: Research Project Workflow
entries.content: 1. *Create Research Notebook*: #+begin_src Scimax: New Notebook  Name: "protein-folding-study"  Template: Research  Initialize git: Yes #+end_src 2. *Set Up Structure*: - Edit README.org with project overview - Add bibliography to references.bib - Create subdirectories: `experiments/', `analysis/' 3. *Add Collaborators*: #+begin_src Scimax: Add Collaborator  Name: Dr. Sarah Lee  Email: slee@university.edu  Role: Co-PI #+end_src 4. *Daily Work*: - Use `Scimax: Open Notebook' to switch proje

entries.heading: Software Development Workflow
entries.content: 1. *Create Software Notebook*: #+begin_src Scimax: New Notebook  Name: "api-client"  Template: Software  Initialize git: Yes #+end_src 2. *Document Architecture*: - Edit README.md with setup instructions - Create `docs/architecture.org' for design notes - Link code examples in org files with source blocks 3. *Integrate with Tools*: - Add custom commands to `.scimax/config.json': #+begin_src json { "customCommands": { "test": "npm test", "build": "npm run build",

entries.heading: Personal Knowledge Base Workflow
entries.content: 1. *Create Notes Notebook*: #+begin_src Scimax: New Notebook  Name: "knowledge-base"  Template: Notes #+end_src 2. *Organize Topics*: - Create topic directories: `programming/', `research/', `books/' - Use `index.org' as a map of knowledge areas - Link between related notes 3. *Daily Journal*: - Use journal directory for daily notes - Link journal entries to topic notes - Tag entries with keywords 4. *Search and Discovery*: - Use `Scimax: Search in Notebook' to find notes by keyword

entries.heading: Multi-Notebook Workflow
entries.content: 1. *Project Switching*: - Use `Scimax: Open Notebook' to switch between projects - Recent notebooks appear first in the list - Master file opens automatically 2. *Cross-Notebook Search*: - Use database search (not notebook-scoped) to search all projects - Use `Scimax: Search in Notebook' for focused searches 3. *Notebook Organization*: - Keep notebooks in `~/notebooks/' or custom directory - Use consistent naming: `project-name' format - Add descriptions and keywords for easy identification

entries.heading: Notebook Not Detected
entries.content: If Scimax doesn't detect your project: 1. Check for project markers (`.projectile', `.git', etc.) 2. Verify the directory is in your workspace 3. Check `scimax.notebook.autoDetect' setting 4. Manually create a `.projectile' file 5. Reload VS Code window

entries.heading: Master File Not Found
entries.content: If master file doesn't open: 1. Check `masterFile' in `.scimax/config.json' 2. Verify the file exists at the specified path 3. Use one of the default names (README.org, index.org, etc.) 4. Path should be relative to notebook root

entries.heading: Search Not Working
entries.content: If notebook search returns no results: 1. Run `Scimax: Index Notebook' to rebuild index 2. Check that files have `.org' or `.md' extensions 3. Verify database is initialized 4. Check search scope is set to notebook directory

entries.heading: Archive Command Fails
entries.content: If archiving fails: 1. Verify notebook is a git repository (`git status' works) 2. Ensure you have committed changes 3. Check git is in your PATH 4. Review error message in VS Code notifications

entries.heading: Custom Templates
entries.content: While Scimax provides built-in templates, you can create custom setups: 1. Create a notebook with empty template 2. Set up your desired structure 3. Save as a template repository 4. Clone for new projects

entries.heading: Automation with Custom Commands
entries.content: Add custom commands to `.scimax/config.json': #+begin_src json { "customCommands": { "setup": "chmod +x scripts/*.sh && npm install", "deploy": "./scripts/deploy.sh", "backup": "rsync -av data/ backup/", "report": "python scripts/generate_report.py" } } #+end_src These commands can be used with shell integrations or task runners.

entries.heading: Nested Notebooks
entries.content: Scimax supports nested projects: #+begin_example parent-notebook/  .projectile  README.org  sub-project/  .projectile  README.org #+end_example Each level is detected as a separate notebook, useful for: - Monorepo structures - Research programs with multiple studies - Course materials with per-chapter projects

entries.heading: Integration with Bibliography
entries.content: For research notebooks, integrate with org-ref: 1. Add bibliography files to config: #+begin_src json { "bibliographyFiles": ["references.bib", "papers.bib"] } #+end_src 2. Reference citations in org files: #+begin_src org See cite:Einstein1905 for details. bibliography:references.bib #+end_src 3. Use `Scimax: Open Bibliography' to manage references

entries.heading: Version Control Best Practices
entries.content: For notebooks with git: 1. Commit `.scimax/config.json' to share configuration 2. Add `.gitignore' for generated files: #+begin_example *.aux *.log *.pdf .ob-jupyter/ __pycache__/ #+end_example 3. Use branches for experimental work 4. Archive important milestones with tags: #+begin_src bash git tag -a v1.0 -m "Phase 1 complete" #+end_src 5. Use `Scimax: Archive Notebook' to create portable snapshots

entries.heading: Summary
entries.content: The Scimax notebook system provides powerful project organization for research, development, and knowledge management: - *Templates* help you start with the right structure - *Master files* provide clear entry points - *Scoped search* and *agenda views* keep you focused - *Collaboration features* track team members - *Projectile integration* works with existing tools - *Flexible configuration* adapts to your workflow Start by creating your first notebook with `Scimax: New Notebook' and exploring

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:15-capture.org][Capture]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:17-projectile.org][Projectile]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 19:55] The Scimax projectile system provides project-aware file management inspired by Emacs Projectile. It enables quick switching between projects, intelligent project detection, and project-scoped operations for efficient multi-project workflows.

entries.heading: What is Projectile?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 19:55] Projectile is a project management system that: - Automatically detects projects based on version control markers (`.git'), special files (`.projectile'), or manual registration - Maintains a list of known projects with quick-switch capabilities - Provides project-scoped file search and text search - Remembers recently accessed projects - Integrates with the notebook system for research project organization - Tracks project metadata including type and last access t

entries.heading: Key Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 19:55] - *Automatic Detection*: Discovers git repos and projectile-marked directories - *Quick Switching*: Fast navigation between known projects with =C-c p p= - *Project History*: Shows when each project was last opened - *Batch Scanning*: Scan directories to discover multiple projects at once - *File Finding*: Project-scoped file search with =C-c p f= - *Cross-Project File Finding*: Find files across all known projects with =C-c p F= - *Text Search*: Search within proj

entries.heading: Detection Methods
entries.content: Scimax uses three methods to detect projects, in this priority order: 1. *Git Repositories*: Any directory containing a .git/ subdirectory 2. *Projectile Markers*: Directories with a .projectile file 3. *Manual Registration*: Projects you explicitly add via commands

entries.heading: Automatic Detection
entries.content: When you open a workspace folder, Scimax automatically registers it as a project: #+begin_example # Opening a folder registers it automatically $ code /home/user/my-project/ # The folder is now in your project list # Type: git (if it has .git) or manual (otherwise) #+end_example

entries.heading: Creating a Projectile Marker
entries.content: To mark a directory as a projectile project, create an empty `.projectile' file in the root: #+begin_src sh # Create marker file touch .projectile # Now Scimax recognizes this as a project #+end_src The `.projectile' file can be empty or contain patterns for ignoring files (reserved for future use).

entries.heading: Project Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 10:25] Projects are classified into three types: | Type         | Marker        | Icon         | Description                         | |--------------+---------------+--------------+-------------------------------------| | =git=        | =.git/=       | Git branch   | Git repository                      | | =projectile= | =.projectile= | File icon    | Marked with .projectile file        | | =manual=     | (none)        | Folder icon  | Manually added directory

entries.heading: Switching Between Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:11] The primary projectile command is *Switch Project* (`C-c p p'): #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Switch Project Keybinding: C-c p p Hydra: Projects  p (Switch Project) #+end_src This opens a quick pick menu showing: - Project name - Full path - Project type (git, projectile, or manual) - Last opened time (e.g., "2h ago", "3d ago") Select a project to choose how to open it: | Option                 | Result                                      | |----------------------

entries.heading: Manually Adding a Project
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:11] Use `Scimax: Add Project' (`C-c p a'): #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Add Project Keybinding: C-c p a Hydra: Projects  a (Add Project) #+end_src This opens a folder picker. Select any directory to add it to your project list. #+begin_example 1. Press C-c p a 2. Navigate to /home/user/projects/my-app/ 3. Select folder  "Added project: my-app"  Project appears in the list #+end_example

entries.heading: Scanning for Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:11] To discover multiple projects at once, use `Scimax: Scan Directory for Projects': #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Scan Directory for Projects Keybinding: (none) Hydra: Projects  s (Scan for Projects) #+end_src Scanning process: 1. Select a parent directory to scan 2. Enter maximum depth (default: 2 levels deep) 3. Scimax searches for git repos and .projectile markers 4. Found projects are added automatically Example: #+begin_example Scan directory: /home/user/project

entries.heading: Removing Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] Remove projects from the list with `Scimax: Remove Project': #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Remove Project Keybinding: (none) Hydra: Projects  r (Remove Project) #+end_src Notes: - This removes the project from the *known projects list only* - It does *not* delete any files from disk - The project can be re-added at any time

entries.heading: Cleaning Up Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] Over time, projects may be moved or deleted. Use `Scimax: Cleanup Non-existent Projects': #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Cleanup Non-existent Projects Keybinding: (none) #+end_src This scans all known projects and removes entries for directories that no longer exist on disk. #+begin_example Known projects: 15 Checking each path... Removed: /home/user/old-project (not found) Removed: /tmp/temp-project (not found) Result: "Cleaned up 2 non-existent projects" #+end_exam

entries.heading: Finding Files in Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] Find files within the current project using `Scimax: Find File in Project' (`C-c p f'): #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Find File in Project Keybinding: C-c p f Hydra: Projects  f (Find File) #+end_src This delegates to VS Code's built-in quick open (`C-p'), which automatically scopes to workspace folders. Features: - Fuzzy matching (e.g., "orgpar" matches "orgParser.ts") - Recent files appear first - Respects .gitignore and VS Code ignore patterns - Fast indexing wi

entries.heading: Searching in Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] Search for text within project files using `Scimax: Search in Project' (`C-c p s'): #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Search in Project Keybinding: C-c p s Hydra: Projects  g (Search in Project) #+end_src This opens VS Code's search panel pre-scoped to the current workspace. Search features: - Regular expression support - Case sensitivity toggle - Whole word matching - Include/exclude file patterns - Replace across all matches Example workflow: #+begin_example 1. Press

entries.heading: Opening Project Root
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] Navigate to the project root in the file explorer with `Scimax: Open Project Root' (`C-c p d'): #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Open Project Root Keybinding: C-c p d Hydra: (none) #+end_src For multi-root workspaces, you'll be asked to select which project root to reveal.

entries.heading: Project Information
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:12] View details about the current project with `Scimax: Project Info': #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Project Info Keybinding: (none) #+end_src Displays: - Project name - Full path - Project type (git, projectile, manual) - Last opened timestamp - Whether it's tracked by projectile Example output: #+begin_example Name: scimax_vscode Path: /home/user/scimax_vscode Type: git Last opened: 2026-01-13 14:32:15 #+end_example

entries.heading: Sidebar Panel
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] The Projects tree view appears in the Scimax sidebar, showing all known projects. To open the sidebar: #+begin_src View  Open View...  Scimax Projects #+end_src

entries.heading: Tree View Elements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Each project in the tree shows: - *Icon*: -  Open folder icon (green) = currently open project - Git branch icon = git repository - File icon = projectile-marked project - Folder icon = manual project - *Name*: Project directory name - *Description*: - " current" for the active project - Relative time (e.g., "2h ago", "3d ago") for recent projects - Empty for never-opened projects

entries.heading: Tree Interactions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Click a project to open it: - Same behavior as `C-c p p' (Switch Project) - Choose New Window, Current Window, or Add to Workspace Right-click (context menu) actions: - Refresh tree view - Remove project - Show project info

entries.heading: Refreshing the Tree
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] The tree auto-refreshes when: - Projects are added or removed - Workspace folders change - Projects are accessed (last opened time updates) Manual refresh: #+begin_src Command: Scimax: Refresh Projects Icon: Refresh button in tree view toolbar #+end_src

entries.heading: Sorting by Last Access
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Projects are sorted by last opened time, with the most recently accessed appearing first: #+begin_example Project List: 1. scimax_vscode        (just now)     #  Currently open 2. my-research          (2h ago)       #  Recently used 3. client-website       (3d ago) 4. old-notes            (2024-11-15)   #  Long time ago #+end_example This ordering makes it quick to switch back to recently used projects.

entries.heading: Automatic Time Tracking
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Last opened time is updated automatically when: - Opening a project via `C-c p p' (Switch Project) - Clicking a project in the tree view - Opening a workspace folder that's a known project The timestamp is stored in VS Code's global state, persisting across sessions.

entries.heading: Time Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Relative times are shown for recent access: | Time Difference | Format         | Example    | |-----------------+----------------+------------| | < 1 minute      | "just now"     | just now   | | < 60 minutes    | minutes ago    | 23m ago    | | < 24 hours      | hours ago      | 5h ago     | | < 30 days       | days ago       | 12d ago    | |  30 days       | date           | 11/23/2024 |

entries.heading: All Projectile Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] | Command                                    | Keybinding  | Hydra Key | Description                        | |--------------------------------------------+-------------+-----------+------------------------------------| | =Scimax: Switch Project=                   | =C-c p p=   | p         | Switch to another project          | | =Scimax: Find File in Project=             | =C-c p f=   | f         | Find file in current project       | | =Scimax: Find File in Known

entries.heading: Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] All projectile keybindings use the =C-c p= prefix, matching Emacs Projectile conventions: #+begin_src C-c p p    Switch project C-c p f    Find file in current project C-c p F    Find file in all known projects C-c p s    Search in project C-c p d    Open project root (directory) C-c p a    Add project #+end_src These bindings work in all editors, regardless of file type.

entries.heading: Hydra Menu Access
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:13] Open the Projects hydra menu: #+begin_src 1. Open main hydra: C-c m (or Command Palette  Scimax: Hydra Menu) 2. Press 'p' for Projects #+end_src The hydra shows all projectile commands with single-key access: #+begin_example   Projects (Projectile)                  Switch                                 p  Switch Project                                                          M

entries.heading: Notebook-Projectile Relationship
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] The notebook and projectile systems work together: - *Notebooks are projects*: Creating a notebook automatically creates a `.projectile' marker - *Projects can be notebooks*: Any project can have a `.scimax/' directory to become a notebook - *Shared markers*: Both systems recognize `.projectile' files - *Unified workflow*: Switch projects with projectile, manage research structure with notebooks

entries.heading: Creating Projectile-Enabled Notebooks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] When you create a notebook with `Scimax: New Notebook': #+begin_src org my-notebook/  .scimax/     config.json        # Notebook metadata  .projectile            #  Projectile marker (auto-created)  .git/                  # Optional: if "Initialize Git" was checked  README.org #+end_src The notebook is automatically: 1. Added to the projectile projects list 2. Detected as type "projectile" (or "git" if git was initialized) 3. Available via `C-c p p

entries.heading: Converting Projects to Notebooks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Convert any existing project into a notebook: #+begin_src 1. Open the project 2. Run: Scimax: New Notebook 3. Choose the project directory as the location  Adds .scimax/ configuration  Project becomes a full notebook with metadata #+end_src The project remains in your projectile list and gains notebook features: - Master file tracking - Collaborator management - Notebook-scoped agenda - Archive capabilities

entries.heading: Notebook Metadata in Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Notebooks store additional metadata in `.scimax/config.json': #+begin_src json { "name": "Research Project", "description": "My research on topic X", "masterFile": "README.org", "collaborators": [ { "name": "Jane Doe", "email": "jane@example.com", "role": "lead" } ], "keywords": ["research", "machine-learning"], "custom": { "grant": "NSF-12345" } } #+end_src This metadata is available to both systems: - Projectile shows the project in its list

entries.heading: Workflow Example: Research Projects
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Typical workflow for managing multiple research projects: #+begin_example # Create notebooks for each research topic Scimax: New Notebook  "ml-experiments" Scimax: New Notebook  "paper-writing" Scimax: New Notebook  "data-analysis" # Each is now in projectile list C-c p p  Shows all three projects # Quick switching between research C-c p p  ml-experiments  open README.org (run experiments, update notes) C-c p p  paper-writing  edit paper.org (write, cite re

entries.heading: Use Consistent Markers
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Choose one marker style per project: - Git projects: Let `.git/' serve as the marker - Non-git projects: Add `.projectile' explicitly - Notebooks: Use notebook creation (adds both `.projectile' and `.scimax/')

entries.heading: Project Naming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Use descriptive, scannable directory names: #+begin_example Good: my-research-project/ client-website-2024/ ml-experiments/ Less good: proj1/ tmp/ stuff/ #+end_example Project names appear in the quick pick list, so clarity helps with quick selection.

entries.heading: Directory Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Organize related projects together: #+begin_example ~/projects/  research/     ml-experiments/     data-analysis/     paper-writing/  work/     client-a/     client-b/  personal/  blog/  dotfiles/ #+end_example Use `Scimax: Scan Directory for Projects' on parent directories to bulk-add.

entries.heading: Quick Switching Pattern
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:14] Develop muscle memory for `C-c p p': #+begin_example C-c p p  type few chars  Enter  choose window option # Takes ~2 seconds to switch projects #+end_example This is faster than: - File  Open Folder  navigate  select - Clicking through GUI menus

entries.heading: Recent Project Access
entries.content: The most recent 3-5 projects appear at the top of the list. Use this for: #+begin_example Morning: Open project A (becomes #1) Afternoon: Switch to project B (becomes #1, A becomes #2) Evening: Back to A (already #2, quick to select) #+end_example

entries.heading: Search Before Switching
entries.content: If you know what file you need: #+begin_example 1. C-c p p  select project 2. C-c p f  find file 3. Start working # Faster than navigating manually #+end_example

entries.heading: Regular Cleanup
entries.content: Run cleanup monthly: #+begin_src Scimax: Cleanup Non-existent Projects #+end_src This prevents clutter from: - Deleted temporary projects - Moved directories - External drive projects (when unmounted)

entries.heading: Curate Your List
entries.content: Remove projects you no longer use: - Old experiments - Completed client work - Temporary test projects A smaller project list means faster selection in `C-c p p'.

entries.heading: Backup Project List
entries.content: The project list is stored in VS Code's global state. To backup: #+begin_src sh # Find VS Code's storage location # Linux: ~/.config/Code/User/globalStorage/ # macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Code/User/globalStorage/ # Windows: %APPDATA%\Code\User\globalStorage\ # Project list is in state.vscdb # Backup this file to preserve project list #+end_src

entries.heading: When to Use Multi-Root
entries.content: Use multi-root workspaces for: - Related projects that share context - Monorepo management - Cross-project refactoring Example: #+begin_example Workspace: "Full Stack App" Folders: - frontend/  (React app) - backend/   (Node API) - shared/    (TypeScript types) Benefits: - Search across all three - Shared settings - Unified git operations #+end_example

entries.heading: When to Use Separate Windows
entries.content: Use separate windows for: - Unrelated projects - Context switching between different work modes - Performance with large projects Example: #+begin_example Window 1: Research project (Jupyter, org files) Window 2: Client website (HTML, CSS, JS) Window 3: Personal blog (Markdown, static site) Benefits: - Mental separation - Independent configurations - Clearer taskbar #+end_example

entries.heading: Custom Project Markers
entries.content: While `.projectile' is the standard marker, you can manually add any directory: #+begin_src Scimax: Add Project  select any folder #+end_src Use this for: - Projects without version control - Shared network directories - Temporary project workspaces

entries.heading: Scanning Large Directories
entries.content: When scanning directories with many subdirectories: #+begin_example Directory: ~/dev/ (contains 100+ repos) Max depth: 1 # Only scans immediate children # Fast, finds top-level projects #+end_example #+begin_example Directory: ~/dev/ Max depth: 3 # Scans deeper # Slower, finds nested projects # Useful for monorepos or organized hierarchies #+end_example Balance depth vs. speed based on your directory structure.

entries.heading: Project Type Prioritization
entries.content: If a directory has multiple markers: #+begin_example my-project/  .git/          # Git marker  .projectile    # Projectile marker Type: git (git takes priority) #+end_example Priority order: 1. `.git/'  type "git" 2. `.projectile'  type "projectile" 3. Manual add  type "manual" This ensures git projects are recognized as such, even if they also have `.projectile' markers.

entries.heading: Programmatic Access
entries.content: Other extensions can access the projectile manager: #+begin_src typescript // Get the projectile manager from extension context const scimaxExt = vscode.extensions.getExtension('scimax.scimax-vscode'); if (scimaxExt?.isActive) { const api = scimaxExt.exports; const projects = api.projectileManager.getProjects(); // Use project list... } #+end_src This enables: - Custom project selection UIs - Integration with external tools - Automated project management

entries.heading: Symptom
entries.content: Project doesn't appear in `C-c p p' list.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Check if directory exists: #+begin_src sh ls -la /path/to/project #+end_src 2. Manually add the project: #+begin_src Scimax: Add Project  select directory #+end_src 3. Check for markers: #+begin_src sh cd /path/to/project ls -la | grep -E '\.git|\.projectile' #+end_src 4. Run cleanup to remove stale entries: #+begin_src Scimax: Cleanup Non-existent Projects #+end_src

entries.heading: Symptom
entries.content: `C-c p p' shows dozens of old projects.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Remove unused projects individually: #+begin_src Scimax: Remove Project  select each #+end_src 2. Clean up non-existent projects: #+begin_src Scimax: Cleanup Non-existent Projects #+end_src 3. Start fresh: #+begin_src # Clear global state (requires extension reload) # Open VS Code settings JSON # Remove scimax.projects entry #+end_src

entries.heading: Symptom
entries.content: Projects tree shows outdated information.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Manual refresh: #+begin_src Scimax: Refresh Projects # Or click refresh icon in tree view toolbar #+end_src 2. Close and reopen sidebar: #+begin_src View  Close Sidebar View  Open View  Scimax Projects #+end_src 3. Reload window: #+begin_src Developer: Reload Window #+end_src

entries.heading: Symptom
entries.content: `Scimax: Scan Directory for Projects' reports "Found 0 projects".

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Increase scan depth: #+begin_example Try depth 2, 3, or 4 #+end_example 2. Check directory structure: #+begin_src sh # Find git repos manually find /path/to/scan -name .git -type d #+end_src 3. Manually add projects: #+begin_src Scimax: Add Project #+end_src 4. Verify permissions: #+begin_src sh # Ensure you have read access to directories ls -la /path/to/scan #+end_src

entries.heading: Symptom
entries.content: `C-c p p' or tree view is slow to load.

entries.heading: Causes & Solutions
entries.content: 1. *Too many projects*: - Remove unused projects - Run cleanup command 2. *Network drives*: - Projects on network shares are slower - Consider removing or using local copies 3. *Deep scanning*: - Reduce max depth when scanning - Use depth 1-2 for most use cases 4. *Large project count*: - Keep project list under 50-100 entries - Archive old projects

entries.heading: Comparison with Emacs Projectile
entries.content: For users familiar with Emacs Projectile:

entries.heading: Similarities
entries.content: | Emacs Projectile           | Scimax VS Code          | Notes                           | |----------------------------+-------------------------+---------------------------------| | =C-c p p= switch           | =C-c p p= switch        | Same keybinding                 | | =C-c p f= find file        | =C-c p f= find file     | Delegates to VS Code picker     | | =C-c p s= search           | =C-c p s= search        | Opens VS Code search panel      | | =.projectile= marker       | =.projectile=

entries.heading: File Finding
entries.content: - *Emacs*: Custom projectile completion - *VS Code*: Uses built-in Quick Open (`C-p') - *Advantage*: VS Code's picker is faster and more familiar

entries.heading: Search
entries.content: - *Emacs*: helm-projectile or ivy integration - *VS Code*: Uses built-in Search panel - *Advantage*: VS Code's search is more visual with inline results

entries.heading: Project Caching
entries.content: - *Emacs*: Caches project file lists - *VS Code*: Uses VS Code's file indexing - *Advantage*: Automatic, no manual cache management

entries.heading: Buffer Management
entries.content: - *Emacs*: `C-c C-p b' switch buffer within project - *VS Code*: Not needed (tabs and Quick Open serve this role)

entries.heading: Project Commands
entries.content: - *Emacs*: Many specialized commands (`C-c C-p c' compile, `C-c C-p t' test) - *VS Code*: Fewer commands, uses VS Code's task system instead

entries.heading: Migration Tips
entries.content: If migrating from Emacs Projectile: 1. *Muscle memory*: Core keybindings (`C-c p p', `C-c p f', `C-c p s') are the same 2. *Markers*: Your `.projectile' files work without changes 3. *Workflows*: File finding and search feel similar but use VS Code UI 4. *Project list*: Use `Scimax: Scan Directory for Projects' to import existing projects 5. *Customization*: VS Code settings replace most projectile variables

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: Projectile settings in VS Code settings (`settings.json'):

entries.heading: No Configuration Required
entries.content: Projectile works out-of-the-box with no configuration. The extension: - Automatically detects current workspace folders - Persists project list in global state - Uses sensible defaults for all operations

entries.heading: Future Configuration Options
entries.content: Potential future settings (not currently implemented): #+begin_src json { // Default depth for scanning directories "scimax.projectile.scanDepth": 2, // Auto-scan directories on startup "scimax.projectile.autoScan": false, // Paths to scan for projects "scimax.projectile.scanPaths": [ "~/projects/", "~/dev/" ], // Max number of recent projects to show "scimax.projectile.maxRecentProjects": 50 } #+end_src Note: These settings are planned but not yet available. Check extension documentation for cu

entries.heading: Conclusion
entries.content: The Scimax projectile system brings Emacs-style project management to VS Code, enabling: - Fast switching between projects with familiar keybindings - Intelligent automatic detection of git repos and marked directories - Project-scoped file finding and text search - Integration with the notebook system for research workflows - Visual project management through the tree view sidebar Whether you're managing multiple research projects, client work, or personal repositories, projectile streamlines y

entries.heading: Next Steps
entries.content: - Create a `.projectile' marker in your important projects - Use `C-c p p' to build muscle memory for project switching - Scan your development directory to populate the project list - Explore integration with notebooks for research projects - Set up keybindings for your most-used projectile commands
