entries.content: If you encounter issues or have feature requests for projectile: - GitHub Issues: [[https://github.com/your-repo/scimax-vscode/issues]] - Discussion: [[https://github.com/your-repo/scimax-vscode/discussions]]

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:16-notebook.org][Notebook]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:18-database-search.org][Database and Search]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] Scimax VS Code includes a powerful database and search system that indexes your org, markdown, and Jupyter notebook files. The database provides: - *Full-text search* with FTS5 (SQLite's Full-Text Search) and BM25 ranking - *Semantic search* using vector embeddings for meaning-based queries - *Hybrid search* combining keyword and semantic approaches - *Advanced search* with query expansion, weighted RRF, and LLM reranking (SOTA) - *Structured queries* for headings,

entries.heading: File Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] The database automatically indexes three types of files: - `.org' files - Org-mode documents - `.md' files - Markdown documents - `.ipynb' files - Jupyter notebooks

entries.heading: Indexed Content
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] For each file, the database extracts and indexes:

entries.heading: Headings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] - Heading text and level (*, **, ***, etc.) - TODO states (TODO, DONE, IN-PROGRESS, etc.) - Priority markers ([#A], [#B], [#C]) - Tags (both direct and inherited) - Properties (CUSTOM_ID, CATEGORY, etc.) - Scheduling information (SCHEDULED, DEADLINE, CLOSED) - Line numbers for navigation

entries.heading: Source Blocks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] - Programming language - Complete code content - Header arguments (`:results', `:exports', etc.) - Line numbers - For notebooks: cell indices

entries.heading: Links
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] - Link type (file, http, https, id, etc.) - Target path or URL - Optional description text - Line number

entries.heading: Hashtags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] - Inline hashtags (e.g., #research, #todo) - Associated file paths

entries.heading: Full Text
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:45] - Complete document content for full-text search - Indexed with FTS5 virtual tables - Porter stemming and Unicode normalization Here is a hashtag #FullTextSearch

entries.heading: Text Chunks (for Semantic Search)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:46] - Document divided into ~2000 character chunks - 3-line overlap between chunks for context - Vector embeddings (if embedding service configured) - Line ranges for each chunk

entries.heading: File Watching
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:43] The database automatically watches for file changes: - New files are indexed when created - Modified files are re-indexed (debounced with 500ms delay) - Deleted files are removed from the index - Changes are queued and processed sequentially

entries.heading: Ignore Patterns
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:46] By default, the following patterns are ignored: - `**/node_modules/**' - `**/.git/**' - `**/dist/**' - `**/build/**' - `**/.ipynb_checkpoints/**' Configure additional patterns in settings: =scimax.db.exclude= [[cmd:workbench.action.openSettings2]] [[cmd:workbench.action.openSettings2?@scimax][Open Scimax Settings]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:46] Full-text search uses SQLite's FTS5 (Full-Text Search version 5) with: - *BM25 ranking* - Industry-standard relevance scoring - *Porter stemming* - Matches word variations (e.g., "run" matches "running") - *Unicode normalization* - Handles accented characters correctly - *Snippet generation* - Shows matching context with highlighting

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:49] Run `Scimax: Search All Files (FTS5)' or use command `scimax.db.search' [[cmd:scimax.db.search]]

entries.heading: Query Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:49] FTS5 supports rich query syntax:

entries.heading: Basic Queries
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:49] #+BEGIN_SRC org machine learning          # Match both words (in any order) "machine learning"        # Match exact phrase neural OR artificial      # Match either word #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Boolean Operators
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org python AND jupyter        # Must contain both python NOT tensorflow     # Contains python but not tensorflow deep OR machine learning  # Contains "deep" or the phrase "machine learning" #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Prefix Matching
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org comput*                   # Matches: computer, computing, computation data*                     # Matches: data, database, dataset #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Column Queries
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org title: introduction       # Search only in titles content: python           # Search only in content #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Proximity Queries
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org NEAR(neural network, 5)   # Words within 5 tokens of each other #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Results
entries.content: Search results include: - File path and basename - Line number - Preview snippet with `<mark>' tags highlighting matches - BM25 relevance score - Up to 100 results (configurable)

entries.heading: Example Searches
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org # Find all references to "gradient descent" gradient descent # Find Python-related TODO items TODO python # Find documents about data science or machine learning "data science" OR "machine learning" # Find recent mentions of TensorFlow (excluding Keras) tensorflow NOT keras # Find all documents with "introduction" in title title: introduction #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:55] Semantic search finds content by *meaning* rather than exact words. It uses vector embeddings to represent text in a high-dimensional space where semantically similar content is close together. Benefits: - Find content even when using different words - Discover related concepts - More natural query language Example: Searching for "machine learning algorithms" will also find documents about "neural networks", "deep learning models", and "classification methods" even

entries.heading: Requirements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:58] Semantic search requires: 1. *Vector search support in libsql* - The database must support vector operations 2. *Embedding provider configured* - Ollama must be running locally 3. *Files indexed with embeddings* - Run `scimax.db.reindex' after configuring

entries.heading: Checking Availability
entries.content: Run `Scimax: Show Database Stats' (`scimax.db.stats') to see: - Whether vector search is supported - Number of embeddings stored - Any error messages If vector search is unavailable, the stats will show: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE Semantic search: Unavailable (vector search not supported) #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Fallback to Full-Text Search
entries.content: If semantic search is unavailable, use full-text search (`scimax.db.search') instead. FTS5 is always available and very fast for keyword-based queries.

entries.heading: Embedding Provider
entries.content: Scimax uses Ollama for embeddings:

entries.heading: Ollama
entries.content: - *Pros*: Free, private, local control, high quality - *Cons*: Requires Ollama installed and running - *Models*: - `nomic-embed-text' (768 dims, recommended) - `all-minilm' (384 dims, smaller) - `mxbai-embed-large' (1024 dims, larger) - *Setup*: Install Ollama, then `ollama pull nomic-embed-text'

entries.heading: Interactive Setup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:59] Run `Scimax: Configure Embedding Service' (`scimax.db.configureEmbeddings') This wizard will: 1. Let you choose a provider 2. Select a model 3. Test the connection 4. Update your settings 5. Prompt you to reindex files

entries.heading: Manual Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 11:59] Add to your VS Code settings (`settings.json'):

entries.heading: Ollama Configuration
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.embeddingProvider": "ollama", "scimax.db.ollamaUrl": "http://localhost:11434", "scimax.db.ollamaModel": "nomic-embed-text" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:01] Run `Scimax: Semantic Search' or use command `scimax.db.searchSemantic'

entries.heading: Query Examples
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:01] Semantic search uses natural language: #+BEGIN_SRC org # Conceptual searches explain neural network architecture how to optimize database queries project management best practices # Related concept discovery clustering algorithms    # Finds: k-means, hierarchical, DBSCAN data visualization       # Finds: matplotlib, charts, plots, graphs # Question answering what is gradient descent how does attention mechanism work #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Results
entries.content: Results include: - File path and line number - Preview (first 200 characters of chunk) - Similarity score (0-100%, higher is more relevant) - Cosine distance (lower is more similar) - Up to 20 results by default

entries.heading: Reindexing for Semantic Search
entries.content: After configuring an embedding provider, you *must reindex* your files: 1. Run `Scimax: Reindex Files' (`scimax.db.reindex') 2. Wait for indexing to complete 3. The database will generate embeddings for all text chunks 4. Semantic search will now be available

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: Hybrid search combines full-text (keyword) and semantic (vector) search using *Reciprocal Rank Fusion* (RRF). This approach: - Gets the best of both worlds - Balances exact matches with conceptual similarity - Provides more robust results

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: Run `Scimax: Hybrid Search' or use command `scimax.db.searchHybrid'

entries.heading: How It Works
entries.content: 1. Query runs through both FTS5 and vector search 2. Results from each are ranked 3. RRF algorithm combines rankings: - Higher rank in either search boosts result - Results appearing in both searches rank highest 4. Final results sorted by combined score

entries.heading: Weights
entries.content: Default weights are 50/50, but can be adjusted: #+BEGIN_SRC typescript // Internal API (for extension developers) db.searchHybrid(query, { limit: 20, ftsWeight: 0.5,      // 50% weight on keywords vectorWeight: 0.5    // 50% weight on semantics }); #+END_SRC

entries.heading: When to Use Hybrid
entries.content: - Default choice for general searches - When you want both exact matches and related concepts - When query has both specific terms and broad concepts - Example: "python sklearn classification accuracy" - finds both sklearn-specific code and general ML accuracy discussions

entries.heading: Results
entries.content: Results include: - Combined ranking score - Source indicator (Keywords, AI, or both) - File location and preview - Up to 20 results

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: Advanced search implements a state-of-the-art (SOTA) search pipeline inspired by modern search engines like [[https://github.com/tobi/qmd][qmd]]. It combines multiple techniques for maximum recall and precision: 1. *Query Expansion* - Generates alternative query formulations 2. *Parallel Retrieval* - Runs FTS5 and vector search concurrently 3. *Weighted Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF)* - Combines results intelligently 4. *LLM Reranking* - Uses AI to improve final ranking (optional)

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: Run =Scimax: Advanced Search= ([[cmd:scimax.db.searchAdvanced]])

entries.heading: When to Use
entries.content: - Complex research queries - When you want maximum recall - When hybrid search isn't finding relevant content - For important searches where accuracy matters more than speed

entries.heading: Query Expansion
entries.content: Query expansion improves recall by generating alternative formulations of your query.

entries.heading: Pseudo-Relevance Feedback (PRF)
entries.content: *No LLM required* - Analyzes top results to find related terms. How it works: 1. Runs initial search with original query 2. Extracts key terms from top 5 results 3. Creates expanded query with additional terms 4. Searches again with expanded query Example: #+BEGIN_SRC org Original: "machine learning" Expanded: "machine learning neural network training models" #+END_SRC

entries.heading: LLM Query Expansion
entries.content: *Requires Ollama* - Uses a language model to generate query variants. How it works: 1. Sends query to LLM (e.g., qwen3:1.7b) 2. LLM generates 3 alternative phrasings 3. All variants searched in parallel 4. Original query gets 2 weight in ranking Example: #+BEGIN_SRC org Original: "database optimization" Variants: - "improve SQL query performance" - "speed up database queries" - "index tuning for databases" #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Weighted RRF
entries.content: Standard RRF assigns scores based on rank position. Advanced search enhances this with:

entries.heading: Position Bonuses
entries.content: Top-ranked results get bonuses: - Rank 1: +15% bonus - Rank 2: +10% bonus - Rank 3: +5% bonus

entries.heading: Original Query Weight
entries.content: The original query's results receive 2 weight compared to expanded query results.

entries.heading: Score Normalization
entries.content: Different backends produce different score ranges: - BM25: Negative values (normalized to 0-1) - Vector: Cosine distance (converted to similarity) - All scores normalized before fusion

entries.heading: LLM Reranking
entries.content: *Requires Ollama* - Uses AI to score relevance after initial retrieval.

entries.heading: How It Works
entries.content: 1. Takes top 30 candidates from RRF fusion 2. LLM scores each document's relevance (0-10) 3. Scores blended with retrieval scores using position-aware weights

entries.heading: Position-Aware Blending
entries.content: High-confidence retrieval matches are preserved: - Ranks 1-3: 75% retrieval, 25% reranker - Ranks 4-10: 60% retrieval, 40% reranker - Ranks 11+: 40% retrieval, 60% reranker

entries.heading: Performance Considerations
entries.content: Reranking adds latency (~1-2 seconds for 30 documents). Disable for fast searches.

entries.heading: Capabilities Check
entries.content: Run =Scimax: Show Search Capabilities= (=scimax.db.searchCapabilities=) to see: #+BEGIN_SRC org  Full-Text Search (FTS5/BM25) - Available  Semantic/Vector Search - Available (Ollama)  Query Expansion (PRF) - Available (no LLM required)  Query Expansion (LLM) - Unavailable - check Ollama  LLM Reranking - Unavailable - pull qwen3:0.6b #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Graceful Degradation
entries.content: Advanced search works without all features: | If Unavailable | Fallback | |----------------+----------| | Vector search  | FTS-only | | LLM expansion  | PRF-only | | Reranking      | Skip reranking | | All LLM features | Equivalent to hybrid search |

entries.heading: Search Mode
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.defaultMode": "hybrid",  // or "fast", "semantic", "advanced" "scimax.search.defaultLimit": 20 } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Query Expansion
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.queryExpansion.enabled": true, "scimax.search.queryExpansion.method": "prf",  // or "llm", "both" "scimax.search.queryExpansion.prfTopK": 5, "scimax.search.queryExpansion.prfTermCount": 5, "scimax.search.queryExpansion.llmModel": "qwen3:1.7b" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Reranking
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.reranking.enabled": false,  // Enable for better accuracy "scimax.search.reranking.model": "qwen3:0.6b", "scimax.search.reranking.topK": 30, "scimax.search.reranking.usePositionBlending": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Hybrid Weights
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.hybrid.ftsWeight": 0.5, "scimax.search.hybrid.vectorWeight": 0.5, "scimax.search.hybrid.usePositionBonus": true, "scimax.search.hybrid.k": 60  // RRF constant } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Caching
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.caching.enabled": true, "scimax.search.caching.ttlSeconds": 900,  // 15 minutes "scimax.search.caching.maxEntries": 500 } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Setting Up LLM Features
entries.content: To enable query expansion and reranking with Ollama: 1. Install Ollama: https://ollama.ai 2. Start Ollama: =ollama serve= 3. Pull models: #+BEGIN_SRC bash ollama pull qwen3:1.7b   # For query expansion ollama pull qwen3:0.6b   # For reranking #+END_SRC 4. Enable in settings: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.search.queryExpansion.method": "both", "scimax.search.reranking.enabled": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Performance Comparison
entries.content: | Mode     | Speed    | Recall | Precision | When to Use | |----------+----------+--------+-----------+-------------| | Fast     | <50ms    | Low    | High      | Exact matches | | Semantic | ~200ms   | High   | Medium    | Conceptual queries | | Hybrid   | ~300ms   | High   | High      | General purpose | | Advanced | 1-3s     | Highest| Highest   | Important searches |

entries.content: Command: `Scimax: Reindex Files' (`scimax.db.reindex'). [[cmd:scimax.db.reindex]] - Scans all workspace folders - Checks file modification times - Only reindexes changed files - Shows progress notification - Reports statistics on completion

entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:08] #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.autoIndex": true } #+END_SRC Warning: Disable for very large workspaces (>10,000 files) to prevent memory issues.

entries.heading: Indexing Sources
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:43] By default, the database indexes: - Journal directory (=scimax.db.includeJournal: true=) - Workspace folders (=scimax.db.includeWorkspace: true=) - Scimax projects (=scimax.db.includeProjects: true=) Add additional directories with =scimax.db.include=: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.include": [ "/home/user/research", "/home/user/notes", "~/Documents/org" ] } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:08] `Scimax: Optimize Database' (`scimax.db.optimize'). [[cmd:scimax.db.optimize]]

entries.heading: Operations
entries.content: - Removes entries for deleted files - Runs VACUUM to reclaim space - Rebuilds indexes for performance - Should be run periodically (monthly)

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: `Scimax: Clear Database' (`scimax.db.clear')

entries.heading: Warning
entries.content: This is destructive and requires confirmation: - Removes all indexed data - Clears embeddings - Resets statistics - Requires full reindex to restore

entries.heading: When to Clear
entries.content: - Database corruption - Major schema changes - Troubleshooting issues - Fresh start needed

entries.heading: Command
entries.content: `Scimax: Show Database Stats' (`scimax.db.stats')

entries.heading: Information Displayed
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org Scimax DB: 127 files (98 org, 23 md, 6 ipynb), 1,234 headings, 456 code blocks, 789 links. Semantic search: Enabled (243 chunks). Last indexed: 2026-01-13 14:30:00 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Stats Include
entries.content: - File count by type - Heading count - Code block count - Link count - Chunk count (for semantic search) - Embedding status - Last index timestamp

entries.heading: File Size
entries.content: - Small files (<100KB): ~10-50ms - Medium files (100KB-1MB): ~50-200ms - Large files (>1MB): ~200ms-1s

entries.heading: Batch Indexing
entries.content: - 100 small files: ~2-5 seconds - 1,000 small files: ~20-60 seconds - With embeddings: 2-5x slower

entries.heading: Optimization Tips
entries.content: 1. Use ignore patterns for large non-content directories 2. Disable auto-indexing for huge workspaces 3. Index incrementally (only changed files) 4. Run optimization monthly

entries.heading: Full-Text Search (FTS5)
entries.content: - Query time: 10-50ms (typical) - Scales well to 10,000+ files - BM25 scoring is highly optimized - Results returned in rank order

entries.heading: Semantic Search
entries.content: - Query time: 50-500ms depending on provider - Local embeddings: slower but private - Ollama: moderate speed - OpenAI: fastest but requires network

entries.heading: Hybrid Search
entries.content: - Query time: Combined FTS + vector time - Typically 100-600ms - Runs searches in parallel - RRF fusion adds ~10ms

entries.heading: Typical Sizes
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org 100 files:      ~5-10 MB 1,000 files:    ~50-100 MB 10,000 files:   ~500 MB-1 GB #+END_SRC

entries.heading: With Embeddings
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org +50-100% size increase for chunks and vectors 384-dim embeddings: ~1.5 KB per chunk 768-dim embeddings: ~3 KB per chunk 1536-dim embeddings: ~6 KB per chunk #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Indexing
entries.content: - Base: ~50-100 MB - Peak during large batch: ~200-500 MB - Embedding generation: +100-300 MB

entries.heading: Searching
entries.content: - FTS5: ~10-50 MB - Vector search: ~50-200 MB (loads embeddings) - Minimal memory footprint when idle

entries.heading: Small Workspace (<100 files)
entries.content: - Enable auto-indexing - Use any embedding provider - Full reindex in seconds

entries.heading: Medium Workspace (100-1,000 files)
entries.content: - Enable auto-indexing - Local or Ollama embeddings recommended - Full reindex in under a minute

entries.heading: Large Workspace (1,000-10,000 files)
entries.content: - Consider disabling auto-indexing - Ollama embeddings recommended - Reindex incrementally

entries.heading: Very Large Workspace (>10,000 files)
entries.content: - Disable auto-indexing (manual reindex) - Use selective directory indexing - Consider multiple smaller databases - Ollama with a fast model recommended

entries.heading: =scimax.db.includeJournal=
entries.content: Type: =boolean= Default: =true= Include journal directory in database indexing.

entries.heading: =scimax.db.includeWorkspace=
entries.content: Type: =boolean= Default: =true= Include workspace folders in database indexing.

entries.heading: =scimax.db.includeProjects=
entries.content: Type: =boolean= Default: =true= Include all scimax projects in database indexing.

entries.heading: =scimax.db.include=
entries.content: Type: =string[]= Default: =[]= Additional directories or files to index (supports ~ for home directory). #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.include": [ "/home/user/notes", "~/Documents/research" ] } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: =scimax.db.exclude=
entries.content: Type: =string[]= Default: =["**/node_modules/**", "**/.git/**", "**/dist/**", "**/build/**"]= Patterns or paths to exclude from indexing (globs and absolute paths). #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.exclude": [ "**/node_modules/**", "**/.git/**", "**/dist/**", "**/temp/**", "**/*.backup.org", "~/notes/scratch.org" ] } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: `scimax.db.autoIndex'
entries.content: Type: `boolean' Default: `false' Automatically index workspace on activation. Disable for large workspaces. #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.autoIndex": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: `scimax.db.embeddingProvider'
entries.content: Type: `enum' Values: "none" | "ollama" Default: `"ollama"' Embedding provider for semantic search. #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.embeddingProvider": "ollama" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: `scimax.db.ollamaUrl'
entries.content: Type: `string' Default: `"http://localhost:11434"' Ollama server URL. #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.ollamaUrl": "http://localhost:11434" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: `scimax.db.ollamaModel'
entries.content: Type: `string' Default: `"nomic-embed-text"' Ollama embedding model name. #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.db.ollamaModel": "nomic-embed-text" } #+END_SRC

entries.content: | Command                       | Description                 | |-------------------------------+-----------------------------| | scimax.db.reindex             | Reindex all files           | | scimax.db.optimize            | Optimize database           | | scimax.db.clear               | Clear database              | | scimax.db.stats               | Show database statistics    | | scimax.db.setScope            | Set search scope            | | scimax.db.configureEmbeddings | Configure embeddin

entries.heading: Backup and Restore
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:17] The database can be backed up and restored to prevent data loss and enable migration between machines.

entries.heading: Backup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:17] Command: =Scimax: Backup Database= (=scimax.db.backup=) Creates a portable backup file containing: - All indexed file paths (not file contents) - Project information - Database metadata Backup is stored in JSON format for portability. #+BEGIN_SRC org # Example backup location ~/.scimax/backup-2026-01-22.json #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Restore
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:17] Command: =Scimax: Restore Database= (=scimax.db.restore=) Restores database from a backup file: - Imports project list - Queues files for reindexing - Preserves original creation timestamps Note: Actual file content must still be reindexed after restore.

entries.heading: Database Rebuild
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:17] Command: =Scimax: Rebuild Database= (=scimax.db.rebuild=) Completely rebuilds the database from scratch: - Drops and recreates all tables - Re-scans all configured directories - Regenerates all indexes - Regenerates embeddings (if configured) Use when: - Database appears corrupted - Major schema changes after update - Switching embedding providers - Performance issues after many incremental updates

entries.heading: Options
entries.content: | Option        | Description                          | |---------------+--------------------------------------| | Full rebuild  | Complete reindex of all files        | | Projects only | Only rebuild project table           |

entries.heading: Database Verification
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:18] Command: =Scimax: Verify Database= (=scimax.db.verify=) Checks database integrity and freshness:

entries.heading: Checks Performed
entries.content: 1. *File existence* - Verifies indexed files still exist on disk 2. *Modification time* - Detects files modified since indexing 3. *Index integrity* - Validates FTS5 and vector indexes 4. *Project validity* - Checks project directories exist

entries.heading: Result Format
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org Database Verification Results: - Total files: 127 - Missing files: 2 - Stale files: 5 - Projects: 8 (7 valid, 1 missing) - Status: NEEDS_REINDEX #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Status Values
entries.content: | Status       | Meaning                          | |--------------+----------------------------------| | OK           | Database is current and valid    | | NEEDS_REINDEX| Some files are stale or missing | | CORRUPTED    | Index integrity check failed     |

entries.heading: Project Integration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:44] The database now stores project information, integrated with the Projectile project manager:

entries.heading: Benefits
entries.content: - Projects persist across VS Code restarts - Shared project list between Projectile and Database - Fast project switching using indexed data - Projects can be associated with indexed files

entries.heading: Project Commands
entries.content: Projects are managed through Projectile commands (=C-c p=), but the database provides the persistence layer. See [[file:17-projectile.org][Projectile]] for project management commands.

entries.heading: Problem
entries.content: Semantic search returns no results, shows "unavailable", or displays an error.

entries.heading: First: Check Vector Search Support
entries.content: Run `Scimax: Show Database Stats' (`scimax.db.stats') to see the semantic search status: | Status Message                         | Meaning                                 | |----------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------| | Semantic search: Enabled (N chunks)    | Working, N chunks with embeddings       | | Semantic search: Ready (no embeddings) | Supported, but no provider configured   | | Semantic search: Unavailable (error)   | Vector search not supported

entries.heading: Vector Search Unavailable
entries.content: If you see "Semantic search: Unavailable", the libsql database doesn't support vector operations. This can happen if: - The libsql version doesn't include vector support - The vector index failed to create *Workaround*: Use full-text search (`scimax.db.search') instead. FTS5 is always available and fast.

entries.heading: Embedding Provider Issues
entries.content: If vector search is supported but not working: 1. Check embedding provider is configured: `scimax.db.embeddingProvider' 2. Test connection: Run `Scimax: Configure Embedding Service' 3. Ensure files are reindexed after configuring embeddings 4. Check console for errors (`Help: Toggle Developer Tools')

entries.heading: Local Provider Issues
entries.content: - First use downloads model (~30MB), wait for completion - Check extension cache directory has write permissions - Try different model if one fails

entries.heading: Ollama Issues
entries.content: - Ensure Ollama is running: `ollama serve' - Pull model: `ollama pull nomic-embed-text' - Check URL is correct in settings - Test connection: `curl http://localhost:11434/api/embeddings'

entries.heading: Problem
entries.content: Searches return empty results despite having files.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Run `Scimax: Show Database Stats' to check file count 2. If files ` 0, run 'Scimax: Reindex Files 3. Check file extensions (.org, .md, .ipynb) 4. Verify files aren't in ignored directories 5. Check search scope is set to "All files"

entries.heading: Problem
entries.content: Indexing takes very long or appears stuck.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Check workspace size (number of files) 2. Add ignore patterns for large non-content directories 3. Disable embedding generation if not needed 4. Index directories incrementally 5. Check disk I/O and available memory

entries.heading: Problem
entries.content: Errors mentioning "database is locked" or "disk I/O error".

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Close other VS Code windows accessing same workspace 2. Restart VS Code 3. Run `Scimax: Clear Database' and reindex 4. Check disk space is available 5. Verify database file permissions

entries.heading: Problem
entries.content: VS Code uses excessive memory during indexing or searching.

entries.heading: Solutions
entries.content: 1. Disable auto-indexing 2. Reduce number of indexed directories 3. Use more aggressive ignore patterns 4. Clear and reindex database 5. Restart VS Code between large indexing operations

entries.heading: Code Snippet Library
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org # Store reusable code blocks ,* Data Processing Utils ,#+BEGIN_SRC python def normalize_data(df): """Normalize numeric columns""" return (df - df.mean()) / df.std() ,#+END_SRC # Search code blocks Language: python Query: normalize # Or semantic search how to standardize dataframe columns #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Personal Knowledge Base
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org # Use hybrid search for discovery Query: "improve code performance" Results will include: - Exact matches: "code performance" articles - Related concepts: optimization, profiling, caching - Similar topics: algorithm efficiency, memory management # Use properties for metadata :PROPERTIES: :CREATED: [2026-01-13 Mon 10:00] :MODIFIED: [2026-01-13 Mon 15:30] :CATEGORY: programming :END: #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Indexing Strategy
entries.content: 1. *Start selective* - Index specific directories first 2. *Use ignore patterns* - Exclude build artifacts and dependencies 3. *Index incrementally* - Don't reindex everything on changes 4. *Schedule optimization* - Run monthly for large databases 5. *Monitor statistics* - Check file counts and sizes regularly

entries.heading: Search Strategy
entries.content: 1. *Start broad* - Use semantic or hybrid search for exploration 2. *Refine with keywords* - Switch to FTS for specific terms 3. *Use structured queries* - Filter by tags/properties when possible 4. *Set scope appropriately* - Narrow to directories for focused work 5. *Combine approaches* - Use multiple search types for thorough research

entries.heading: Organization Tips
entries.content: 1. *Use consistent tags* - Establish tag naming conventions 2. *Add properties* - Include metadata for filtering 3. *Set schedules* - Use SCHEDULED/DEADLINE for time management 4. *Include hashtags* - Quick inline categorization 5. *Write descriptive headings* - Better search results

entries.heading: Performance Tips
entries.content: 1. *Disable auto-indexing* - For large workspaces (manual trigger) 2. *Choose appropriate embeddings* - Balance quality vs. speed 3. *Limit result counts* - Don't request thousands of results 4. *Use search scope* - Narrow searches to relevant directories 5. *Cache frequent queries* - Database has 15-minute result cache

entries.heading: Files Table
entries.content: Tracks indexed files with modification tracking: - `path', `file_type', `mtime', `hash', `size', `indexed_at'

entries.heading: Headings Table
entries.content: Org/markdown headings with full metadata: - `level', `title', `todo_state', `priority' - `tags', `inherited_tags', `properties' - `scheduled', `deadline', `closed' - `line_number', `begin_pos'

entries.heading: Source Blocks Table
entries.content: Code blocks with language and content: - `language', `content', `headers' - `line_number', `cell_index'

entries.heading: Links Table
entries.content: All link types (file, http, id, etc.): - `link_type', `target', `description' - `line_number'

entries.heading: Hashtags Table
entries.content: Inline hashtags: - `tag', `file_path'

entries.heading: Chunks Table
entries.content: Text chunks for semantic search: - `content', `line_start', `line_end' - `embedding' (F32_BLOB vector)

entries.heading: FTS Content (Virtual Table)
entries.content: Full-text search index: - `file_path', `title', `content' - Porter stemming, Unicode normalization - BM25 ranking support

entries.heading: Indexes
entries.content: Performance indexes on: - `headings.file_id', `headings.todo_state' - `headings.deadline', `headings.scheduled' - `source_blocks.language' - `hashtags.tag' - `chunks.embedding' (vector index with cosine metric) - `files.file_type'

entries.heading: Vector Search
entries.content: Using libsql's vector extension: - Cosine similarity metric - F32_BLOB storage format - HNSW-like index structure - Efficient nearest neighbor queries

entries.heading: Org Mode
entries.content: `UnifiedParserAdapter' - Full AST parser compatible with org-element: - Recursive heading parsing with inheritance - Property drawer extraction - Timestamp parsing (scheduled, deadline, closed) - Source block with headers - Link extraction

entries.heading: Markdown
entries.content: Simplified parser: - ATX heading syntax (`#') - Fenced code blocks - Inline links

entries.heading: Jupyter Notebooks
entries.content: `ipynbParser' - Notebook-specific parser: - Markdown cells  headings and links - Code cells  source blocks - Cell indices tracked for navigation - Hashtags from markdown cells

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:07] Scimax VS Code provides comprehensive bibliography and citation management inspired by Emacs org-ref. This system allows you to: - Manage BibTeX bibliography files - Insert and format citations in multiple styles - Follow citation links to PDFs, URLs, and notes - Search and browse your reference library - Export citations to various formats - Integrate with CrossRef and OpenAlex for metadata The reference system seamlessly integrates with org-mode documents while a

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: Configure your default bibliography files in VS Code settings (Preferences: Open Settings (UI)  search for "scimax ref"): | Setting                      | Description                                 | |------------------------------+---------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.bibliographyFiles | Array of .bib file paths (global)           | | scimax.ref.pdfDirectory      | Directory containing PDF files              | | scimax.ref.notesDirectory    | Directory for reference note

entries.heading: Example Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:07] :PROPERTIES: :ID: c95c70d9-14b9-484a-9657-1bf847387e30 :END: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.ref.bibliographyFiles": [ "~/Documents/references.bib", "~/research/bibliography.bib" ], "scimax.ref.pdfDirectory": "~/Documents/papers/", "scimax.ref.notesDirectory": "~/Documents/notes/", "scimax.ref.defaultCiteStyle": "cite" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Document-Local Bibliography Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:07] You can specify bibliography files per document using:

entries.heading: Bibliography Links
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:08] #+BEGIN_SRC org bibliography:~/Documents/refs.bib bibliography:./local-refs.bib,~/global-refs.bib #+END_SRC Multiple files are comma-separated. Paths can be: - Absolute: /path/to/file.bib - Home-relative: ~/Documents/refs.bib - Document-relative: ./refs.bib or ../shared/refs.bib

entries.heading: Bibliography Keywords
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:08] Alternative org-mode syntax: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+BIBLIOGRAPHY: ~/Documents/references.bib #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Workspace Bibliography Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:08] The extension automatically discovers all .bib files in your workspace and makes them available for citation completion.

entries.heading: Creating a Bibliography File
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:08] Create a new .bib file manually or use the command: - [[cmd:scimax.ref.openBibliography]] - Opens bibliography file or creates new one Basic BibTeX entry structure: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{smith2024machine, author = {Smith, John and Doe, Jane}, title = {Machine Learning for Scientific Computing}, journal = {Journal of Computational Science}, year = {2024}, volume = {15}, number = {3}, pages = {123--145}, doi = {10.1000/jcs.2024.0001} } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Citation Link Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:08] Scimax VS Code supports multiple citation styles for different contexts:

entries.heading: Citation Styles
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:09] | Style      | Syntax         | Rendered As (typical) | Use Case               | |------------+----------------+-----------------------+------------------------| | cite       | cite:key       | [1] or (Smith, 2024)  | Basic citation         | | citet      | citet:key      | Smith (2024)          | Textual citation       | | citep      | citep:key      | (Smith, 2024)         | Parenthetical citation | | citeauthor | citeauthor:key | Smith                 | Author n

entries.heading: Multiple Citations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 10:15] Cite multiple sources by separating keys with commas or semicolons: cite:kitchin-2015-examp-effec,kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt          # Version 2 cite:&kitchin-2015-examp-effec;&kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt        # Version 3

entries.heading: Citation Formats by File Type
entries.content: Citations adapt to your document format:

entries.heading: Org-Mode Format
entries.content: in scimax the preferred org-mode citation syntax is org-ref v3L cite:&kitchin-2015-examp-effec citet:&kitchin-2015-examp-effec;&kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt citep:&kitchin-2015-examp-effec;&kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt

entries.heading: Markdown/Pandoc Format
entries.content: The insert citation command generates Pandoc-style citations in Markdown files: #+BEGIN_SRC markdown [@kitchin-2015-examp-effec] [@kitchin-2015-examp-effec, p. 42] [see @kitchin-2015-examp-effec; also @kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt] #+END_SRC

entries.heading: LaTeX Format
entries.content: For LaTeX documents, citations use standard LaTeX commands: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \cite{kitchin-2015-examp-effec} \citet{kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt} \citep{kitchin-2015-examp-effec,kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Org-Mode 9.5+ Citation Syntax
entries.content: Modern org-mode citation syntax is also supported: #+BEGIN_SRC org [cite:@kitchin-2015-examp-effec] [cite/t:@kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt] [cite/p:@kitchin-2015-examp-effec;@kitchin-2025-beyon-fourt] #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Insert Citation Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:14] | Key   | Command                                     | |-------+---------------------------------------------| | C-c ] | Insert citation (scimax.ref.insertCitation) |

entries.heading: Interactive Citation Insertion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:16] 1. Press C-c ] or run command [[cmd:scimax.ref.insertCitation]] 2. Search and select a reference (searches key, author, title, year) 3. Choose citation style (cite, citet, citep, citeauthor, citeyear) 4. Citation is inserted at cursor

entries.heading: Appending to Existing Citations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:16] When cursor is on an existing citation: 1. Press C-c ] 2. Select additional reference 3. Key is automatically appended: cite:key1,key2 The command detects when you're on a citation and adds the new key to the list.

entries.heading: Citation Completion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:16] Auto-completion triggers after typing: - cite: (org-mode) - @ (Markdown/Pandoc) - \cite{ (LaTeX) Completion shows: - Citation key - Author and year - Full formatted citation on hover

entries.heading: Quick Citation Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:16] #+NAME: quick-cite-commands | Command                       |           | Description                           | |-------------------------------+-----------+---------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.insertCitation     | C-c - ]   | Insert/append citation                | | scimax.ref.insertRef          | C-u C-c ] | Insert cross-reference (ref:, eqref:) | | scimax.ref.insertBibliography |           | Insert bibliography link              |

entries.heading: Insert from Zotero
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] Scimax can insert citations directly from your Zotero library using the Better BibTeX plugin. This provides seamless integration between your Zotero reference manager and org-mode documents.

entries.heading: Requirements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] To use Zotero integration, you need: 1. *Zotero desktop application* - Must be running when inserting citations 2. *Better BibTeX plugin* - Install from https://retorque.re/zotero-better-bibtex/ Better BibTeX provides the local API that Scimax uses to communicate with Zotero.

entries.heading: Usage
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] | Keybinding | Command                      | Description                 | |------------+------------------------------+-----------------------------| | C-c z      | scimax.zotero.insertCitation | Insert citation from Zotero |

entries.heading: Workflow
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] 1. Press =C-c z= in an org, markdown, or LaTeX file 2. Zotero's native citation picker opens (you may need to switch to the Zotero window) 3. Search and select one or more references 4. Click "OK" or press Enter to confirm your selection 5. The citation is inserted at the cursor position 6. The BibTeX entry is automatically added to your bibliography file

entries.heading: Bibliography File Handling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] When inserting from Zotero, the extension intelligently manages your bibliography file: | Scenario                                    | Behavior                                           | |---------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------| | Document has =bibliography:= link           | Uses that file                                     | | No link, but =references.bib= exists in dir | Asks if you want to use it

entries.heading: Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] Before (no bibliography): #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* My Research Paper Some text discussing machine learning. #+END_SRC After pressing =C-c z= and selecting a reference: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,* My Research Paper Some text discussing machine learning cite:&smith2024machine. bibliography:./references.bib #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Troubleshooting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 11:44] | Problem                        | Solution                                              | |--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------| | "Zotero is not running"        | Start Zotero desktop application                      | | Picker doesn't appear          | Switch to Zotero window; it may be behind VS Code     | | "Failed to fetch BibTeX"       | Ensure Better BibTeX is installed and enabled         | | Wrong citati

entries.heading: Citation Link Actions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:19] Click on a citation or press C-c C-o on a citation to open an action menu:

entries.heading: For Known Citations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:19] | Action                  | Description                                    | |-------------------------+------------------------------------------------| | Open BibTeX Entry       | Jump to entry in .bib file                     | | Open DOI                | Open DOI URL in browser                        | | Open URL                | Open entry's URL field in browser              | | Open PDF                | Open PDF file if available                     | | Open/

entries.heading: For Unknown Citations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:19] If citation key is not found in bibliography: | Action                  | Description                                    | |-------------------------+------------------------------------------------| | Search Google Scholar   | Search for the key on Google Scholar           | | Search CrossRef         | Search CrossRef database                       | | Add from DOI            | Fetch BibTeX from DOI                          | | Copy Key                | Copy citat

entries.heading: Citation Hover Information
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:20] Hover over a citation to see: - Full title and authors - Publication venue and year - Abstract (if available) - DOI and URL links - Citation count (via OpenAlex) - Open Access status - Quick action links

entries.heading: Opening PDFs
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 10:20] The system looks for PDF files in scimax.ref.pdfDirectory using these patterns: 1. key.pdf (exact key match) 2. Author_Year.pdf (first author and year) 3. DOI.pdf (DOI with slashes replaced by underscores) If no local PDF is found but the entry has a DOI: - Prompts to open DOI in browser - OpenAlex integration may provide Open Access PDF link

entries.heading: Reference Notes
entries.content: Each reference can have an associated notes file: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+TITLE: Notes on Machine Learning for Scientific Computing #+AUTHOR: Smith and Doe #+DATE: 2024 #+CITE_KEY: smith2024machine ,* Summary ,* Key Points - ,* Quotes #+BEGIN_QUOTE #+END_QUOTE ,* Notes ,* References #+END_SRC Notes are stored in scimax.ref.notesDirectory as key.org files and created automatically with a template when first opened.

entries.heading: Citation Manipulation
entries.content: When cursor is on a citation with multiple keys:

entries.heading: Transpose Citations
entries.content: | Key             | Command                           | Action                 | |-----------------+-----------------------------------+------------------------| | S-<left> Arrow  | scimax.ref.transposeCitationLeft  | Swap with previous key | | S-<right> Arrow | scimax.ref.transposeCitationRight | Swap with next key     | Example: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE cite:jones2023,smith2024,doe2022 ^cursor here Press S-<right>: cite:jones2023,doe2022,smith2024 ^cursor follows #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Sort Citations
entries.content: | Key          | Command                                | Action                      | |--------------+----------------------------------------+-----------------------------| | S-<up> Arrow | scimax.ref.sortCitations               | Sort by year (oldest first) | | S-<down>     | scimax.ref.sortCitationsByYear         | Sort by year (newest first) | |              | scimax.ref.sortCitationsAlphabetically | Sort alphabetically by key  | Citations are sorted by extracting year from: 1. Bibliograph

entries.heading: Delete Citation Key
entries.content: | Command                   | Action                                | |---------------------------+---------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.deleteCitation | Delete current key or entire citation | - If multiple keys: Removes current key only - If single key: Deletes entire citation

entries.heading: References Tree View
entries.content: The References view shows your bibliography organized by entry type: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE REFERENCES  article (45)    smith2024machine: Smith (2024)    jones2023deep: Jones (2023)    ...  book (12)    doe2022python: Doe (2022)    ...  inproceedings (23)  ... #+END_EXAMPLE Click an entry to open the action menu.

entries.heading: Search References
entries.content: | Command                     | Description                              | |-----------------------------+------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.searchReferences | Search bibliography by author/title/year | Searches across: - Citation keys - Author names - Titles - Years - Journals - Keywords Results are ranked by relevance (key matches first, then author, then title).

entries.heading: Find Citations
entries.content: | Command                  | Description                       | |--------------------------+-----------------------------------| | scimax.ref.findCitations | Find all citations of a reference | Searches workspace for citations of a selected key in all org, markdown, and LaTeX files. Results shown in peek view for quick navigation.

entries.heading: Add Reference from DOI
entries.content: | Command                 | Description                              | |-------------------------+------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.fetchFromDOI | Fetch BibTeX entry from DOI via CrossRef |

entries.heading: Usage
entries.content: 1. Run scimax.ref.fetchFromDOI 2. Enter DOI (accepts 10.xxx/xxx or https://doi.org/10.xxx/xxx) 3. Preview the fetched entry 4. Choose action: - Add to Bibliography - Appends to first configured .bib file - Copy BibTeX - Copies to clipboard - Cancel

entries.heading: DOI Resolution
entries.content: The system fetches metadata from CrossRef API and converts it to BibTeX format. If the key already exists, you can: - Replace the existing entry - Generate a new unique key - Cancel

entries.heading: Search CrossRef by Query
entries.content: | Command                   | Description                              | |---------------------------+------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.searchCrossRef | Search CrossRef and add entry by query   | When you don't have a DOI, you can search CrossRef directly by title, author, or keywords: 1. Run =scimax.ref.searchCrossRef= 2. Enter search query (or select text first to pre-fill) 3. Browse results showing title, authors, year, publisher, and DOI 4. Select an entry to add 5. Co

entries.heading: OpenAlex Integration
entries.content: OpenAlex provides enhanced metadata for academic works:

entries.heading: Show Citing Works
entries.content: | Command                    | Description                  | |----------------------------+------------------------------| | scimax.ref.showCitingWorks | Show papers citing this work | Displays papers that cite the selected reference with: - Title, authors, year - Citation count - Open Access status and PDF link - Publication venue

entries.heading: Show Related Works
entries.content: | Command                     | Description         | |-----------------------------+---------------------| | scimax.ref.showRelatedWorks | Show related papers | Shows papers related to the selected reference based on OpenAlex's relatedness algorithm.

entries.heading: Search OpenAlex
entries.content: | Command                   | Description              | |---------------------------+--------------------------| | scimax.ref.searchOpenAlex | Search OpenAlex database | Search the global OpenAlex database for works by title, author, or keywords. Results include: - Citation counts - Open Access status - Topic classification - Abstracts

entries.heading: DOI Hover Information
entries.content: Hover over DOI links (doi:10.xxx, https://doi.org/10.xxx) to see: - Title, authors, publication info - Citation count (via OpenAlex) - Open Access status and PDF link - Abstract - Quick actions: Add to bibliography, open DOI, view citing works

entries.heading: Cross-References
entries.content: Beyond citations, Scimax supports cross-references to figures, tables, equations, and sections.

entries.heading: Reference Link Types
entries.content: | Type    | Example         | References                               | |---------+-----------------+------------------------------------------| | ref     | ref:fig-results | Figures, tables, sections                | | eqref   | eqref:eq-1      | Equations (with parentheses)             | | pageref | pageref:intro   | Page number reference                    | | nameref | nameref:methods | Name/title of section                    | | autoref | autoref:tbl-1   | Auto-formatted (Figure 1, Table

entries.heading: Insert Cross-Reference
entries.content: | Key   | Command                           | |-------+-----------------------------------| | C-S-] | Insert ref (scimax.ref.insertRef) | 1. Run scimax.ref.insertRef 2. Select label from workspace 3. Choose reference type (ref, eqref, pageref, etc.) 4. Reference inserted at cursor

entries.heading: Label Definitions
entries.content: Define labels for cross-referencing. The =ref:= link type searches for these label definitions: | Definition Type | Syntax                    | Example               | |-----------------+---------------------------+-----------------------| | #+NAME:         | =#+NAME: label=           | Tables, figures, blocks | | #+LABEL:        | =#+LABEL: label=          | Figures, tables       | | label:          | =label:label=             | Inline labels         | | \label{}        | =\label{label}=

entries.heading: Org-Mode Labels
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+NAME: fig-results ,#+CAPTION: Experimental results [[file:./images/results.png]] ,#+NAME: tbl-data ,#+CAPTION: Data summary | Column 1 | Column 2 | |----------+----------| | Data     | Values   | label:eq-main  \[ E = mc^2 \] ,* Methods :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: methods :END: #+END_SRC References: #+BEGIN_SRC org See ref:fig-results for the results. See ref:tbl-data for the data summary. As shown in eqref:eq-main, energy equals... The ref:methods section describes our approach.

entries.heading: LaTeX Labels
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \begin{equation} \label{eq:main} E = mc^2 \end{equation} See equation \eqref{eq:main} for details. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Reference Hover
entries.content: Hover over cross-references to see: - Label type (figure, table, equation, heading) - Caption or heading text - Surrounding context - Link to jump to definition

entries.heading: HTML Export
entries.content: HTML export uses citation-js for full CSL-based citation formatting. Citations are processed according to standard citation styles like APA, MLA, Chicago, etc.

entries.heading: Citation Link Types
entries.content: | Org Citation       | Rendered Output               | |--------------------+-------------------------------| | =cite:smith2024=   | (Smith, 2024)                 | | =citep:smith2024=  | (Smith, 2024)                 | | =citet:smith2024=  | Smith (2024)                  | | =citeauthor:smith2024= | Smith                     | | =citeyear:smith2024= | 2024                        |

entries.heading: Specifying Citation Style
entries.content: Use =#+CSL_STYLE:= to set the citation format: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+CSL_STYLE: apa #+END_SRC Available styles: =apa= (default), =mla=, =chicago=, =harvard=, =ieee=, =vancouver=

entries.heading: Bibliography Generation
entries.content: The HTML export automatically generates a formatted bibliography section at the end of the document. Ensure your document includes a bibliography reference: #+BEGIN_SRC org #+BIBLIOGRAPHY: references.bib #+END_SRC See [[file:10-export.org::*HTML Citation Export][Export System: HTML Citation Export]] for complete documentation.

entries.heading: LaTeX Export
entries.content: Citations convert to LaTeX commands: | Org Citation   | LaTeX Output     | |----------------+------------------| | cite:key       | \cite{key}       | | citet:key      | \citet{key}      | | citep:key      | \citep{key}      | | citeauthor:key | \citeauthor{key} | | citeyear:key   | \citeyear{key}   | Bibliography links export to \bibliography{file} commands.

entries.heading: Markdown Export
entries.content: Citations export to Pandoc citation syntax: | Org Citation | Pandoc Markdown Output | |--------------+------------------------| | cite:key     | [@key]                 | | citet:key    | @key                   | | citep:key    | [@key]                 |

entries.heading: Extract Bibliography for Document
entries.content: | Command                        | Description                               | |--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.extractBibliography | Extract cited references to new .bib file | Useful for creating document-specific bibliography files: 1. Scans current document for all citations 2. Looks up entries in your bibliography 3. Saves to new .bib file or copies to clipboard Generates a portable .bib file containing only the references cited in

entries.heading: Opening Bibliography Files
entries.content: | Command                     | Description                       | |-----------------------------+-----------------------------------| | scimax.ref.openBibliography | Open configured bibliography file | If multiple files configured, shows a picker.

entries.heading: Copy BibTeX Entry
entries.content: | Command               | Description                              | |-----------------------+------------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.copyBibTeX | Copy BibTeX entry for selected reference | Select a reference and copy its BibTeX source to clipboard.

entries.heading: Refresh Bibliography
entries.content: | Command            | Description                   | |--------------------+-------------------------------| | scimax.ref.refresh | Reload all bibliography files | Reloads all configured and workspace .bib files. Useful after external changes.

entries.heading: Bibliography File Diagnostics
entries.content: The extension validates bibliography links in org files: - Highlights missing bibliography files - Shows error diagnostics for invalid paths - Suggests creating missing files

entries.heading: Code Lenses in .bib Files
entries.content: When viewing a .bib file, code lenses appear for each entry: - Find citations - Search workspace for citations of this key - Copy key - Copy citation key to clipboard

entries.heading: Citation Commands
entries.content: | Command                                | Default Key | Description                 | |----------------------------------------+-------------+-----------------------------| | scimax.ref.insertCitation              | C-c ]       | Insert/append citation      | | scimax.zotero.insertCitation           | C-c z       | Insert citation from Zotero | | scimax.ref.insertRef                   | C-S-]       | Insert cross-reference      | | scimax.ref.insertBibliography          |             | Insert b

entries.heading: Bibliography Commands
entries.content: | Command                        | Description                 | |--------------------------------+-----------------------------| | scimax.ref.openBibliography    | Open bibliography file      | | scimax.ref.searchReferences    | Search bibliography         | | scimax.ref.findCitations       | Find citations of reference | | scimax.ref.copyBibTeX          | Copy BibTeX entry           | | scimax.ref.refresh             | Reload bibliography files   | | scimax.ref.extractBibliography | Extract ci

entries.heading: DOI and External Commands
entries.content: | Command                     | Description                        | |-----------------------------+------------------------------------| | scimax.ref.fetchFromDOI     | Add reference from DOI             | | scimax.ref.searchCrossRef   | Search CrossRef and add entry      | | scimax.ref.showCitingWorks  | Show citing works (OpenAlex)       | | scimax.ref.showRelatedWorks | Show related works (OpenAlex)      | | scimax.ref.searchOpenAlex   | Search OpenAlex database           |

entries.heading: Use Consistent Citation Keys
entries.content: Good key format: author-year-keyword Examples: - smith-2024-machine-learning - jones-2023-deep-neural - doe-2022-python-scientific Benefits: - Easy to remember and type - Sorting by name is meaningful - Year visible in key - Keyword aids recall

entries.heading: Maintain Multiple .bib Files
entries.content: Organize by topic or project: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE ~/Documents/  machine-learning.bib      # ML papers  statistics.bib             # Statistics references  projects/  thesis/  thesis-refs.bib    # Thesis-specific #+END_EXAMPLE Configure global files + use document-local links for project-specific references.

entries.heading: Store PDFs Systematically
entries.content: Use consistent naming in PDF directory: - smith-2024-machine-learning.pdf - Match citation keys when possible - Or use FirstAuthor_Year.pdf format

entries.heading: Literature Review Workflow
entries.content: 1. Search OpenAlex: scimax.ref.searchOpenAlex 2. Find relevant paper 3. Add to bibliography via DOI 4. Check citing works: scimax.ref.showCitingWorks 5. Explore related works: scimax.ref.showRelatedWorks 6. Create notes file for each key reference 7. Download PDFs to configured directory

entries.heading: Writing Workflow
entries.content: 1. Write draft with placeholder citations 2. Insert citations: C-c ] 3. Search references interactively 4. Hover citations to verify 5. Before final export: scimax.ref.extractBibliography 6. Creates portable .bib file with your document

entries.heading: Managing Notes
entries.content: Create comprehensive notes for key papers: #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TITLE: Notes on Smith (2024) - Machine Learning ,#+CITE_KEY: smith2024machine ,* Summary Three-sentence summary of the paper ,* Key Points - Main contribution 1 - Main contribution 2 - Methodology highlights ,* Quotes ,#+BEGIN_QUOTE "Important quote from the paper" (p. 42) ,#+END_QUOTE ,* Personal Notes Connections to my research... ,* Follow-up References - cite:jones2023deep - Related deep learning work - cite:nguyen2024neural - Ext

entries.heading: For LaTeX/PDF Export
entries.content: Ensure bibliography link includes all cited .bib files: #+BEGIN_SRC org bibliography:~/Documents/refs.bib,./local-refs.bib #+END_SRC Use standard citation styles LaTeX understands (cite, citet, citep).

entries.heading: For HTML Export
entries.content: Citations export as links. For proper bibliography rendering: 1. Ensure #+BIBLIOGRAPHY: keyword is present 2. Or include bibliography: link 3. HTML export generates bibliography section automatically

entries.heading: For Standalone Documents
entries.content: Before sharing: 1. Run scimax.ref.extractBibliography 2. Save extracted .bib alongside document 3. Update bibliography link to local file: #+BEGIN_SRC org bibliography:./references.bib #+END_SRC

entries.heading: BibTeX Entry Quality
entries.content: Ensure complete entries for best results: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{key, author = {Required}, title = {Required}, journal = {Recommended for articles}, year = {Required}, volume = {Recommended}, number = {Recommended}, pages = {Recommended}, doi = {Highly recommended - enables OpenAlex integration}, url = {Useful if no DOI}, abstract = {Helpful for hover info}, keywords = {Aids search} } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Citation Not Found
entries.content: If citation shows "not found in bibliography": 1. Check spelling of citation key 2. Verify .bib file is configured or linked in document 3. Run `scimax.ref.refresh' to reload bibliography 4. Check .bib file for entry with that exact key

entries.heading: PDF Not Found
entries.content: If "PDF not found" when trying to open: 1. Check `scimax.ref.pdfDirectory' is set correctly 2. Verify PDF filename matches key or `Author_Year.pdf' pattern 3. Check file exists with `ls' or file explorer 4. Try opening from DOI if available

entries.heading: DOI Fetch Fails
entries.content: If fetching from DOI fails: 1. Verify DOI is correct (should start with 10.) 2. Check internet connection 3. Try searching on https://crossref.org directly 4. Some DOIs may not be in CrossRef database 5. Try OpenAlex search as alternative

entries.heading: Bibliography Link Not Recognized
entries.content: If bibliography link isn't recognized: 1. Check path is correct (try absolute path first) 2. Ensure .bib extension is included 3. Verify file exists at that location 4. Check for typos in filename 5. Use `~' for home directory, not `$HOME'

entries.heading: Export Issues
entries.content: If citations don't export correctly: 1. Check export format supports citations 2. Verify bibliography link is present in document 3. Ensure citation keys are in bibliography 4. For LaTeX: check LaTeX citation package is available 5. For Pandoc: use Pandoc-compatible citation syntax

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: - [[file:05-links.org][Hyperlinks]] - General link syntax and usage - [[file:10-export.org][Export System]] - Exporting documents with citations - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - BibTeX as source blocks - [[file:26-configuration.org][Configuration]] - Reference system settings

entries.heading: Essential Keybindings
entries.content: | Key       | Action                        | |-----------+-------------------------------| | C-c ]     | Insert citation               | | C-c z     | Insert citation from Zotero   | | C-S-]     | Insert cross-reference        | | C-c C-o   | Open link/citation at point   | | S-<left>  | Transpose citation left       | | S-<right> | Transpose citation right      | | S-<up>    | Sort citations (oldest first) | | S-<down>  | Sort citations (newest first) |

entries.heading: Citation Syntax Quick Reference
entries.content: | Format        | Org-Mode       | Markdown   | LaTeX            | |---------------+----------------+------------+------------------| | Basic         | cite:key       | [@key]     | \cite{key}       | | Textual       | citet:key      | @key       | \citet{key}      | | Parenthetical | citep:key      | [@key]     | \citep{key}      | | Author only   | citeauthor:key | N/A        | \citeauthor{key} | | Year only     | citeyear:key   | N/A        | \citeyear{key}   | | Multiple      | cite:k1,k2,k3

entries.heading: Add New Reference
entries.content: 1. scimax.ref.fetchFromDOI or scimax.ref.searchOpenAlex 2. Review metadata 3. Add to bibliography

entries.heading: Insert Citation
entries.content: 1. C-c ] 2. Search for reference 3. Select citation style 4. Citation inserted

entries.heading: Find Related Papers
entries.content: 1. Hover over citation or DOI 2. Click "Citing Works" or "Related Works" 3. Browse results 4. Add relevant papers

entries.heading: Prepare for Export
entries.content: 1. scimax.ref.extractBibliography 2. Save to document directory 3. Update bibliography link 4. Export document
