entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:20-editmarks.org][Editmarks]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:22-hydra-menus.org][Hydra Menus]]

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:36] Hydra menus are a powerful keyboard-driven menu system inspired by Emacs hydra and transient packages. They provide quick access to Scimax commands through persistent, modal menus that remain open until you explicitly close them or execute an exit command.

entries.heading: What Are Hydra Menus?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:36] A hydra menu is a quick pick interface that displays available commands organized into logical groups. Each command is associated with a single keyboard shortcut, allowing you to rapidly execute actions without navigating through multiple menus or remembering complex key combinations. Think of hydra menus as command palettes optimized for keyboard efficiency: - Single-key selection (no Enter needed) - Commands stay organized in logical groups - Menus can stay open

entries.heading: Key Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:37] - Fast keyboard-driven navigation with single-key selection - Organized command groups with descriptive labels and icons - Persistent menus that stay open for repeated actions (red heads) - Exit-after-action commands (blue heads) - Submenu navigation for hierarchical organization - Toggle indicators showing on/off state - Conditional visibility based on context - Customizable through VS Code settings - Full integration with all Scimax features

entries.heading: Philosophy
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:37] The hydra system is designed around the principle of discoverability and efficiency. Instead of memorizing dozens of keyboard shortcuts, you can press `C-c m' to open the main menu and see all available commands with their shortcuts. Once you learn commonly-used shortcuts, you can invoke them directly without opening the menu.

entries.heading: Opening the Main Menu
entries.content: The fastest way to access hydra menus is through the main menu: - Press `C-c m' to open the main Scimax menu - Press `C-c C-m' for a context-aware menu based on the current file type You can also open menus through the command palette: 1. Press `C/cmd-S-P' 2. Type "Scimax: Main Menu" or "Scimax: Show Hydra Menu" 3. Press Enter

entries.heading: Basic Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:39] When a hydra menu is open: 1. Press a single key to execute the corresponding command 2. Type multiple characters to filter the list 3. Use arrow keys to navigate 4. Press Enter to execute the selected command 5. Press Escape to close, or select "Back" to return to parent menu

entries.heading: Understanding Exit Behaviors
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:52] Each menu item has one of three exit behaviors, indicated by icons in the interface. Note: The terms "Blue Head" and "Red Head" come from Emacs Hydra, which uses colored text. VS Code's QuickPick API doesn't support per-item colors, so we use icons instead.

entries.heading: Exit (Blue Head) - $(sign-out)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:13] The menu closes after executing the command. Most commands use this behavior. These items are marked with a $(sign-out) icon (exit door). #+begin_example [t] Today $(sign-out)            Opens today's journal and closes menu [s] Search $(sign-out)           Starts search and closes menu #+end_example

entries.heading: Stay (Red Head) - $(sync)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] The menu remains open after executing the command, allowing you to execute it multiple times or try different commands. These items are marked with a $(sync) icon (circular arrows). #+begin_example [r] Refresh $(sync)              Refreshes data and keeps menu open [i] Index File $(sync)           Indexes file and keeps menu open #+end_example

entries.heading: Submenu - $(chevron-right)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:14] Navigates to a child menu. These items are marked with a $(chevron-right) icon (arrow). #+begin_example [j] Journal $(chevron-right)     Opens journal submenu [r] References $(chevron-right)  Opens references submenu #+end_example

entries.heading: Available Hydras
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:42] Scimax comes with eight pre-built hydra menus covering all major features:

entries.heading: Main Menu (scimax.main)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 07:42] The main entry point for all Scimax features. *Access*: `C-c m' or command `Scimax: Main Menu' #+begin_example Scimax Features: [j] Journal       - Date-based journaling [r] References    - Bibliography management [n] Notebook      - Project notebooks [p] Projects      - Project switching (projectile) Search & Navigation: [s] Search        - Search across files [g] Jump (Avy)    - Quick navigation Database: [d] Database      - Org database operations #+end_example

entries.heading: Journal Menu (scimax.journal)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Date-based journaling commands for creating and navigating entries. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Journal Open Entry: [t] Today           - Open today's journal entry [y] Yesterday       - Open yesterday's entry [w] Tomorrow        - Open tomorrow's entry [g] Go to Date      - Open entry for specific date Navigation: [p] Previous Entry  - Navigate to previous entry [n] Next Entry      - Navigate to next entry [v] Week View       - View entries for the week Cr

entries.heading: References Menu (scimax.references)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Bibliography and citation management powered by org-ref. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example References Citations: [c] Insert Citation - Search and insert a citation [o] Open Entry      - Open a bibliography entry [u] Open URL        - Open URL for reference Add References: [d] Fetch from DOI    - Add entry from DOI [b] Fetch from BibTeX - Add entry from BibTeX string [n] New Entry         - Create new bibliography entry Search: [s] Search References - Search bibli

entries.heading: Notebook Menu (scimax.notebook)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Project-based organization for scientific computing. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Notebook Navigation: [o] Open Notebook   - Open an existing notebook [l] List Notebooks  - Show all notebooks Create: [n] New Notebook  - Create a new notebook [e] New Entry     - Add entry to current notebook Search: [s] Search Notebook - Search within current notebook Files: [f] Open File      - Open file from notebook [r] Recent Files   - Show recent notebook files #+end_exa

entries.heading: Projectile Menu (scimax.projectile)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Project management and switching inspired by Emacs projectile. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Projects (Projectile) Switch: [p] Switch Project  - Switch to another project Manage: [a] Add Project       - Add current folder as project [r] Remove Project    - Remove a project from list [s] Scan for Projects - Scan directories for projects Files: [f] Find File         - Find file in project [g] Search in Project - Search text in project #+end_example *Example Usa

entries.heading: Search Menu (scimax.search)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Comprehensive search across files and content. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Search Fuzzy Search: [f] Search Current File - Fuzzy search in current file [o] Search Open Files   - Search across all open files [h] Search Headings     - Search headings in current file Database Search: [s] Full-text Search  - Search all indexed content [v] Vector Search     - Semantic similarity search Tasks & Agenda: [t] Search TODOs  - Find TODO items [a] Agenda        - View a

entries.heading: Jump Menu (scimax.jump)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Avy-style quick navigation for jumping to visible text. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Jump (Avy) Jump to Character: [c] Jump to Char    - Jump to a character [2] Jump to 2 Chars - Jump to two characters Jump to Word: [w] Jump to Word - Jump to start of word Jump to Line: [l] Jump to Line  - Jump to a line [a] Jump Above    - Jump to line above cursor [b] Jump Below    - Jump to line below cursor #+end_example *Example Usage*: 1. Press C-c M, then g to open ju

entries.heading: Database Menu (scimax.database)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] Org database operations including search and indexing. *Parent*: Main Menu #+begin_example Database Search: [s] Full-text Search  - Search all content [v] Vector Search     - Semantic similarity search [h] Search Headings   - Search by heading text Tasks: [t] Search TODOs  - Find TODO items [a] Agenda        - View scheduled items Links: [l] Search Links  - Find org links [b] Backlinks     - Find backlinks to current file Index: [i] Index Current File  - Re-index t

entries.heading: Global Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:15] | Keybinding | Command                  | Description             | |------------+--------------------------+-------------------------| | C-c m      | scimax.hydra.main        | Open main menu          | | C-c C-m    | scimax.hydra.contextMenu | Open context-aware menu | [[cmd:scimax.hydra.main][C-c m]] opens the main hydra menu, while [[cmd:scimax.hydra.contextMenu][C-c C-m]] opens a menu tailored to the current file type.

entries.heading: Available Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:16] All hydra commands can be invoked through the command palette (Cmd/C-S-P):

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.show
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:16] Show a specific hydra menu by ID. If no ID is provided, shows a picker to select from available menus. #+begin_src typescript // Show main menu await vscode.commands.executeCommand('scimax.hydra.show', 'scimax.main'); // Show menu picker await vscode.commands.executeCommand('scimax.hydra.show'); #+end_src

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.hide
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:16] Hide the currently visible hydra menu.

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.back
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:16] Navigate back to the parent menu. If there's no parent, closes the menu.

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.main
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Open the main Scimax menu (scimax.main).

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.contextMenu
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Open a context-aware menu based on the current file type. Falls back to the main menu if no language-specific menu exists.

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.toggle
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Toggle visibility of a specific menu. #+begin_src typescript await vscode.commands.executeCommand('scimax.hydra.toggle', 'scimax.journal'); #+end_src

entries.heading: Settings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Configure hydra behavior through VS Code settings (File > Preferences > Settings or Cmd/C-,):

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.showKeyHints
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Show keyboard shortcuts inline with menu items. - Type: boolean - Default: true When enabled, shows shortcuts like [t] before each menu item: #+begin_example [t] Today           - With key hints Today               - Without key hints #+end_example #+begin_src json { "scimax.hydra.showKeyHints": true } #+end_src

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.singleKeySelection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Select menu items with a single keypress (no Enter needed). - Type: boolean - Default: true When enabled, pressing a key immediately executes the command. When disabled, you must press Enter after selecting. #+begin_src json { "scimax.hydra.singleKeySelection": true } #+end_src

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.dimNonMatching
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Dim menu items that don't match the current filter. - Type: boolean - Default: true When typing to filter, non-matching items are dimmed rather than hidden. #+begin_src json { "scimax.hydra.dimNonMatching": true } #+end_src

entries.heading: scimax.hydra.sortByKey
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Sort menu items by their keyboard shortcut instead of definition order. - Type: boolean - Default: false When enabled, items are alphabetically sorted by key (a, b, c...) rather than their logical grouping. #+begin_src json { "scimax.hydra.sortByKey": false } #+end_src

entries.heading: Example Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] A complete hydra configuration might look like: #+begin_src json { "scimax.hydra.showKeyHints": true, "scimax.hydra.singleKeySelection": true, "scimax.hydra.dimNonMatching": true, "scimax.hydra.sortByKey": false } #+end_src

entries.heading: Creating Custom Hydras
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] You can create custom hydra menus programmatically in extension code or through configuration.

entries.heading: Menu Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] A hydra menu definition consists of: - Unique ID - Title and optional hint text - Groups of menu items - Optional parent menu for hierarchical navigation - Optional lifecycle hooks

entries.heading: Using the Fluent Builder API
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] The easiest way to create a custom menu is with the fluent builder: #+begin_src typescript import { HydraManager } from './hydra'; // Get the hydra manager instance const hydraManager = getHydraManager(); // Build a custom menu const menu = hydraManager.createMenuBuilder('my.custom.menu') .title('My Custom Menu') .hint('Press a key to select an action') .command('a', 'Action A', 'my.command.a') .persistentCommand('r', 'Refresh', 'my.command.refresh') .submenu('s',

entries.heading: Exit Commands (Blue Heads)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Close the menu after executing: #+begin_src typescript .command('t', 'Today', 'scimax.journal.today') #+end_src

entries.heading: Persistent Commands (Red Heads)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Keep the menu open after executing: #+begin_src typescript .persistentCommand('r', 'Refresh', 'my.refresh.command') #+end_src

entries.heading: Submenu Links
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Navigate to a child menu: #+begin_src typescript .submenu('j', 'Journal', 'scimax.journal') #+end_src

entries.heading: Manual Menu Definition
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] For more control, you can define menus manually: #+begin_src typescript import { HydraMenuDefinition } from './hydra/types'; const customMenu: HydraMenuDefinition = { id: 'my.custom', title: 'Custom Menu', hint: 'My custom commands', parent: 'scimax.main', groups: [ { title: 'Actions', items: [ { key: 'a', label: 'Action A', description: 'Performs action A',

entries.heading: Conditional Visibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Show items only when certain conditions are met: #+begin_src typescript { key: 'x', label: 'Advanced Feature', exit: 'exit', action: 'my.advanced.command', when: () => { const config = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('myext'); return config.get('enableAdvanced', false); } } #+end_src

entries.heading: Toggle Items
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Display on/off state for toggle commands: #+begin_src typescript { key: 't', label: 'Auto Save', exit: 'stay', action: 'my.toggle.autosave', isToggle: true, getToggleState: async () => { const config = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('myext'); return config.get('autoSave', false); } } #+end_src Toggle items display $(check) when on and $(circle-outline) when off.

entries.heading: Lifecycle Hooks
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:17] Execute code when menus are shown or hidden: #+begin_src typescript const menu: HydraMenuDefinition = { id: 'my.menu', title: 'My Menu', groups: [], onShow: async () => { console.log('Menu opened'); await refreshData(); }, onHide: async () => { console.log('Menu closed'); await cleanup(); } }; #+end_src

entries.heading: Registering Multiple Menus
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] Register several menus at once: #+begin_src typescript const menus = [menu1, menu2, menu3]; hydraManager.registerMenus(menus); #+end_src

entries.heading: Unregistering Menus
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] Remove a menu from the registry: #+begin_src typescript hydraManager.unregisterMenu('my.custom.menu'); #+end_src

entries.heading: Example 1: Opening Today's Journal
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] The quickest way to open today's journal entry: 1. Press C-c m  opens main menu 2. Press j  opens journal submenu 3. Press t  opens today's entry and closes menu Or, if you remember the keybinding, press C-S-J directly.

entries.heading: Example 2: Inserting a Citation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] To insert a citation in your document: 1. Position cursor where you want the citation 2. Press C-c m  opens main menu 3. Press r  opens references submenu 4. Press c  starts citation insertion 5. Type to search for your reference 6. Select the reference to insert it

entries.heading: Example 3: Quick Navigation with Jump
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] To jump to a visible word on screen: 1. Press C-c m  opens main menu 2. Press g  opens jump submenu 3. Press w  starts word jump mode 4. Type first letter of target word 5. Type the hint character shown at target location 6. Cursor jumps to that word

entries.heading: Example 4: Searching TODO Items
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:18] To find all TODO items in your org files: 1. Press C-c m  opens main menu 2. Press s  opens search submenu 3. Press t  searches for TODO items 4. View results in quick pick 5. Select an item to navigate to it

entries.heading: Example 5: Navigating Back
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:50] When in a submenu: 1. Press C-c m  main menu 2. Press d  database menu 3. Select "Back" at the top of the menu  returns to main menu 4. Press Escape  closes all menus

entries.heading: Differences from Emacs Hydra
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:19] While inspired by Emacs hydra, the VS Code implementation has some differences due to platform constraints and design choices:

entries.heading: Similarities
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:19] - Keyboard-driven navigation with single-key selection - Persistent menus that stay open for repeated actions - Exit vs. stay behavior (blue vs. red heads) - Hierarchical menu organization - Visual indicators and hints

entries.heading: Quick Pick vs. Minibuffer
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:19] VS Code uses the native quick pick interface instead of Emacs's minibuffer. This provides: - Native VS Code look and feel - Fuzzy filtering built-in - Mouse support (if desired) - Icon support - Better accessibility

entries.heading: No Dedicated Hydra Mode
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] VS Code doesn't have a dedicated "hydra mode" like Emacs. Hydras appear as quick picks that temporarily take focus but don't create a new modal mode.

entries.heading: Async Command Execution
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Commands execute asynchronously and can return Promises, supporting VS Code's async command pattern.

entries.heading: Icon-Based Indicators Instead of Colors
entries.content: Unlike Emacs hydra which uses colored text (blue for exit, red for stay), VS Code's QuickPick API doesn't support per-item color customization. Instead, we use codicons to indicate behavior: | Behavior   | Icon              | Meaning                            | |------------+-------------------+------------------------------------| | Exit       | $(sign-out)       | Menu closes after command executes | | Stay       | $(sync)           | Menu stays open after command      | | Submenu    | $(chev

entries.heading: Menu State Persistence
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] The hydra state is not persisted across VS Code restarts. Each session starts fresh.

entries.heading: Configuration Through Settings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Configuration uses VS Code's settings system (JSON) rather than Emacs Lisp variables.

entries.heading: No Posframe Support
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Menus don't appear at specific screen positions like Emacs posframe. They always appear in the standard quick pick location (top center).

entries.heading: Migration Tips
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] If you're coming from Emacs hydra: 1. *Keybindings*: Map C-c m (or your preferred binding) to scimax.hydra.main 2. *Menu Definition*: Use the fluent builder API for a declarative style similar to Emacs 3. *Exit Behavior*: exit ` blue head, stay ' red head 4. *Submenus*: Use the submenu exit behavior instead of (exit) with another hydra call 5. *Hooks*: Use onShow and onHide instead of :before-exit and :after-exit

entries.heading: Discoverability
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Keep menus organized in logical groups - Use descriptive labels and helpful descriptions - Add icons to make items visually distinct - Use consistent key assignments (e.g., s for search, n for new)

entries.heading: Performance
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Use conditional visibility (when) to hide irrelevant items - Don't create too many nested submenus (2-3 levels max) - Keep async actions fast to avoid blocking the UI - Use persistent commands (stay) for repeated actions

entries.heading: Keyboard Shortcuts
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Assign memorable single-letter keys - Use uppercase for destructive or advanced operations - Group related commands under similar keys across menus - Reserve common keys (q for quit, ? for help, b for back)

entries.heading: User Experience
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Provide clear hints in menu titles - Show toggle state for boolean options - Use submenus to reduce cognitive load - Test both keyboard and mouse interaction - Ensure menus work in all relevant contexts

entries.heading: Debugging
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] To debug custom menus: 1. Open the Developer Console (Help > Toggle Developer Tools) 2. Set breakpoints in menu actions 3. Use console.log in onShow and onHide hooks 4. Check for errors in command execution 5. Verify menu registration with hydraManager.getMenuIds()

entries.heading: Menu Not Appearing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Verify the menu is registered: Check hydraManager.getMenuIds() - Ensure the menu ID is correct - Check for errors in the Developer Console - Verify keybindings are not conflicting

entries.heading: Commands Not Executing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Verify the command is registered in VS Code - Check command arguments are correct - Look for errors in the Developer Console - Test the command directly from command palette

entries.heading: Items Not Showing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Check the when condition if present - Verify group visibility conditions - Ensure items are not filtered by current search - Check that sortByKey setting isn't hiding items

entries.heading: Single-Key Selection Not Working
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Verify scimax.hydra.singleKeySelection is true - Check for key conflicts with other extensions - Ensure the hydra menu has focus - Try pressing keys slowly (avoid double-press)

entries.heading: Submenus Not Navigating
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - Verify submenu ID exists and is registered - Check exit is set to 'submenu' - Ensure action contains the submenu ID string - Verify parent menu is properly configured

entries.heading: Can I create hydras for non-Scimax commands?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Yes! You can create hydras that execute any VS Code command, including those from other extensions.

entries.heading: How do I add a hydra to the command palette?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Hydra commands like scimax.hydra.show are automatically available in the command palette. To show a specific menu, register it first, then call: #+begin_src typescript await vscode.commands.executeCommand('scimax.hydra.show', 'your.menu.id'); #+end_src

entries.heading: Can I bind a hydra to a custom keybinding?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Yes! Add a keybinding in keybindings.json: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+alt+h", "command": "scimax.hydra.show", "args": "my.custom.menu" } #+end_src

entries.heading: How do I share custom hydras with my team?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Custom hydras defined in extension code are automatically shared. For configuration-based hydras, share your workspace .vscode/settings.json file.

entries.heading: Can hydras work with multiple workspaces?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Yes! Hydras are global to the VS Code window and work across all workspace folders.

entries.heading: How do I disable hydras?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Unmap the keybindings in your keybindings.json: #+begin_src json { "key": "ctrl+c m", "command": "-scimax.hydra.main" } #+end_src The hydras remain available through the command palette.

entries.heading: Source Code
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] The hydra framework source is located in src/hydra/: - src/hydra/types.ts - Type definitions - src/hydra/hydraManager.ts - Core manager implementation - src/hydra/commands.ts - Command registrations - src/hydra/menus/ - Pre-built menu definitions

entries.heading: Related Documentation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - [[file:24-keybindings.org][Keybindings]] - All Scimax keyboard shortcuts - [[file:26-configuration.org][Configuration]] - Complete settings reference - [[file:14-journal.org][Journal]] - Journal-specific commands and workflows - [[file:19-references.org][References]] - Bibliography management - [[file:18-database-search.org][Database Search]] - Search and query system

entries.heading: External References
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] - [[https://github.com/abo-abo/hydra][Emacs Hydra Package]] - Original inspiration - [[https://github.com/magit/transient][Emacs Transient Package]] - Alternative approach - [[https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#QuickPick][VS Code QuickPick API]] - Underlying implementation

entries.heading: Conclusion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:20] Hydra menus provide a powerful and discoverable way to access Scimax features. Whether you're a new user exploring available commands or an experienced user building custom workflows, hydras help you work efficiently without memorizing dozens of keyboard shortcuts. Start with C-c m to open the main menu and explore. Over time, you'll develop muscle memory for frequently-used commands and can invoke them directly or through submenus. Happy hydra-ing!

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 19:51] - Previous: [[file:21-navigation.org][Navigation]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:23-speed-commands.org][Speed Commands]]

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:44] Speed commands are single-letter keyboard shortcuts that work when the cursor is positioned at the very beginning (column 0) of a heading line. This feature, borrowed from Emacs org-mode, provides lightning-fast navigation and editing without the need for complex key chords.

entries.heading: What are Speed Commands?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:44] Speed commands transform the beginning of each heading into a powerful command interface. When your cursor is at column 0 of a heading (the first star `*' in org-mode or the first hash `#' in markdown), you can press a single key to execute common operations: - Navigation: jump between headings, siblings, parent - Visibility: fold/unfold sections - Structure editing: move, promote, demote, cut, paste - TODO management: cycle states, set priorities - Planning: add s

entries.heading: Why Use Speed Commands?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:44] - *Efficiency*: Single keystrokes instead of multi-key combinations - *Contextual*: Only active at heading starts, so no conflicts with normal typing - *Discoverable*: Press `?' at a heading start to see all available commands - *Emacs-compatible*: Familiar workflow for Emacs org-mode users

entries.heading: Enabling Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:44] Speed commands are enabled by default in Scimax VS Code. To toggle them on or off:

entries.heading: Via Settings UI
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:44] 1. Open VS Code Settings (C-, or s-, on Mac) 2. Search for "speed commands" 3. Toggle the checkbox for *Scimax: Speed Commands > Enabled*

entries.heading: Via settings.json
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] Add or modify this setting in your `settings.json': #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.speedCommands.enabled": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Via Command Palette
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] 1. Open Command Palette (C-S-P or s-S-P on Mac) 2. Type "speed" and select *Scimax: Toggle Speed Commands*

entries.heading: Supported File Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] Speed commands work in: - Org-mode files (`.org') - Markdown files (`.md', `.markdown')

entries.heading: When Speed Commands are Active
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] Speed commands are only active when *all* of the following conditions are met: 1. *Speed commands are enabled* in settings (`scimax.speedCommands.enabled: true') 2. *Cursor is at column 0* (the very beginning of the line) 3. *Line is a heading* (starts with `*' for org-mode or `#' for markdown) 4. *No text is selected* (cursor position only, not a selection)

entries.heading: Visual Indicator
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] When speed commands are active, you'll notice that single key presses trigger actions immediately. If speed commands aren't working: 1. Check that your cursor is at position 0 (before the first `*' or `#') 2. Ensure no text is selected 3. Verify the file type is org or markdown 4. Check settings to confirm speed commands are enabled

entries.heading: Speed Command Reference
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] This section provides a complete listing of all available speed commands, organized by functional category.

entries.heading: Navigation Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:45] Move efficiently through your document structure. | Key | Command            | Description                                       | |-----+--------------------+---------------------------------------------------| | n   | Next heading       | Move to the next visible heading at any level     | | p   | Previous heading   | Move to the previous visible heading at any level | | f   | Next sibling       | Move to next heading at the same level            | | b   | Previo

entries.heading: Go To Submenu Options
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:46] The `g' key opens a submenu with additional navigation choices: | Key | Command             | Description                       | |-----+---------------------+-----------------------------------| | n   | Next heading        | Next visible heading              | | p   | Previous heading    | Previous visible heading          | | f   | Next sibling        | Next heading at same level        | | b   | Previous sibling    | Previous heading at same level    | | u   | P

entries.heading: Visibility/Folding Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:46] Control how much content is visible in your document. | Key | Command                 | Description                                   | |-----+-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------| | c   | Cycle global visibility | Cycle through: overview  contents  show all | | C   | Show all children       | Unfold all children of current subtree        | | o   | Overview                | Fold all headings (show only top-level)       | | <ta

entries.heading: Structure Editing Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:38] Reorganize and modify your document structure. | Key | Command              | Description                                    | |-----+----------------------+------------------------------------------------| | U   | Move subtree up      | Move entire subtree (and children) up          | | D   | Move subtree down    | Move entire subtree (and children) down        | | r   | Demote heading       | Decrease level of heading only (shift right)   | | l   | Promote headin

entries.heading: Structure Editing Notes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:47] - *Promote* (left) decreases the heading level (fewer stars/hashes) - *Demote* (right) increases the heading level (more stars/hashes) - Lowercase `l'/`r' affect only the heading line - Uppercase `L'/`R' affect the entire subtree (heading and children) - `y' (yank) intelligently adjusts heading levels to match context - `k' kills (cuts) the subtree, matching Emacs scimax - `w' refiles the subtree, matching Emacs org-mode - `m' and `@' both mark (select) the subtree

entries.heading: Sorting Entries (^)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-27 Tue 18:13] The `^' speed command sorts child entries of the current heading. When invoked, it presents a menu of sorting criteria: | Key | Sort Type                          | |-----+------------------------------------| | a/A | Alphabetically (A = reverse)       | | n/N | Numerically (by leading number)    | | t/T | By timestamp (first in entry)      | | d/D | By DEADLINE date                   | | s/S | By SCHEDULED date                  | | p/P | By priority ([#A], [#B], [

entries.heading: TODO and Priority Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:47] Manage task states and priorities. | Key | Command           | Description                                  | |-----+-------------------+----------------------------------------------| | t   | Cycle TODO state  | Cycle through: (none)  TODO  DONE  (none) | | ,   | Cycle priority up | Increase priority: C  B  A                 | | 1   | Priority [#A]     | Set priority to A (highest)                  | | 2   | Priority [#B]     | Set priority to B (medium)

entries.heading: Priority System
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:47] Org-mode uses a three-level priority system: - *[#A]* - High priority (critical, urgent) - *[#B]* - Medium priority (normal importance) - *[#C]* - Low priority (nice to have) Priorities appear after the TODO keyword: `** TODO [#A] Important task'

entries.heading: Planning/Timestamp Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:47] Add scheduling and deadline information to tasks. | Key | Command            | Description                            | |-----+--------------------+----------------------------------------| | s   | Add/edit SCHEDULED | Set when you plan to work on this task | | d   | Add/edit DEADLINE  | Set when this task must be completed   | | .   | Insert timestamp   | Insert an inactive timestamp at point  |

entries.heading: Timestamp Types
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:38] - *SCHEDULED*: When you plan to start working on the task - Format: `SCHEDULED: <2026-01-13 Mon>' - Appears in agenda on the scheduled date - *DEADLINE*: When the task must be completed - Format: `DEADLINE: <2026-01-20 Mon>' - Appears in agenda with warnings before due date - *Plain timestamp*: Reference dates, events, notes - Format: `[2026-01-13 Mon 14:30]' - For documentation purposes

entries.heading: Metadata Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:38] :PROPERTIES: :Effort: 0:15 :END: Add tags, properties, and effort estimates to headings. | Key | Command      | Description                                    | |-----+--------------+------------------------------------------------| | :   | Set tags     | Add or modify tags (colon-separated)           | | e   | Set effort   | Set estimated effort/duration for task         | | P   | Set property | Set a custom property in the properties drawer |

entries.heading: Tags
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:48] Tags are keywords attached to headings for categorization and filtering: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: TODO Complete documentation :work:urgent:docs:
entries.content: #+END_EXAMPLE Tags are: - Separated by colons (`:') - Can contain letters, numbers, and special chars (`_@#%') - Inherited by child headings - Used for agenda filtering and searches - Automatically aligned to column 77 (Emacs-style)

entries.heading: Effort Estimates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:48] Effort is stored as a property in `H:MM' format: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: TODO Write documentation
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :Effort: 2:00 :END: #+END_EXAMPLE Common effort values: - `0:15' - 15 minutes - `0:30' - 30 minutes - `1:00' - 1 hour - `2:00' - 2 hours - `4:00' - Half day - `8:00' - Full day

entries.heading: Properties
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:48] Properties are key-value pairs stored in a properties drawer: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Research Project
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: research-2026 :CATEGORY: Research :Effort: 8:00 :ASSIGNED: John Doe :END: #+END_EXAMPLE Common property names: - `ID' - Unique identifier - `CUSTOM_ID' - User-defined ID for linking - `CATEGORY' - Category for agenda display - `Effort' - Estimated effort - `LOGGING' - Log state changes - `COLUMNS' - Column view format

entries.heading: Clocking Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:48] Track time spent on tasks. | Key | Command   | Description                          | |-----+-----------+--------------------------------------| | I   | Clock in  | Start time tracking for current task | | O   | Clock out | Stop time tracking                   |

entries.heading: Clocking Workflow
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:48] 1. Position cursor at column 0 of a task heading 2. Press `I' to clock in - starts timer 3. Work on the task 4. Press `O' to clock out - stops timer and records duration Clock entries are stored in a `:LOGBOOK:' drawer: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Clocking Notes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:37] - Only one task can be clocked in at a time - Clocking in a new task automatically clocks out the previous one - Clock duration is automatically calculated - Clock data is used for time reports and agenda views

entries.heading: Archive Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] Move completed tasks to archive storage. | Key | Command              | Description                                     | |-----+----------------------+-------------------------------------------------| | a   | Archive subtree      | Move subtree to archive file                    | | A   | Toggle :ARCHIVE: tag | Add/remove ARCHIVE tag (marks for archiving)    | | $   | Archive to sibling   | Move subtree under an "Archive" sibling heading |

entries.heading: Archive File
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] By default, `a' moves the subtree to a file named `{basename}_archive.org': - `notes.org'  `notes_archive.org' - `projects.org'  `projects_archive.org' The archived subtree is tagged with `:ARCHIVE:' and includes metadata: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: DONE Completed project :ARCHIVE:
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :ARCHIVE_TIME: [2026-01-13 Mon 15:30] :ARCHIVE_FILE: ~/org/projects.org :END: #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Learning the Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] 1. *Start with navigation*: `n', `p', `f', `b', `u' are the most frequently used 2. *Use the help*: Press `?' at any heading start to see all commands 3. *Muscle memory*: The keys are mnemonic: - `n' ` next, `p' ' previous, `f' ` forward, `b' ' backward - `u' = up (parent) - `t' ` TODO, `s' ' schedule, `d' = deadline - `I'/`O' = In/Out (clocking) - `l'/`r' = left/right (promote/demote)

entries.heading: Quick Task Management
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] 1. Create heading with `C-<return>' 2. Move to beginning of line (`Home' or `C-a') 3. Press `t' to add TODO state 4. Press `1' to set high priority 5. Press `s' to schedule it 6. Press `:' to add tags

entries.heading: Organizing Content
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] 1. Navigate to a heading 2. Use `U'/`D' to reorder siblings 3. Use `l'/`r' to adjust hierarchy 4. Use `k' to cut and `y' to paste sections 5. Use `w' to refile sections to another location 6. Use `^' to sort child entries 7. Use `a' to archive completed work

entries.heading: Reviewing Documents
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] 1. Press `o' to see overview (all headings folded) 2. Use `n'/`p' to navigate between sections 3. Press `Tab' to expand interesting sections 4. Press `c' to cycle through visibility levels

entries.heading: Combining with Regular Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] Speed commands complement (don't replace) regular keybindings: - Use speed commands for quick operations when cursor is at heading start - Use regular keybindings (`C-c C-t', etc.) when cursor is elsewhere - Use `C-a' or `Home' to quickly jump to column 0 to activate speed commands

entries.heading: Cursor Position Matters
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] Remember: speed commands *only* work at column 0. If a speed command doesn't trigger: 1. Press `Home' or `C-a' to move to beginning of line 2. Verify you're on a heading line (starts with `*' or `#') 3. Check that no text is selected

entries.heading: Customization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:50] Currently, speed command keys are pre-defined and cannot be customized. The key mappings follow standard Emacs org-mode conventions for consistency and muscle memory compatibility. If you need custom keybindings, use VS Code's keybinding system to bind the underlying commands (e.g., `scimax.org.nextHeading', `scimax.org.cycleTodo') to your preferred key combinations.

entries.heading: Reference: All Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:52] Complete alphabetical reference of all speed commands. | Key | Category   | Command                 | |-----+------------+-------------------------| | ,   | TODO       | Cycle priority up       | | .   | Planning   | Insert timestamp        | | 0   | TODO       | Remove priority         | | 1   | TODO       | Set priority [#A]       | | 2   | TODO       | Set priority [#B]       | | 3   | TODO       | Set priority [#C]       | | :   | Metadata   | Set tags

entries.heading: Speed Commands Not Working
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:52] *Problem*: Pressing keys doesn't trigger speed commands *Solutions*: 1. Verify cursor is at column 0 (before the `*' or `#') 2. Check file type is `.org' or `.md' 3. Ensure no text is selected 4. Verify speed commands are enabled: `scimax.speedCommands.enabled: true' 5. Restart VS Code after changing settings

entries.heading: Wrong Command Executes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:52] *Problem*: Different command executes than expected *Solutions*: 1. Press `?' to see command list and verify key mapping 2. Check for conflicting VS Code keybindings 3. Ensure you're in an org or markdown file 4. Update extension to latest version

entries.heading: Help Menu Shows Wrong Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-15 Thu 14:52] *Problem*: Help menu (`?') shows outdated information *Solution*: The help is generated from code, so this shouldn't occur. If it does, report as a bug.

entries.heading: BibTeX Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:22] :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: bibtex-speed-commands :END: BibTeX speed commands provide single-key shortcuts for navigating and manipulating BibTeX entries when editing `.bib' files. These commands are active when the cursor is at column 0 of a line starting with `@' (entry definition line).

entries.heading: Activation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:22] BibTeX speed commands are active when: 1. You are editing a `.bib' file 2. Cursor is at column 0 3. Line starts with `@' (e.g., `@article{', `@book{') 4. Speed commands are enabled in settings

entries.heading: Command Reference
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:22] | Key | Category    | Command                  | |-----+-------------+--------------------------| | n   | Navigation  | Next entry               | | p   | Navigation  | Previous entry           | | j   | Navigation  | Jump to entry (search)   | | s   | Formatting  | Sort fields in entry     | | d   | Formatting  | Downcase entry           | | t   | Formatting  | Title case article title | | S   | Formatting  | Sentence case title      | | c   | Formatting  | Clean/

entries.heading: Next Entry (n)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Jump to the next BibTeX entry in the file. #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE @article{smith2020, title = {First Article} } <- press n here @book{jones2021,       <- cursor moves here title = {Second Book} } #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Previous Entry (p)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Jump to the previous BibTeX entry in the file.

entries.heading: Jump to Entry (j)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Opens a quick pick dialog showing all entries in the file. Search by key, author, or title.

entries.heading: Sort Fields (s)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Reorders fields in the current entry according to the standard BibLaTeX field order: 1. author, title, journaltitle/journal, booktitle 2. editor, edition, volume, number, pages 3. publisher, location/address, year, date 4. doi, url, isbn/issn 5. note, abstract, keywords

entries.heading: Downcase Entry (d)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Converts entry type and field names to lowercase: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE Before: @ARTICLE{key, AUTHOR = {Name}} After:  @article{key, author = {Name}} #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Title Case (t)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Converts the article title to Title Case, preserving braced content like `{DNA}' or `{LaTeX}'.

entries.heading: Sentence Case (S)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Converts the article title to Sentence case (only first letter capitalized), preserving braced content.

entries.heading: Clean Entry (c)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Applies all cleaning operations: - Normalizes whitespace - Downcases entry type and field names - Sorts fields - Removes double braces

entries.heading: Open PDF (o)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Attempts to open the PDF associated with the entry: 1. Checks the `file' field in the entry 2. Looks in the configured PDF directory 3. Offers to open DOI in browser if no PDF found

entries.heading: Open URL/DOI (u)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Opens the URL or DOI associated with the entry: - Prefers DOI if available - Falls back to URL field - Supports arXiv eprint field

entries.heading: Open Notes (N)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Opens or creates notes for the entry. Notes are stored as org files in the configured notes directory.

entries.heading: Google Scholar (g)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Searches Google Scholar for the entry using DOI or title.

entries.heading: CrossRef (x)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Opens the entry in CrossRef search using the DOI.

entries.heading: Web of Science (w)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Opens the entry in Web of Science using the DOI.

entries.heading: Copy Key (y)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:23] Copies the citation key to the clipboard.

entries.heading: Copy BibTeX (b)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] Copies the entire BibTeX entry to the clipboard.

entries.heading: Kill Entry (k)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] Deletes the entire entry (with confirmation). The deleted entry is copied to the clipboard for easy recovery.

entries.heading: Generate Citation Key (K)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] Generates a standardized citation key from the entry's author and year fields. Offers multiple format options: - =lastname-year= (e.g., =smith-2020=) - =lastname-titleword-year= (e.g., =smith-machine-2020=) - =lastname-titlewords-year= (e.g., =smith-machine-learning-2020=) Features: - Extracts first author's last name from various formats ("John Smith", "Smith, John") - Removes stop words from title (the, a, an, using, novel, etc.) - *Checks for uniqueness* against

entries.heading: Show Help (?)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] Displays a quick pick menu with all available BibTeX speed commands. Select a command to execute it.

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] BibTeX speed commands use the same enable/disable setting as org-mode speed commands: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.speedCommands.enabled": true } #+END_SRC For PDF and notes access, configure: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.ref.pdfDirectory": "~/Papers", "scimax.ref.notesDirectory": "~/Notes/papers" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Comparison with Emacs org-ref
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:24] These BibTeX speed commands are inspired by the functions in Emacs `org-ref-bibtex.el': | Scimax       | Emacs org-ref Function           | |--------------+----------------------------------| | n            | org-ref-bibtex-next-entry        | | p            | org-ref-bibtex-previous-entry    | | s            | org-ref-sort-bibtex-entry        | | d            | org-ref-downcase-bibtex-entry    | | t            | org-ref-title-case-article       | | S            |

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: This document provides a comprehensive reference for all keybindings in Scimax VS Code. The extension brings Emacs-style org-mode functionality to Visual Studio Code, with keybindings designed to match the familiar Emacs Scimax experience. *Note for Mac Users:* On macOS, most keybindings use Ctrl (not Cmd) to match Emacs conventions, except where explicitly noted with alternative Mac bindings.

entries.heading: Global Commands
entries.content: | Key         | Action                              | |-------------+-------------------------------------| | C-S-j       | Open today's journal entry          | | s-S-j       | (Mac) Open today's journal entry    | | C-c m       | Show Hydra main menu                | | C-c C-m     | Show Hydra context menu             | | C-c d       | Show database hydra menu            | | C-c c       | Quick capture                       | | C-c t       | Quick capture TODO                  | | C-M-v

entries.heading: Help Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 13:38] Emacs-style help commands for discovering keybindings and commands. | Key   | Action                                                | |-------+-------------------------------------------------------| | C-h k | Describe key - type a key sequence to see its command | | C-h b | List keybindings - browse all keybindings             | | C-h f | Describe command - select a command to see its keys   | | C-h v | Describe variable - view setting details              | | C-h

entries.heading: C-h k (Describe Key)
entries.content: Type a key sequence using either Emacs notation (`C-c C-c', `M-x') or VS Code notation (`ctrl+c ctrl+c', `alt+x') to see what command it is bound to. Shows the command ID, title, and any context conditions (`when' clause).

entries.heading: C-h b (List Keybindings)
entries.content: Browse all scimax keybindings in a searchable list. Filter by typing to find keybindings. Select an entry to see full details or execute the command.

entries.heading: C-h f (Describe Command)
entries.content: Search for a command by name and see its keybindings. Useful when you know what you want to do but not the keybinding.

entries.heading: C-h v (Describe Variable/Setting)
entries.content: Browse all scimax settings with completion. Shows the setting type, default value, current value, and description. Actions include opening VS Code Settings to modify the value.

entries.heading: C-h a (Apropos)
entries.content: Search the documentation for keywords. Enter one or more search terms to find relevant documentation sections. Results are ranked by relevance: - Heading matches score highest - Command and keybinding mentions score high - Keyword and content matches score lower Select a result to see details or open the documentation file at that location.

entries.heading: Speed Commands
entries.content: Speed commands are single-key shortcuts available when the cursor is at the *beginning* of a heading (the first character of the heading line). They must be enabled in settings (scimax.speedCommands.enabled).

entries.heading: Navigation Speed Commands
entries.content: | Key | Action                            | |-----+-----------------------------------| | n   | Next heading (same level)         | | p   | Previous heading (same level)     | | f   | Next sibling heading              | | b   | Previous sibling heading          | | u   | Parent heading (up one level)     | | j   | Jump to heading (quick picker)    | | g   | Goto menu (additional navigation) |

entries.heading: Visibility Speed Commands
entries.content: | Key   | Action                            | |-------+-----------------------------------| | <tab> | Toggle fold (same as regular tab) | | c     | Cycle global fold                 | | C     | Show children only                | | o     | Overview (collapse all)           | | 1     | Show level 1 headings             | | 2     | Show level 2 headings             | | 3     | Show level 3 headings             | | 0     | Show all headings                 | | N     | Narrow to subtree

entries.heading: Structure Editing Speed Commands

entries.heading: Context-Dependent Keybindings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:19] Many keybindings are context-aware and behave differently depending on cursor position: - C-c C-c toggles checkboxes normally, executes source blocks inside code blocks, and recalculates tables on TBLFM lines - S-<arrow> keys modify timestamps normally, but transpose/sort citations when on a citation - M-S-<left>/M-S-<right> promote/demote subtrees normally, but delete/insert columns when in a table - <return> opens links when cursor is on a link

entries.heading: When Conditions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:19] Some keybindings only work in specific contexts: - Org-mode/Markdown files: Most document structure commands - On headings: Folding, promotion, demotion - In tables: Table-specific commands - In source blocks: Block execution - At heading start: Speed commands

entries.heading: Mac vs Windows/Linux
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:19] Most keybindings use C- (Ctrl) on all platforms to match Emacs conventions. Exceptions where Mac uses s- (Cmd): - s-S-j (journal) - s-<return> (execute/insert heading) - s-S-k (delete citation) - s-S-r (reload window) - C-s-v (database menu)

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 12:23] This document provides a comprehensive reference of all commands available in the Scimax VS Code extension. Commands are organized by feature area for easy lookup. *Note on Keybindings:* All keybindings shown use the format key for standard keys and C-x for C-x (or s-x on macOS). When (org) or (md) appears, the binding is context-sensitive.

entries.heading: scimax.help.describeCommand
entries.content: Shows the keybindings for a specific command. Useful for learning keyboard shortcuts.

entries.heading: scimax.help.describeKey
entries.content: Describes what a specific key combination does. Enter the key sequence to see its bound command.

entries.heading: scimax.help.listKeybindings
entries.content: Lists all keybindings defined by the extension. Opens a quick pick to browse available shortcuts.

entries.heading: scimax.help.describeVariable
entries.content: Browse all scimax settings with completion. Shows the setting type, default value, current value, and description. Select a setting to open VS Code Settings.

entries.heading: scimax.help.apropos
entries.content: Search the documentation for keywords. Enter search terms to find relevant documentation sections. Results are ranked by relevance (headings, commands, keybindings, content). Select a result to view details or open the documentation file.

entries.heading: scimax.update

Fetches the latest release from the [[https://github.com/jkitchin/scimax_vscode][GitHub repository]] 2. Shows the current version vs. the latest available version 3. Downloads the VSIX file with progress indication 4. Installs it using VS Code's extension manager 5. Offers to reload VS Code to activate the new version This provides an easy way to update without leaving VS Code. Requires the repository to

entries.heading: Linting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:59] :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: linting :END: Commands for checking org-mode document quality. | Command ID                     | Description        | Default Keybinding | |--------------------------------+--------------------+--------------------| | [[cmd:scimax.org.lint]]        | Run Linter         | -                  | | [[cmd:scimax.org.lintCheckers]]| Show Lint Checkers | -                  |

entries.heading: scimax.org.lint
entries.content: Runs the org-mode linter on the current document. The linter checks for: - Duplicate IDs - Broken internal links - Missing TODO keywords in sequences - Unbalanced brackets and quotes - Invalid timestamps - Missing required properties - And more Results appear in the Problems panel.

entries.heading: scimax.org.lintCheckers
entries.content: Shows available lint checkers and allows enabling/disabling specific checks.

entries.heading: Mark Ring
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: mark-ring :END: Emacs-style mark ring for navigation and selection. Save cursor positions (marks) and return to them later. Each document has its own mark ring, plus there's a global mark ring that tracks positions across all documents. | Command ID                       | Description               | Default Keybinding | |----------------------------------+---------------------------+--------------------| | [[cmd:scimax.mark.set]]          | Set Mark (for selection)  | C

entries.heading: Mark Ring Concepts
entries.content: - **Mark**: A saved cursor position that you can return to - **Point**: The current cursor position - **Mark Ring**: A stack of marks (per-document), most recent first (default size: 16) - **Global Mark Ring**: A cross-file stack of marks for navigating between documents - **Selection Mode**: When mark is set, cursor movement extends the selection from the mark

entries.heading: Setting a Mark for Selection
entries.content: 1. Press =C-SPC= to set mark at current position (line flashes briefly as feedback) 2. Move cursor to end of desired selection - the region automatically expands 3. Press =C-SPC= again to deactivate selection mode (toggle behavior) 4. Press =C-g= to cancel selection and collapse to cursor position

entries.heading: Returning to Previous Positions
entries.content: 1. Press =C-SPC C-SPC= to push mark without activating selection mode 2. Navigate elsewhere in the file 3. Press =C-u C-SPC= to pop the most recent mark and jump to it 4. Current position is saved before jumping, so you can return with another pop

entries.heading: Cross-file Navigation
entries.content: 1. Marks are automatically pushed to the global ring when set 2. Press =C-x C-SPC= to pop from global mark ring and jump (can cross files) 3. Use =C-x C-x= to exchange point and mark (swap current position with last mark)

entries.heading: Viewing the Mark Ring
entries.content: 1. Run =scimax.mark.show= from command palette 2. Quick pick shows local marks and global marks with line previews 3. Select an entry to jump to that position 4. Timestamps show how long ago each mark was set

entries.heading: Publishing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 10:02] :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: publishing :END: Commands for publishing org files to HTML, creating static sites similar to Emacs org-publish. | Command ID                        | Description                   | Default Keybinding | |-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------| | [[cmd:scimax.publish.init]]       | Initialize Publishing Project | -                  | | [[cmd:scimax.publish.project]]    | Publish Project

entries.heading: Setting Up a Publishing Project
entries.content: 1. Run =scimax.publish.init= to create a publishing configuration 2. Configure the project in the generated =.org-publish.json= file 3. Use =scimax.publish.project= to publish the configured project

entries.heading: Publishing Configuration
entries.content: The =.org-publish.json= file configures: - Source directory for org files - Output directory for HTML - Include/exclude patterns - HTML template settings - Asset handling (CSS, images)

entries.heading: Query Replace
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 10:02] :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: query-replace :END: Interactive search and replace. | Command ID                  | Description   | Default Keybinding | |-----------------------------+---------------+--------------------| | [[cmd:scimax.queryReplace]] | Query Replace | M-%                | Provides Emacs-style interactive query-replace with confirmation for each replacement.

entries.heading: Utilities
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 13:21] :PROPERTIES: :CUSTOM_ID: utilities :END: Miscellaneous utility commands. | Command ID                       | Description                       | Default Keybinding | |----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+--------------------| | [[cmd:scimax.openFolder]]        | Open Folder                       | -                  | | [[cmd:scimax.dired.open]]        | Open Dired (Directory Editor)     | C-x d              | | [[cmd:scimax.dired

entries.heading: Dired Commands
entries.content: Dired (Directory Editor) provides Emacs-style file management. Open with =C-x d= and use these keys in the dired panel: - Navigation: =n/p= (next/prev), =RET= (open), =^= (parent), =g= (refresh) - Marking: =m= (mark), =u= (unmark), =U= (unmark all), =t= (toggle marks) - Operations: =D= (delete), =C= (copy), =R= (rename/move), =+= (create directory) - WDired: =C-x C-q= (enter edit mode), =C-c C-c= (commit), =C-c C-k= (cancel) See [[file:37-dired.org][Dired documentation]] for full details.

entries.heading: scimax.replaceNonAscii
entries.content: Replaces common non-ASCII characters (smart quotes, em-dashes, etc.) with their ASCII equivalents. Useful for preparing documents for systems that don't handle Unicode well.

entries.heading: scimax.showDebugInfo
entries.content: Displays diagnostic information about the scimax extension, including version, enabled features, and configuration state. Useful for troubleshooting.

For configuration options, see the VS Code settings under scimax.*. For more information about the Scimax VS Code extension, visit the project repository.
