entries.content: - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Code Blocks]] - Executing code in org documents - [[file:03-todo-items.org][TODO Items]] - Task management - [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Headlines and navigation - [[file:06-timestamps.org][Timestamps]] - Dates, scheduling, and clocking

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: - Previous: [[file:26-configuration.org][Configuration]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:28-non-standard-features.org][Non-Standard Features]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:08] Scimax VS Code implements several features that are *not part* of the official org-mode syntax specification at https://orgmode.org/worg/org-syntax.html. These features are inspired by Emacs packages like org-ref and scimax, and provide additional functionality for scientific writing. This document describes these non-standard features and their behavior during export.

entries.heading: org-ref Citation Links
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:15] The citation system (`cite:', `citet:', `citep:', etc.) comes from the org-ref package for Emacs, not from core org-mode.

entries.heading: Citation Styles
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:15] | Style           | Syntax              | Description                    | |-----------------+---------------------+--------------------------------| | cite            | cite:key            | Basic citation                 | | citet           | citet:key           | Textual citation (Author, Year)| | citep           | citep:key           | Parenthetical citation         | | citeauthor      | citeauthor:key      | Author name only               | | citeyear        |

entries.heading: LaTeX/PDF Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:16] Citations are converted directly to LaTeX cite commands: | Org Citation     | LaTeX Output        | |------------------+---------------------| | cite:key         | \cite{key}          | | citet:key        | \citet{key}         | | citep:key        | \citep{key}         | | citeauthor:key   | \citeauthor{key}    | | citeyear:key     | \citeyear{key}      | | cite:k1,k2       | \cite{k1,k2}        | Requires `natbib' or `biblatex' package in your LaTeX preamble.

entries.heading: HTML Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:16] Citations are rendered as clickable links with CSS classes for styling.

entries.heading: Markdown Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:16] Citations are converted to Pandoc-style citations: | Org Citation     | Pandoc Markdown     | |------------------+---------------------| | cite:key         | [@key]              | | citet:key        | @key                | | citep:key        | [@key]              | | cite:k1,k2       | [@k1; @k2]          |

entries.heading: Compatibility Notes
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:16] - Emacs org-mode users will find this syntax familiar - Standard org-mode uses `[[cite:@key]]' syntax (org-cite) which is also supported - The org-ref style `cite:key' is more concise for scientific writing See [[file:19-references.org][References]] for full documentation.

entries.heading: Emacs-style Command Markup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:17] The command markup syntax `command' (backtick  text  single quote) is used in Emacs documentation to reference commands, functions, and key sequences. This renders with dark red highlighting in the editor (with the Leuven theme).

entries.heading: Keybinding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:17] | Key   | Command                 | Description          | |-------+-------------------------+----------------------| | C-c ' | scimax.markup.command   | Insert command markup| When text is selected, it wraps the selection. Otherwise, it inserts the markers and positions the cursor between them.

entries.heading: HTML Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:17] Command markup is exported as `<kbd>' elements: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE `my-command'  <kbd>my-command</kbd> #+END_EXAMPLE The `<kbd>' element is semantically appropriate for keyboard input and command names.

entries.heading: LaTeX Export
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:17] Command markup is exported as `\texttt{}': #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE `my-command'  \texttt{my-command} #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Why Non-Standard?
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:18] - This syntax is not part of the org-mode specification - Standard org code markup uses ~code~ or =verbatim= - The ``command'' style is specific to Emacs/Elisp documentation conventions - We implement it for Emacs users who are familiar with this convention and because we think it looks nicer.

entries.heading: Alternatives
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:18] If you need portable org documents, use standard markup: | Our Syntax  | Standard Alternative | Description          | |-------------+----------------------+----------------------| | `command'   | ~command~            | Org code markup      | | `command'   | =command=            | Org verbatim markup  |

entries.heading: Future Non-Standard Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:19] This section will be updated as additional non-standard features are added.

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:19] - [[file:19-references.org][References]] - Full citation and bibliography documentation - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - Export to HTML, LaTeX, PDF - [[file:24-keybindings.org][Keybindings]] - All keyboard shortcuts

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 11:19] - Previous: [[file:27-org-api.org][Org API]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]]

entries.heading: Link Folding (Descriptive Links)
entries.content: In Emacs org-mode, links with descriptions like =[[https://example.com][Example]]= can be displayed in a "folded" state showing only "Example" with the URL hidden. The full link is revealed on cursor hover or edit. *VS Code limitation*: VS Code does not support this kind of dynamic text folding. Links are always displayed in their full form: =[[https://example.com][Example]]=. *Workaround*: None. You can use the hover preview to see a clickable version of the link.

entries.heading: Inline Image Display
entries.content: In Emacs org-mode, images can be displayed inline within the buffer using =org-toggle-inline-images= (=C-c C-x C-v=). Images appear directly in the text where the link is. *VS Code limitation*: VS Code's text editor does not support embedding images within the text buffer. *Workaround*: Scimax-vscode provides: - Hover tooltips that show image previews when you hover over image links - Gutter icons for source block output images - The Image Overlay panel (=Ctrl+Shift+I=) for viewing all images in

entries.heading: LaTeX Fragment Preview
entries.content: In Emacs org-mode, LaTeX fragments like =\(E=mc^2\)= or =\begin{equation}...= can be rendered as images inline using =org-latex-preview=. *VS Code limitation*: No inline LaTeX rendering in the editor. *Workaround*: - Use the LaTeX Live Preview panel (=Ctrl+Shift+L=) to see rendered LaTeX - Hover over LaTeX fragments to see a preview - Export to PDF/HTML to see rendered math

entries.heading: Indirect Buffers for Source Blocks
entries.content: In Emacs, =org-edit-special= (=C-c '=) opens source blocks in a separate "indirect buffer" with the appropriate major mode. This provides full language support (completion, syntax checking, etc.) while maintaining the connection to the original org file. *VS Code limitation*: VS Code does not have the concept of indirect buffers. *Workaround*: Scimax-vscode provides: - Syntax highlighting for source blocks via embedded language grammars - Language-specific completions within source blocks (parti

entries.heading: Column View
entries.content: In Emacs org-mode, =org-columns= provides a spreadsheet-like view of headline properties in a columnar format, useful for project planning and time tracking. *VS Code limitation*: Not implemented. VS Code's editor model doesn't easily support this overlay-style interface. *Workaround*: Use the Agenda view or database search to query and view properties.

entries.heading: Visible-Only Export
entries.content: In Emacs org-mode, you can export only the visible (non-folded) content using =C-c C-e= and selecting the "visible" scope. *VS Code limitation*: The "visible" export option is defined but not yet implemented. VS Code's folding model is different from Emacs, making it difficult to determine what content is "visible". *Workaround*: Use subtree export to export specific sections, or manually narrow your document.

entries.heading: Additional Export Backends
entries.content: The following org-mode export backends are not implemented: | Backend     | Description                    | Alternative                    | |-------------+--------------------------------+--------------------------------| | ODT         | LibreOffice/OpenDocument       | Export to HTML, convert        | | ASCII       | Plain text export              | Export to Markdown             | | Beamer      | LaTeX presentations            | Use standard LaTeX with Beamer | | iCalendar   | Calendar expor

entries.heading: Unsupported Languages
entries.content: The following org-babel languages are not yet implemented: - Ruby - Perl - C/C++ - Go - Rust - Gnuplot - Ditaa (ASCII diagrams) - Dot/Graphviz - Octave/MATLAB - LaTeX (as executable blocks) - Haskell - Clojure - Scheme/Racket *Workaround*: Use Jupyter kernels where available (e.g., =jupyter-rust=, =jupyter-go=).

entries.heading: Emacs Lisp Execution
entries.content: Emacs Lisp (=elisp=) blocks have only stub support since there's no Emacs Lisp interpreter in VS Code. *Workaround*: None for elisp-specific code. Consider porting logic to JavaScript/TypeScript.

entries.heading: Error Line Jumping
entries.content: In scimax, clicking on error messages in results jumps to the corresponding line in the source block. *VS Code limitation*: Not implemented.

entries.heading: Custom Agenda Views
entries.content: Emacs org-agenda supports highly customizable agenda views with complex matching criteria, custom sorting, and display options via =org-agenda-custom-commands=. *VS Code limitation*: Only basic agenda views (day/week/month, TODO list, tag filter) are supported. *Workaround*: Use database search with custom queries for complex filtering.

entries.heading: Agenda Follow Mode
entries.content: In Emacs, =org-agenda-follow-mode= shows the corresponding org file location as you move through agenda items. *VS Code limitation*: Not implemented as a live-updating side-by-side view. *Workaround*: Click on agenda items to navigate to their location.

entries.heading: Org-Crypt (Encryption)
entries.content: Emacs org-mode supports encrypting subtrees with GPG via =org-crypt=. *VS Code limitation*: Not implemented.

entries.heading: Org-Attach (Attachments)
entries.content: The =org-attach= system for managing file attachments to headlines is not implemented. *Workaround*: Use regular file links and organize attachments manually.

entries.heading: Radio Targets
entries.content: Radio targets (=<<<target>>>=) that automatically create links throughout the document are not supported.

entries.heading: Footnote Renumbering
entries.content: Automatic footnote renumbering (=org-footnote-renumber-fn:N=) is not implemented.

entries.heading: Speed Keys Customization
entries.content: While speed commands are implemented, the set of available commands is fixed and cannot be customized like in Emacs.

entries.heading: Macros
entries.content: Org-mode macros (={{{macro(args)}}}=) are parsed but have limited expansion support.

entries.heading: Platform Differences
entries.content: These are not bugs but fundamental differences in how VS Code works compared to Emacs: | Feature              | Emacs                   | VS Code                        | |----------------------+-------------------------+--------------------------------| | Buffer model         | Indirect buffers        | Single file per editor         | | Text properties      | Per-character overlays  | Decorations API (limited)      | | Keyboard input       | Full control            | Limited by browser/Electro

entries.heading: Parser Safety Limits
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] To prevent crashes or unresponsiveness when opening malformed org files, the parser enforces several safety limits. These limits are set high enough that they should never affect legitimate files.

entries.heading: Heading Nesting Depth
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] *Limit*: 100 levels maximum *Rationale*: Prevents stack overflow from deeply nested headings. Real org files rarely exceed 10 levels of nesting. *What happens*: Headings beyond 100 levels deep are not included in search results or the document outline.

entries.heading: Block Line Limits
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] *Limit*: 50,000 lines per block *Affected blocks*: - Source blocks (=#+BEGIN_SRC= ... =#+END_SRC=) - Quote blocks (=#+BEGIN_QUOTE= ... =#+END_QUOTE=) - Example blocks (=#+BEGIN_EXAMPLE= ... =#+END_EXAMPLE=) - Export blocks (=#+BEGIN_EXPORT= ... =#+END_EXPORT=) - Special blocks (=#+BEGIN_name= ... =#+END_name=) - LaTeX environments (=\begin{env}= ... =\end{env}=) - Drawers (=:DRAWER:= ... =:END:=) - Dynamic blocks (=#+BEGIN:= ... =#+END:=) *Rationale*: Prevents unbo

entries.heading: Properties Drawer Limit
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] *Limit*: 1,000 lines *Rationale*: Properties drawers are typically small (<50 lines). A tighter limit catches unclosed drawers faster.

entries.heading: Tag Restrictions
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] *Limit*: 50 tags per heading *Allowed characters*: Letters, numbers, underscore (=_=), at-sign (=@=), hash (=#=), percent (=%=), hyphen (=-=) *Not allowed*: Spaces, colons, and most punctuation (=!=, =$=, =^=, =&=, =*=, etc.) *Rationale*: The previous tag parser used a regex pattern that could cause exponential backtracking (ReDoS) on malformed input like =:::::::::::::=. The character restrictions prevent this vulnerability while supporting all common tag formats.

entries.heading: Meeting :@office:2024:Q1_review:
entries.content: #+END_EXAMPLE *If you need exotic characters*: Tags with unsupported characters will not be recognized. Consider using standard alphanumeric tags with hyphens or underscores instead.

entries.heading: When Limits Are Hit
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] When any limit is reached: - The parser stops consuming input at the limit boundary - No error is thrown to the user - Parsing continues with remaining content - The file remains usable, just with incomplete parsing of the oversized element This "graceful degradation" approach ensures that even malformed files can be opened and edited, rather than causing the extension to crash or hang.

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:23] - [[file:10-export.org][Export System]] - What export features ARE supported - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Supported code execution features - [[file:08-supported-languages.org][Supported Languages]] - Languages with full Babel support - [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda]] - Available agenda features - [[file:28-non-standard-features.org][Non-Standard Features]] - VS Code-specific features not in Emacs

entries.heading: Introduction
entries.content: Scimax VS Code includes a command-line interface (CLI) that provides access to many features without needing to open VS Code. This is useful for: - Batch operations (exporting multiple files) - Integration with other tools and scripts - Quick lookups from the terminal - CI/CD pipelines for documentation The CLI reads from the same SQLite database that the VS Code extension builds, so you get consistent results between the editor and command line.

entries.heading: From the Extension
entries.content: If you have the extension installed, the CLI is included. After building the extension: #+begin_src bash # From the extension directory npm run compile # Run directly node out/cli/index.js --help # Or use npx (if in the extension directory) npx scimax --help #+end_src

entries.heading: Global Installation
entries.content: To use ~scimax~ from anywhere: #+begin_src bash # From the extension directory npm link # Now available globally scimax --help #+end_src To unlink later: #+begin_src bash npm unlink scimax-vscode #+end_src

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: The CLI looks for configuration in the following order: 1. =.scimax/config.json= in the current directory or parent directories 2. =.scimax/= directory (uses =org.db= inside it) 3. Falls back to =.scimax/org.db= in the current directory The database is created and maintained by VS Code when you open a folder with org files. The CLI primarily reads from this database.

entries.heading: Example config.json
entries.content: #+begin_src json { "dbPath": ".scimax/org.db", "rootDir": "." } #+end_src

entries.heading: Help
entries.content: #+begin_src bash scimax --help scimax <command> --help #+end_src

entries.heading: Agenda
entries.content: View scheduled items, deadlines, and TODO items. #+begin_src bash # Today's agenda scimax agenda today # Week view scimax agenda week # All TODO items scimax agenda todos # Filter by state scimax agenda todos --state NEXT # Overdue items scimax agenda overdue #+end_src

entries.heading: Output Example
entries.content: #+begin_example === Today's Agenda === TODO     Today    Review paper draft docs/paper.org:42 NEXT     Today    Submit grant proposal projects/grant.org:15 #+end_example

entries.heading: Search
entries.content: Full-text search across all indexed org files. #+begin_src bash # Basic search scimax search "machine learning" # Limit results scimax search "catalyst" --limit 10 # JSON output for scripting scimax search "python" --format json #+end_src

entries.heading: Output Example
entries.content: #+begin_example Searching for: "machine learning" Found 5 result(s): Neural Network Architecture (score: 12.34) projects/ml-notes.org:156 "...using machine learning techniques to..." Deep Learning Overview (score: 10.21) docs/tutorials/deep-learning.org:23 "...introduction to machine learning and..." #+end_example

entries.heading: Export
entries.content: Export org files to HTML, LaTeX, or PDF. #+begin_src bash # Export to HTML scimax export paper.org --format html # Export to LaTeX scimax export paper.org --format latex # Export to PDF (requires pdflatex/latexmk) scimax export paper.org --format pdf # Specify output file scimax export paper.org --format html --output build/paper.html # With bibliography scimax export paper.org --format html --bib references.bib # With specific CSL style scimax export paper.org --format html --bib refs.bib --csl

entries.heading: Citations
entries.content: Citation-related operations.

entries.heading: Extract Citations
entries.content: List all citation keys used in a document: #+begin_src bash scimax cite extract paper.org # JSON output scimax cite extract paper.org --format json #+end_src Output: #+begin_example Found 12 citation(s) with 8 unique key(s): doe-2020 jones-2021 smith-2019 ... #+end_example

entries.heading: Check Citations
entries.content: Validate citations against a bibliography file: #+begin_src bash scimax cite check paper.org --bib references.bib #+end_src Output: #+begin_example Citation Check: paper.org Citations found: 12 Bibliography entries: 15 MISSING (2 cited but not in .bib): - nonexistent-2020 - typo-key UNUSED (5 in .bib but not cited): - old-reference-2010 - unused-entry ... #+end_example This is useful in CI pipelines to catch citation errors before publishing.

entries.heading: Convert Citation Syntax
entries.content: Convert between org-ref v2, v3, and org-cite syntax: #+begin_src bash # Convert v2 to v3 scimax cite convert paper.org --from v2 --to v3 # Convert to org-cite scimax cite convert paper.org --from v3 --to org-cite # Modify file in place scimax cite convert paper.org --from v2 --to v3 --inplace # Output to new file scimax cite convert paper.org --from v2 --to v3 --output paper-v3.org #+end_src

entries.heading: List Bibliography
entries.content: List entries in a BibTeX file: #+begin_src bash scimax cite list references.bib # JSON output scimax cite list references.bib --format json #+end_src

entries.heading: Database
entries.content: Database maintenance operations.

entries.heading: Statistics
entries.content: Show database statistics: #+begin_src bash scimax db stats #+end_src Output: #+begin_example === Database Statistics === Database: .scimax/org.db Root: /home/user/project Files indexed: 42 Headings: 1,234 TODO items: 89 Has embeddings: No #+end_example

entries.heading: Check Integrity
entries.content: Check for missing or stale files: #+begin_src bash scimax db check #+end_src Output: #+begin_example Checking database integrity... MISSING: old-file.org MISSING: deleted-folder/notes.org Total files in database: 42 Missing files: 2 Open VS Code to rebuild the index. #+end_example

entries.heading: Rebuild
entries.content: Rebuild the database from org files. This parses all org files in the specified directory and indexes headings, source blocks, and links. #+begin_src bash # Rebuild from current directory scimax db rebuild # Rebuild from a specific path scimax db rebuild --path ./docs #+end_src Output: #+begin_example Rebuilding database from: /home/user/project Database path: .scimax/org.db Found 42 org file(s) to index. Indexing: notes/meeting.org... OK Indexing: docs/guide.org... OK Indexing: projects/paper.o

entries.heading: Scan Directory
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 20:57] Scan a specific directory and add its files to the database. This is a simplified command that takes the directory as a direct argument, making it ideal for cron jobs and scripts. #+begin_src bash # Scan a specific directory scimax db scan /path/to/org-files # Scan multiple directories (run sequentially) scimax db scan ~/work/org-files scimax db scan ~/personal/notes #+end_src Output: #+begin_example Scanning directory: /path/to/org-files Database path: .scimax/org

entries.heading: Cron Job Examples
entries.content: Schedule automatic database updates: #+begin_src bash # Edit crontab crontab -e # Scan every hour 0 * * * * cd /path/to/project && scimax db scan ~/org-files # Scan daily at 6am 0 6 * * * cd /path/to/project && scimax db scan ~/org-files >> /var/log/scimax-scan.log 2>&1 # Scan multiple directories every 30 minutes */30 * * * * cd /path/to/project && scimax db scan ~/work/notes && scimax db scan ~/personal/org #+end_src

entries.heading: Difference from Rebuild
entries.content: | Command                        | Use Case                                    | |--------------------------------+---------------------------------------------| | =scimax db scan <dir>=         | Quick scan of a specific directory          | | =scimax db rebuild=            | Full rebuild of the project root            | | =scimax db rebuild --path <d>= | Rebuild with additional options (--force)   | The =scan= command is simpler and takes the directory as a direct argument, while =rebuild= off

entries.heading: Export All Org Files to HTML
entries.content: #+begin_src bash #!/bin/bash for f in docs/*.org; do scimax export "$f" --format html --output "build/$(basename "$f" .org).html" done #+end_src

entries.heading: Check Citations in CI
entries.content: #+begin_src yaml # .github/workflows/check-citations.yml name: Check Citations on: [push, pull_request] jobs: check: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - uses: actions/checkout@v3 - uses: actions/setup-node@v3 with: node-version: '18' - run: npm ci - run: npm run compile - run: node out/cli/index.js cite check paper.org --bib refs.bib #+end_src

entries.heading: Daily Agenda Email
entries.content: #+begin_src bash #!/bin/bash # Send daily agenda via email scimax agenda today | mail -s "Today's Agenda" user@example.com #+end_src

entries.heading: Find Files with Specific Tags
entries.content: #+begin_src bash # Using search (if tag is in heading) scimax search ":research:" --limit 50 #+end_src

entries.heading: Limitations
entries.content: The CLI has some limitations compared to the VS Code extension: 1. *Semantic Search*: Requires embeddings which need the embedding service configured in VS Code. 2. *Live Updates*: The CLI reads a snapshot of the database. Changes made to org files won't be reflected until you run =scimax db rebuild= or VS Code re-indexes them. 3. *Interactive Features*: No support for interactive features like completion or live preview. 4. *FTS Index*: The CLI rebuild populates the main tables but doesn't rebu

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: - [[file:18-database-search.org][Database & Search]] - How the database indexing works - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - Export options and configuration - [[file:19-references.org][References & Citations]] - Citation syntax and bibliography management - [[file:13-agenda.org][Agenda]] - Agenda views in VS Code

entries.heading: Markdown Compatibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:32] Scimax VS Code provides first-class support for org-mode files, with substantial structural editing and navigation support for Markdown documents as well. This chapter documents which features work in Markdown files and how to use them.

entries.heading: Design Philosophy
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:32] The extension treats Markdown as a first-class citizen for *structural editing and navigation*. Features that rely on org-mode specific syntax (TODO states, scheduling, clocking, properties) are not available in Markdown since they would require non-standard Markdown extensions. | Category                | Markdown Support | Notes                              | |-------------------------+------------------+------------------------------------| | Structural editing

entries.heading: Document Outline and Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:33] Markdown files have full support for the VS Code outline view and breadcrumb navigation.

entries.heading: Outline View
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:33] The extension provides a =DocumentSymbolProvider= for Markdown that recognizes: - Headings (lines starting with =#=) - Fenced code blocks (=```language= or =~~~language=) - YAML frontmatter title Open the Outline view in the Explorer sidebar or press =Ctrl+Shift+O= to see the document structure.

entries.heading: Breadcrumbs
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:33] Breadcrumbs show the current heading hierarchy in the editor title bar. This works automatically for Markdown files.

entries.heading: Jump to Heading
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:34] Press =C-c C-j= to open a quick-pick menu of all headings in the current file. Type to filter and press Enter to jump.  `Cmd-C/Shift-o' also works.

entries.heading: Heading Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:35] All heading navigation commands work in Markdown: | Key       | Command                   | Description                      | |-----------+---------------------------+----------------------------------| | C-c C-n   | Next Heading              | Move to next heading (any level) | | C-c C-p   | Previous Heading          | Move to previous heading         | | C-c C-u   | Parent Heading            | Move to parent (higher level)    | | C-c C-j   | Jump to Heading

entries.heading: Heading Manipulation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:35] Change heading levels and move subtrees: | Key         | Command           | Description                      | |-------------+-------------------+----------------------------------| | M-<left>    | Promote Heading   | Decrease level (## -> #)         | | M-<right>   | Demote Heading    | Increase level (# -> ##)         | | M-S-<left>  | Promote Subtree   | Promote heading and all children | | M-S-<right> | Demote Subtree    | Demote heading and all children  | |

entries.heading: Insert Headings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:35] | Key        | Command           | Description                           | |------------+-------------------+---------------------------------------| | C-<return> | Insert Heading    | Insert new heading at same level      | | -          | Insert Subheading | Insert heading one level deeper       | The extension automatically uses =#= characters for Markdown (not =*= like org).

entries.heading: Subtree Operations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:35] All subtree operations work in Markdown: | Command                    | Speed Key | Description                    | |----------------------------+-----------+--------------------------------| | scimax.org.markSubtree     | @         | Select entire subtree          | | scimax.org.killSubtree     | w         | Cut subtree to clipboard       | | scimax.org.cloneSubtree    | W         | Duplicate subtree below        | | scimax.org.yankSubtree     | y         | Paste

entries.heading: Yank Subtree Level Adjustment
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:35] When yanking (pasting) a subtree, the extension automatically adjusts heading levels to match the context: #+BEGIN_SRC markdown ## Target Section <!-- Yank a subtree that was cut from a different level --> <!-- Headings are automatically adjusted to match ## level --> #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Code Block Support
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:37] Markdown fenced code blocks have full support for: - Detection and navigation - Execution via Babel/Jupyter - Block manipulation (split, merge, clone)

entries.heading: Fenced Block Syntax
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:37] Both backtick and tilde fences are supported: #+BEGIN_SRC markdown ```python print("Hello from Python") ``` ~~~javascript console.log("Hello from JS"); ~~~ #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Code Block Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:53] | Key       | Command              | Description                    | |-----------+----------------------+--------------------------------| | C-c C-v n | Next Source Block    | Jump to next fenced block      | | C-c C-v p | Previous Source Block| Jump to previous fenced block  | | C-c C-v g | Jump to Source Block | Quick-pick menu of all blocks  |

entries.heading: Code Block Execution
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:50] Press =C-c C-c= inside a fenced code block to execute it. Results appear below the block. Supported languages include Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, Shell, and any language with a Jupyter kernel installed.

entries.heading: Code Block Manipulation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:50] | Command                        | Description                          | |--------------------------------+--------------------------------------| | scimax.ob.splitBlock           | Split block at cursor                | | scimax.ob.mergeWithPrevious    | Merge with previous block            | | scimax.ob.mergeWithNext        | Merge with next block                | | scimax.ob.insertBlockAbove     | Insert new block above               | | scimax.ob.insertBlockBe

entries.heading: Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] Speed commands work at the beginning of Markdown headings (column 0 of a line starting with =#=).

entries.heading: Navigation Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Key | Action                               | |-----+--------------------------------------| | n   | Next heading                         | | p   | Previous heading                     | | f   | Forward to same-level heading        | | b   | Back to same-level heading           | | u   | Up to parent heading                 | | j   | Jump to heading (quick-pick)         | | g   | Go to... (navigation menu)           |

entries.heading: Structure Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Key | Action                    | |-----+---------------------------| | @   | Mark (select) subtree     | | w   | Kill (cut) subtree        | | W   | Clone subtree             | | y   | Yank (paste) subtree      | | s   | Narrow to subtree         | | S   | Widen (show all)          |

entries.heading: Visibility Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Key | Action               | |-----+----------------------| | c   | Cycle visibility     | | C   | Show children        | | o   | Overview (fold all)  |

entries.heading: Folding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] Markdown headings support folding via the standard VS Code folding mechanism: - Press =Tab= on a heading to cycle fold state - Press =Shift+Tab= anywhere for global fold cycling - Use the fold icons in the gutter

entries.heading: Features Not Available in Markdown
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] The following org-mode features are *not* supported in Markdown files because they require org-specific syntax:

entries.heading: Task Management
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Feature        | Reason                                      | |----------------+---------------------------------------------| | TODO keywords  | Org syntax: =* TODO Task=                   | | Priorities     | Org syntax: =[#A]=                          | | Checkbox lists | Markdown checkboxes work differently        | | Progress cookies| Org syntax: =[2/5]= or =[40%]=             |

entries.heading: Planning
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Feature    | Reason                                         | |------------+------------------------------------------------| | SCHEDULED  | Org syntax: =SCHEDULED: <2026-01-20>=          | | DEADLINE   | Org syntax: =DEADLINE: <2026-01-20>=           | | Clocking   | Org syntax: =CLOCK: [timestamp]--[timestamp]=  | | Agenda     | Requires TODO states and scheduling            |

entries.heading: Metadata
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Feature         | Reason                                    | |-----------------+-------------------------------------------| | Properties      | Org syntax: =:PROPERTIES:= drawer         | | Tags            | Org syntax: =* Heading :tag1:tag2:=       | | Inherited tags  | Requires org tag syntax                   | | LOGBOOK         | Org syntax: =:LOGBOOK:= drawer            |

entries.heading: Special Elements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:40] | Feature         | Reason                                    | |-----------------+-------------------------------------------| | Inline tasks    | Org syntax: 15+ stars                     | | Dynamic blocks  | Org syntax: =#+BEGIN:=                    | | Special blocks  | Org syntax: =#+BEGIN_QUOTE=, etc.         |

entries.heading: Maximizing Compatibility
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:41] To get the most out of Scimax VS Code with Markdown: 1. *Use speed commands* - Position cursor at column 0 of headings for rapid single-key operations 2. *Use fenced code blocks* - The extension fully supports =```language= blocks for execution and manipulation 3. *Use the outline view* - Provides visual navigation similar to org's sparse tree features 4. *Use jump commands* - =C-c C-j= for headings, =C-c C-v g= for code blocks

entries.heading: When to Use Org-Mode Instead
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:41] Consider using org-mode files when you need: - Task management with TODO states and priorities - Scheduling and deadlines with agenda integration - Time tracking with clocking - Inherited properties and tags - Advanced export features Org files can be exported to Markdown when sharing with others who don't use org-mode.
