entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:41] - [[file:02-document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Full org-mode structure documentation - [[file:23-speed-commands.org][Speed Commands]] - Complete speed command reference - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Code execution details - [[file:21-navigation.org][Navigation]] - All navigation features

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:44] - Previous: [[file:29-unsupported-features.org][Unsupported Features]] - Index: [[file:00-index.org][Documentation Index]] - Next: [[file:31-publishing.org][Publishing]]

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: The Scimax VS Code extension provides an org-publishing system for converting multiple org-mode documents into a cohesive HTML website. This is ideal for creating documentation sites, blogs, or project pages hosted on GitHub Pages. The publishing system follows a wizard-first approach - most users can get started with a few clicks, while power users can customize everything through a JSON configuration file.

entries.heading: Step 1: Initialize a Publishing Project
entries.content: Run the command `Scimax: Initialize Publishing Project' (`C-c C-e p i') to start the 5-step wizard: 1. *Project name* - A short identifier (e.g., "my-website") 2. *Source directory* - Where your org files are located (default: `./org') 3. *Output directory* - Where HTML files will be published (default: `./docs' for GitHub Pages) 4. *Publishing target* - GitHub Pages (recommended) or Local/Custom 5. *Sitemap generation* - Whether to auto-generate an index page

entries.heading: Step 2: Add Content
entries.content: Create or edit `.org' files in your source directory. Each file becomes an HTML page. Example `./org/about.org': #+BEGIN_SRC org ,#+TITLE: About This Project ,#+AUTHOR: Your Name ,#+DATE: 2026-01-16 ,* Introduction Welcome to my project documentation! ,* Features - Feature one - Feature two #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Step 3: Publish
entries.content: Run `Scimax: Publish Project' (`C-c C-e p p') to generate HTML files.

entries.heading: Step 4: Deploy to GitHub Pages
entries.content: 1. Commit the `./docs' folder to your repository 2. Go to your repository's Settings  Pages 3. Set Source to "Deploy from a branch" 4. Select `main' branch and `/docs' folder 5. Your site will be live at `https://username.github.io/repo-name/'

entries.heading: Commands
entries.content: | Command                              | Keybinding      | Description                       | |--------------------------------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------| | =scimax.publish.init=                | =C-c C-e p i=   | Initialize publishing project     | | =scimax.publish.project=             | =C-c C-e p p=   | Publish selected project          | | =scimax.publish.file=                | =C-c C-e p f=   | Publish current file only         | | =scimax.publish.all=

entries.heading: Configuration File
entries.content: The publishing system supports two configuration formats: 1. `_config.yml' - YAML format (Jupyter Book compatible, takes precedence) 2. `.org-publish.json' - JSON format The wizard creates a `.org-publish.json' file by default. You can also create or edit either file manually.

entries.heading: YAML Configuration (`_config.yml')
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:17] For Jupyter Book compatibility, create a `_config.yml' in your project root: #+BEGIN_SRC yaml # _config.yml - Jupyter Book compatible title: "My Documentation" publish: base_directory: "./docs" publishing_directory: "./public" recursive: true auto_sitemap: true sitemap_filename: "index.org" html: use_default_theme: true toc_depth: 3 css_files: - "./css/custom.css" github_pages: true #+END_SRC

entries.heading: JSON Configuration (`.org-publish.json')
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "website": { "baseDirectory": "./org", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "recursive": true, "autoSitemap": true } }, "githubPages": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Full Configuration Reference
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "my-website": { "baseDirectory": "./org", "baseExtension": "org", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "recursive": true, "exclude": "drafts/*", "include": ["extra/special.org"], "publishingFunction": "org-html-publish-to-html", "autoSitemap": true, "sitemapFilename": "index.org", "sitemapTitle": "Home", "sitemapStyle": "list", "sitemapSortFiles": "alphabetically", "sitemapSortFolders": "first", "htmlPreamble": "./templates/nav.html",

entries.heading: File Selection Options
entries.content: | Option                 | Type     | Default | Description                                    | |------------------------+----------+---------+------------------------------------------------| | =baseDirectory=        | string   | -       | Source directory containing org files          | | =baseExtension=        | string   | ="org"= | File extension to match (without dot)          | | =publishingDirectory=  | string   | -       | Output directory for HTML files                | | =recursive=

entries.heading: Publishing Function Options
entries.content: | Option               | Type   | Default                       | Description                    | |----------------------+--------+-------------------------------+--------------------------------| | =publishingFunction= | string | ="org-html-publish-to-html"=  | How to process files           | Available functions: - `org-html-publish-to-html' - Convert org files to HTML - `md-html-publish-to-html' - Convert Markdown files to HTML - `ipynb-html-publish-to-html' - Convert Jupyter notebooks to HT

entries.heading: Supported File Types
entries.content: The publishing system supports multiple file types: | Extension | Description              | Conversion                            | |-----------+--------------------------+---------------------------------------| | =.org=    | Org-mode documents       | Full org parsing with code blocks     | | =.md=     | Markdown files           | Basic Markdown to HTML conversion     | | =.ipynb=  | Jupyter notebooks        | Notebook cells to HTML with syntax    | When using `auto' or `org-html-publish-to-h

entries.heading: Sitemap Options
entries.content: | Option              | Type             | Default           | Description                          | |---------------------+------------------+-------------------+--------------------------------------| | =autoSitemap=       | boolean          | =true=            | Generate sitemap automatically       | | =sitemapFilename=   | string           | ="sitemap.org"=   | Sitemap file name                    | | =sitemapTitle=      | string           | ="Site Map"=      | Title for sitemap page

entries.heading: HTML Template Options
entries.content: | Option          | Type     | Description                                      | |-----------------+----------+--------------------------------------------------| | =htmlPreamble=  | string   | File path or HTML string for header/navigation   | | =htmlPostamble= | string   | File path or HTML string for footer              | | =htmlHead=      | string   | Extra content for =<head>= section               | | =htmlHeadExtra= | string   | Additional head content (appended)               | | =cssFi

entries.heading: Export Options
entries.content: | Option           | Type             | Default | Description                    | |------------------+------------------+---------+--------------------------------| | =withAuthor=     | boolean          | =true=  | Include author in output       | | =withCreator=    | boolean          | =true=  | Include generator info         | | =withToc=        | boolean / number | =true=  | Table of contents (or depth)   | | =sectionNumbers= | boolean          | =false= | Number sections                | |

entries.heading: Global Options
entries.content: | Option          | Type    | Description                              | |-----------------+---------+------------------------------------------| | =githubPages=   | boolean | Enable GitHub Pages features             | | =customDomain=  | string  | Custom domain (creates CNAME file)       | | =defaultProject= | string | Project to publish when none specified   |

entries.heading: Multi-Project Configuration
entries.content: You can define multiple projects for different parts of your site: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "pages": { "baseDirectory": "./org", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "recursive": true, "autoSitemap": true }, "static": { "baseDirectory": "./assets", "publishingDirectory": "./docs/assets", "baseExtension": "css|js|png|jpg|svg", "publishingFunction": "copy" }, "full-site": { "components": ["pages", "static"] } } } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Component Projects
entries.content: A component project groups multiple projects together: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "full-site": { "components": ["pages", "static", "images"] } } #+END_SRC When you publish "full-site", all component projects are published in order.

entries.heading: Explicit Table of Contents (`_toc.yml')
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-17 Sat 15:17] By default, the publishing system discovers files automatically and generates an alphabetical sitemap. For curated documentation or books where order matters, you can create an explicit table of contents using a `_toc.yml' file.

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: When a `_toc.yml' file exists in your source directory, the publishing system: 1. Publishes files in the order specified (not alphabetically) 2. Generates prev/next navigation links on each page 3. Creates an index page reflecting the TOC structure 4. Only includes files listed in the TOC (plus unlisted if configured)

entries.heading: Basic `_toc.yml' Format
entries.content: Create a `_toc.yml' file in your source directory (e.g., `./docs/_toc.yml'): #+BEGIN_SRC yaml # Simple flat structure format: scimax root: index chapters: - file: getting-started - file: installation - file: configuration - file: advanced-usage #+END_SRC

entries.heading: With Sections (Nested Chapters)
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC yaml format: scimax root: index chapters: - file: getting-started sections: - file: getting-started/installation - file: getting-started/first-steps - file: user-guide sections: - file: user-guide/basics - file: user-guide/advanced - file: reference #+END_SRC

entries.heading: With Parts (Book Format)
entries.content: For larger documentation with multiple parts/volumes: #+BEGIN_SRC yaml format: jb-book root: intro parts: - caption: Getting Started chapters: - file: installation - file: quickstart - file: tutorials - caption: User Guide chapters: - file: basics sections: - file: basics/syntax - file: basics/formatting - file: advanced - caption: Reference chapters: - file: api-reference - file: changelog #+END_SRC

entries.heading: TOC Options
entries.content: | Field        | Description                                    | |--------------+------------------------------------------------| | =format=     | ="scimax"=, ="jb-book"=, or ="jb-article"=     | | =root=       | Landing page file (without extension)          | | =chapters=   | List of chapter entries                        | | =parts=      | List of parts (with caption and chapters)      |

entries.heading: Entry Options
entries.content: | Field      | Description                                      | |------------+--------------------------------------------------| | =file=     | File path without extension (relative to baseDir)| | =title=    | Override display title (optional)                | | =sections= | Nested child entries (optional)                  | | =url=      | External URL link (optional)                     |

entries.heading: Custom Titles
entries.content: You can override the title from the file's `#+TITLE': #+BEGIN_SRC yaml chapters: - file: api title: API Reference (Complete) - file: changelog title: Version History #+END_SRC

entries.heading: External Links
entries.content: Include external URLs in your TOC: #+BEGIN_SRC yaml chapters: - file: documentation - url: https://github.com/user/repo title: Source Code - url: https://github.com/user/repo/issues title: Report Issues #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Navigation Links
entries.content:
When using `_toc.yml', each published page automatically gets: #+BEGIN_SRC html
Previous Next
#+END_SRC You can style these with CSS: #+BEGIN_SRC css .page-navigation { display: flex; justify-content: space-between; padding: 1rem 0; border-top: 1px solid #eee; margin-top: 2rem; } .nav-prev, .nav-next { color: #0066cc; } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Combining with Configuration
entries.content: Your `.org-publish.json' works the same way - the `_toc.yml' just controls ordering: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "docs": { "baseDirectory": "./docs", "publishingDirectory": "./public", "autoSitemap": true, "sitemapFilename": "index.org", "sitemapTitle": "Documentation" } } } #+END_SRC With `./docs/_toc.yml': #+BEGIN_SRC yaml format: scimax root: intro chapters: - file: getting-started - file: user-guide - file: reference #+END_SRC

entries.heading: File Extension Resolution
entries.content: The TOC references files without extensions. The system automatically finds files with these extensions (in order): 1. `.org' 2. `.md' 3. `.ipynb' So `file: getting-started' will match `getting-started.org', `getting-started.md', or `getting-started.ipynb'.

entries.heading: HTML Preamble (Navigation)
entries.content:
Create a file like `./templates/nav.html': #+BEGIN_SRC html
Home About Contents
#+END_SRC Reference it in your config: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "htmlPreamble": "./templates/nav.html" } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: HTML Postamble (Footer)
entries.content:
Create `./templates/footer.html': #+BEGIN_SRC html

© 2026 Your Name. Generated by scimax-vscode.

#+END_SRC

entries.heading: Custom CSS
entries.content: Create `./css/style.css' and reference it: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "cssFiles": ["./css/style.css"] } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: GitHub Pages Integration
entries.content: When `githubPages' is enabled: 1. A `.nojekyll' file is created in the output directory (disables Jekyll processing) 2. If `customDomain' is set, a `CNAME' file is created 3. The default output directory is `./docs' (GitHub Pages convention) 4. The default sitemap becomes `index.org'  `index.html'

entries.heading: Custom Domain Setup
entries.content: To use a custom domain: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "githubPages": true, "customDomain": "docs.example.com" } #+END_SRC Then configure your DNS to point to GitHub Pages.

entries.heading: Cross-File Links
entries.content: Links between org files are automatically converted to HTML links: #+BEGIN_SRC org See [[file:other-page.org][the other page]] for details. #+END_SRC Becomes: #+BEGIN_SRC html See the other page for details. #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Documentation Site
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "docs": { "baseDirectory": "./docs-src", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "autoSitemap": true, "sitemapFilename": "index.org", "sitemapTitle": "Documentation", "withToc": 2 } }, "githubPages": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Blog
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "blog": { "baseDirectory": "./posts", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "autoSitemap": true, "sitemapFilename": "index.org", "sitemapTitle": "Blog", "sitemapSortFiles": "anti-chronologically", "htmlPreamble": "./templates/blog-header.html" } }, "githubPages": true } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Project with Static Assets
entries.content: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "projects": { "pages": { "baseDirectory": "./org", "publishingDirectory": "./docs", "autoSitemap": true }, "images": { "baseDirectory": "./images", "publishingDirectory": "./docs/images", "baseExtension": "png|jpg|gif|svg", "publishingFunction": "copy" }, "css": { "baseDirectory": "./css", "publishingDirectory": "./docs/css", "baseExtension": "css", "publishingFunction": "copy" }, "site": { "components": ["pages", "images", "css"]

entries.heading: "No publishing configuration found"
entries.content: Run `Scimax: Initialize Publishing Project' (`C-c C-e p i') to create a `.org-publish.json' file.

entries.heading: "Base directory does not exist"
entries.content: Create the source directory specified in `baseDirectory', or update the config to point to an existing directory.

entries.heading: Links not working after publish
entries.content: Ensure you're using `file:' links to reference other org files: #+BEGIN_SRC org [[file:other.org][Link text]] #+END_SRC

entries.heading: GitHub Pages not updating
entries.content: 1. Ensure the `./docs' folder is committed 2. Check that GitHub Pages is configured to serve from `/docs' 3. Wait a few minutes for GitHub to rebuild the site

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: - [[file:export.org][Export System]] - Single-file export options - [[file:source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Code blocks in org files - [[file:document-structure.org][Document Structure]] - Headings and organization

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:34] Scimax VS Code integrates with the [[https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=pomdtr.excalidraw-editor][Excalidraw VS Code extension]] to provide seamless support for creating and editing diagrams directly from org-mode documents.

entries.heading: Prerequisites
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:34] Install the Excalidraw extension from the VS Code marketplace: | Extension ID              | Name               | |---------------------------+--------------------| | pomdtr.excalidraw-editor  | Excalidraw Editor  | You can install it via: - Command Palette: =Extensions: Install Extensions=  search "Excalidraw" - Or run: =code --install-extension pomdtr.excalidraw-editor=

entries.heading: Supported File Formats
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:35] Excalidraw supports multiple file formats, all of which work with this integration: | Extension           | Description                              | Hover Preview | |---------------------+------------------------------------------+---------------| | .excalidraw         | Native Excalidraw format (JSON)          | Via exports   | | .excalidraw.json    | Explicit JSON format                     | Via exports   | | .excalidraw.svg     | SVG with embedded Excalidraw

entries.heading: Creating Excalidraw Links
entries.content: Use standard org-mode link syntax to reference Excalidraw drawings:

entries.heading: Basic Links
entries.content: [[_static/drawing.excalidraw]]

entries.heading: Hover Preview
entries.content: When you hover over an Excalidraw link, a tooltip appears showing: 1. *Drawing name* - The filename or link description 2. *Visual preview* - For all Excalidraw file types: - =.excalidraw.svg= and =.excalidraw.png= files show the image directly - =.excalidraw= and =.excalidraw.json= files show a generated SVG preview 3. *Element count* - Number of shapes in the drawing 4. *File information* - Size and last modified date The hover preview for =.excalidraw= files renders a simplified SVG showing:

entries.heading: Click to Edit
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:36] Clicking an Excalidraw link opens the drawing in the Excalidraw visual editor.

entries.heading: Existing Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:36] When you click a link to an existing Excalidraw file: 1. The file opens in the Excalidraw editor 2. You can edit the drawing visually 3. Changes are saved automatically

entries.heading: New Files (Auto-creation)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:36] When you click a link to a non-existent Excalidraw file: 1. The file is automatically created with an empty drawing 2. Parent directories are created if needed 3. The new drawing opens in the Excalidraw editor This makes it easy to create new diagrams - just write the link and click it: #+BEGIN_SRC org # This file doesn't exist yet - clicking creates it [[new-diagram.excalidraw][My New Diagram]] #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Fallback Behavior
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:36] If the Excalidraw extension is not installed: 1. The file opens as a text document (showing JSON) 2. A message suggests installing the Excalidraw extension

entries.heading: Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:39] | Command                      | Description             | Invocation         | |------------------------------+-------------------------+--------------------| | scimax.org.openExcalidraw    | Open Excalidraw Drawing | Click on link      | The command is automatically invoked when clicking Excalidraw links. It can also be called programmatically: #+BEGIN_SRC typescript vscode.commands.executeCommand('scimax.org.openExcalidraw', { file: '/path/to/drawing.excalidraw'

entries.heading: Organizing Drawings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:56] Keep drawings organized alongside your org files: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE project/  notes.org  diagrams/     architecture.excalidraw.svg     dataflow.excalidraw.svg     ui-mockup.excalidraw.png  docs/  design.org #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Export for Sharing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:56] Excalidraw's =.excalidraw.svg= and =.excalidraw.png= formats are ideal because: - They display correctly in web browsers and image viewers - They can be embedded in HTML/PDF exports - They retain full editability (scene data is embedded)

entries.heading: Version Control
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:56] All Excalidraw formats are text-based (JSON or JSON-embedded), making them suitable for version control with git. The =.excalidraw.svg= format shows meaningful diffs for the SVG portions.

entries.heading: Drawing won't open in visual editor
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 09:56] - Ensure the Excalidraw extension is installed: =pomdtr.excalidraw-editor= - Check that the file extension is correct (=.excalidraw=, =.excalidraw.json=, =.excalidraw.svg=, or =.excalidraw.png=) - Try reloading VS Code window

entries.heading: No hover preview appears
entries.content: - All Excalidraw file types now show hover previews - For =.excalidraw= files, a simplified SVG is generated from the JSON - The file must exist on disk for preview to work - Empty drawings show "Empty drawing" instead of a preview

entries.heading: Link not recognized as Excalidraw
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:40] Ensure the file extension is one of: - =.excalidraw= - =.excalidraw.json= - =.excalidraw.svg= - =.excalidraw.png=

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-18 Sun 08:40] - [[file:05-links.org][Hyperlinks]] - General link syntax and handling - [[file:12-image-overlays.org][Image Overlays]] - Inline image display - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - Including drawings in exports

entries.heading: LaTeX Navigation and Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:24] Scimax VS Code provides comprehensive navigation, structure editing, and tooltips for LaTeX documents. These features mirror the org-mode heading navigation and structure editing commands, adapted for LaTeX section commands and environments.

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:24] LaTeX support in Scimax VS Code includes: 1. *Document Outline* - Hierarchical view of sections, environments, and labels 2. *Section Navigation* - Move between sections at any level 3. *Structure Editing* - Promote/demote, move, and manipulate sections 4. *Environment Commands* - Select, change, wrap, and unwrap environments 5. *Hover Tooltips* - Information about references, citations, packages, and commands 6. *Speed Commands* - Single-key shortcuts at section s

entries.heading: Document Outline
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:24] The outline view (VS Code's built-in outline panel `Cmd/C-Shift-o') shows the structure of your LaTeX document: - *Sections* (part, chapter, section, subsection, etc.) - *Labeled Environments* (figures, tables, equations with labels) - *Labels* for cross-referencing The outline uses hierarchical nesting to show the document structure. Click any item to jump to it.

entries.heading: Section Hierarchy
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:26] LaTeX sections are organized hierarchically: | Level | Command         | Symbol Kind | |-------+-----------------+-------------| |     0 | \part           | Module      | |     1 | \chapter        | Class       | |     2 | \section        | Method      | |     3 | \subsection     | Function    | |     4 | \subsubsection  | Field       | |     5 | \paragraph      | Property    | |     6 | \subparagraph   | Property    | Starred variants (e.g., =\section*{...}=) are

entries.heading: Section Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:26] Navigate between sections in your LaTeX document using these commands: | Command                               | Key Binding   | Description                        | |---------------------------------------+---------------+------------------------------------| | scimax.latex.nextSection              | C-c C-n       | Jump to next section               | | scimax.latex.previousSection          | C-c C-p       | Jump to previous section           | | scimax.latex.par

entries.heading: Next/Previous Section
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:26] Move through all sections in document order: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \section{Introduction} Content here... \subsection{Background}    % <- Current position \subsection{Motivation}    % <- Next section \section{Methods}          % <- Another next section #+END_SRC =nextSection= moves forward through sections regardless of level. =previousSection= moves backward.

entries.heading: Sibling Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:26] Move between sections at the same level: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \section{Introduction} \subsection{Background}    % <- Current position \subsection{Motivation}    % <- Next sibling (same level) \subsection{Goals}         % <- Another sibling \section{Methods}          % <- NOT a sibling (different level) #+END_SRC =nextSiblingSection= moves to the next section at the same hierarchical level. =previousSiblingSection= moves backward.

entries.heading: Parent Section
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:26] Jump to the containing (parent) section: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \section{Methods}            % <- Jump here (parent) \subsection{Data Collection} \subsubsection{Sampling}     % <- From here #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Jump to Section
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:21] The =jumpToSection= command (C-c C-j or C-c j) opens a quick pick showing all sections with: - Hierarchical indentation showing structure - Section type (=\section=, =\subsection=, etc.) - Line numbers Type to filter, then select a section to jump to it.

entries.heading: Structure Editing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:27] Edit the document structure by promoting, demoting, and moving sections. | Command                          | Key Binding      | Description                     | |----------------------------------+------------------+---------------------------------| | scimax.latex.promoteSection      | Alt+Left         | Promote section (e.g., subsec) | | scimax.latex.demoteSection       | Alt+Right        | Demote section (e.g., secsub)  | | scimax.latex.promoteSubtree      |

entries.heading: Promote/Demote
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:27] Change the level of a section command: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before promote: \subsection{Methods} % After promote (Alt+Left): \section{Methods} % Before demote: \section{Results} % After demote (Alt+Right): \subsection{Results} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Promote/Demote Subtree
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:27] Promote or demote a section and all its children: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before promoteSubtree on "Methods": \subsection{Methods} \subsubsection{Data} \subsubsection{Analysis} % After promoteSubtree (Alt+Shift+Left): \section{Methods} \subsection{Data} \subsection{Analysis} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Move Section Up/Down
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:27] Swap a section with its previous or next sibling: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before moveSectionDown on "Introduction": \section{Introduction} Content A... \section{Methods} Content B... % After moveSectionDown (Alt+Down): \section{Methods} Content B... \section{Introduction} Content A... #+END_SRC The entire section subtree (including all nested content) is moved.

entries.heading: Environment Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:27] Work with LaTeX environments (=\begin{...}= / =\end{...}=): | Command                                | Key Binding | Description                    | |----------------------------------------+-------------+--------------------------------| | scimax.latex.selectEnvironment         | C-c C-e     | Select entire environment      | | scimax.latex.selectEnvironmentContent  | -           | Select content (not begin/end) | | scimax.latex.changeEnvironment         | C-c e

entries.heading: Environment Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:28] Navigate between environments: | Command                            | Key Binding | Description               | |------------------------------------+-------------+---------------------------| | scimax.latex.nextEnvironment       | -           | Jump to next environment  | | scimax.latex.previousEnvironment   | -           | Jump to previous environment | | scimax.latex.jumpToEnvironment     | -           | Quick pick all environments |

entries.heading: Change Environment
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:28] The =changeEnvironment= command (C-c e) prompts to change the environment type: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before: \begin{equation} E = mc^2 \end{equation} % After changing to "align": \begin{align} E = mc^2 \end{align} #+END_SRC Both =\begin= and =\end= are updated simultaneously.

entries.heading: Wrap in Environment
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:28] Select text and use =wrapInEnvironment= (C-c w) to surround it: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before (with "E = mc^2" selected): E = mc^2 % After wrapping in "equation": \begin{equation} E = mc^2 \end{equation} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Toggle Star
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:28] Toggle the starred variant of an environment: #+BEGIN_SRC latex % Before: \begin{equation} E = mc^2 \end{equation} % After toggleEnvironmentStar (C-c *): \begin{equation*} E = mc^2 \end{equation*} #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Hover Tooltips
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Hover over LaTeX elements to see helpful information: | Element              | Information Shown                           | |----------------------+---------------------------------------------| | =\ref{label}=        | What the label refers to, line number       | | =\cite{key}=         | Citation keys (bib integration planned)     | | =\label{name}=       | Where label is referenced, context          | | =\usepackage{pkg}=   | Package description

entries.heading: Reference Hover
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Hovering over =\ref{fig:example}= shows: - The label name - Line number where label is defined - Context (section or environment containing the label) - Preview of the labeled line

entries.heading: Citation Hover
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Hovering over =\cite{key}= shows rich BibTeX information: - Full title - Authors with proper formatting - Year - Journal or book title - Volume, number, pages - DOI (as clickable link) - Abstract preview Supports all natbib and biblatex citation commands: - =\cite=, =\citep=, =\citet= - =\citealt=, =\citealp= - =\citeauthor=, =\citeyear= - =\nocite=

entries.heading: Package Hover
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Hovering over =\usepackage{amsmath}= shows: - Package name - Description of what the package provides

entries.heading: Math Symbol Hover
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Hovering over math commands like =\alpha= shows: - Unicode representation:  - Unicode code point: U+03B1 - Description: Greek lowercase alpha

entries.heading: Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] At the beginning of a section line, single keys trigger commands: | Key | Action                 | Key | Action             | |-----+------------------------+-----+--------------------| | n   | Next section           | <   | Promote section    | | p   | Previous section       | >   | Demote section     | | f   | Next sibling           | U   | Move section up    | | b   | Previous sibling       | D   | Move section down  | | u   | Parent section         | m   | Mark

entries.heading: Using Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] 1. Place cursor at the start of a section line (column 0 or before =\=) 2. Press a single key 3. The corresponding action executes Example: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \section{Introduction}   % <- Place cursor here, press 'n' to go to next section ^ |__ Cursor position #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Folding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] LaTeX documents support folding for sections and environments. | Command               | Key Binding | Description                  | |-----------------------+-------------+------------------------------| | scimax.org.toggleFold | Tab         | Toggle fold at cursor        | | scimax.org.cycleGlobalFold | Shift+Tab | Cycle all folds         |

entries.heading: Section Folding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Sections fold from the section command to the next section at the same or higher level: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \section{Introduction}...  % <- Folds from here Content... \subsection{Background}    % <- Included in fold More content... \section{Methods}          % <- Fold ends before this #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Environment Folding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] Environments fold from =\begin= to =\end=: #+BEGIN_SRC latex \begin{figure}...          % <- Folds from here \includegraphics{...} \caption{...} \end{figure}               % <- Fold ends here #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Global Fold Cycling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:29] =Shift+Tab= cycles through three states: 1. *OVERVIEW* - All sections folded 2. *CONTENTS* - Top-level sections visible 3. *SHOWALL* - Everything expanded

entries.heading: Label Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:31] Navigate to labels in your document: | Command                    | Key Binding | Description              | |----------------------------+-------------+--------------------------| | scimax.latex.jumpToLabel   | C-c l       | Quick pick all labels    | The quick pick shows: - Label name - Context (section or environment) - Line number

entries.heading: Compile and Preview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:31] Compile LaTeX documents and view the generated PDF. | Command                         | Key Binding    | Description                    | |---------------------------------+----------------+--------------------------------| | scimax.latex.compile            | C-c C-c        | Compile the document           | | scimax.latex.viewPdf            | C-c C-v        | View PDF (external viewer)     | | scimax.latex.viewPdfPanel       | C-c v          | View PDF (built-in p

entries.heading: Compilation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:31] The =compile= command runs the configured LaTeX compiler (default: pdflatex): 1. Saves the document 2. Compiles with =-interaction=nonstopmode= for error handling 3. Shows compilation errors with line numbers 4. Outputs detailed log to the "LaTeX" output channel Configure the compiler via =scimax.latex.compiler= setting: - =pdflatex= (default) - =xelatex= - =lualatex= - =latexmk=

entries.heading: SyncTeX Support
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:31] SyncTeX allows jumping between source and PDF positions. *Forward search* (C-c g): Jump from cursor position in source to corresponding PDF location. Supported PDF viewers: - *macOS*: Skim (recommended) - *Linux*: Zathura - *Windows*: SumatraPDF Configure via =scimax.latex.pdfViewer= setting.

entries.heading: Built-in PDF Viewer Panel
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:26] For an Overleaf-like experience, use the built-in PDF viewer panel (=C-c v=): - Opens PDF in a VS Code panel beside your source - Auto-refreshes when you recompile - Zoom controls (+, -, Fit) - Page navigation - Bidirectional sync with text-based highlighting - No external PDF viewer required This is ideal for side-by-side editing without leaving VS Code. | Viewer Option    | Key     | Description                          | |------------------+---------+-----------

entries.heading: Bidirectional Sync
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:24] The built-in PDF viewer supports precise bidirectional synchronization: *Forward sync (TeX  PDF):* - Double-click a word in your LaTeX source to jump to that location in the PDF - Or use =C-c C-s= to sync the current cursor position to the PDF - The word is highlighted with a yellow flash *Inverse sync (PDF  TeX):* Double-click a word in the PDF viewer to jump to the corresponding line in your LaTeX source. | Key     | Action                              | |-----

entries.heading: Debug Popup Setting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:24] To see SyncTeX coordinates and debug information when syncing: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latex.showSyncDebugPopup": true } #+END_SRC Default is =false=. When enabled, shows a popup with page, coordinates, source line/column, and search text for troubleshooting sync issues.

entries.heading: Auto-Compile on Save
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:25] When the PDF panel is open, saving a LaTeX file automatically recompiles and refreshes the PDF. This provides an Overleaf-like live preview experience. To disable auto-compile on save: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latex.autoCompileOnSave": false } #+END_SRC Default is =true=.

entries.heading: Insert Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:26] Quick insertion of common LaTeX elements: | Command                       | Description                        | |-------------------------------+------------------------------------| | scimax.latex.insertFigure     | Insert figure environment snippet  | | scimax.latex.insertTable      | Insert table with booktabs snippet | | scimax.latex.insertEquation   | Insert equation environment        | These commands insert snippets with tab stops for easy navigation.

entries.heading: Go to Definition
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 18:26] Jump to the definition of labels, citations, commands, and files: | Trigger              | What it does                                      | |----------------------+---------------------------------------------------| | =\ref{label}=        | Jump to the =\label{label}= definition            | | =\cite{key}=         | Jump to the BibTeX entry in the .bib file         | | =\input{file}=       | Open the included file                            | | =\mycommand=

entries.heading: Find All References
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:55] Find all usages of a label or citation: | Position on          | Shows all                                         | |----------------------+---------------------------------------------------| | =\label{name}=       | All =\ref{name}= references                       | | =\cite{key}=         | All citations of that key                         | Use =Shift+F12= or right-click  "Find All References". Works across all files in the project.

entries.heading: Auto-Completion
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:56] Smart completions trigger as you type: | Context              | Completions                                       | |----------------------+---------------------------------------------------| | =\ref{=              | All labels in project with context                | | =\cite{=             | All BibTeX keys with author/year/title            | | =\begin{=            | Common environments (equation, figure, etc.)      | | =\usepackage{=       | Common packages with

entries.heading: Multi-File Project Support
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:56] Projects with multiple files (using =\input= or =\include=) are fully supported: - *Master document detection*: Automatically finds the main .tex file - *Cross-file labels*: Complete and navigate labels defined in any project file - *Shared bibliography*: Finds .bib files referenced anywhere in project - *Project-wide search*: Find References searches all included files The master document is detected by looking for =\documentclass=.

entries.heading: Project Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:56] #+BEGIN_SRC text thesis/  main.tex              # Master document (has \documentclass)     \input{chapters/intro}     \input{chapters/methods}     \bibliography{refs}  chapters/     intro.tex        # \label{sec:intro} defined here     methods.tex      # \ref{sec:intro} works here too  refs.bib              # Bibliography #+END_SRC

entries.heading: ChkTeX Linting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:56] Real-time linting with ChkTeX catches common LaTeX issues: - Missing or extra braces - Spacing issues - Style recommendations Errors appear in the Problems panel and as squiggles in the editor.

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:56] #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latex.enableChktex": true  // Enable/disable linting (default: true) } #+END_SRC Requires =chktex= to be installed: - *macOS*: =brew install chktex= - *Linux*: =apt install chktex= - *Windows*: Included with MiKTeX/TeX Live

entries.heading: Error Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:24] Navigate through compilation errors: | Command                       | Key Binding      | Description                    | |-------------------------------+------------------+--------------------------------| | scimax.latex.nextError        | C-c `            | Jump to next error             | | scimax.latex.previousError    | C-c Shift+`      | Jump to previous error         | | scimax.latex.showErrors       | C-c C-e          | Show all errors in quick pick  | Er

entries.heading: Error Display
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:57] When compilation fails: 1. First error is shown in a notification with "Go to Error" button 2. The Problems panel shows all parsed errors 3. Use navigation commands to cycle through errors Errors include: - File path (supports multi-file projects) - Line number - Error message

entries.heading: Hover Previews
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:18] Hover over LaTeX elements to see previews and information.

entries.heading: Equation Preview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:18] Hover over any math expression to see a rendered preview: - Inline math: =$E=mc^2$=, =\(E=mc^2\)= - Display math: =$$...$$$=, =\[...\]= - Environments: =equation=, =align=, =gather=, etc. The preview: - Renders using the system LaTeX installation - Respects document preamble (packages, custom commands) - Adapts to dark/light VS Code theme - Shows the source LaTeX below the preview *Note:* Requires a LaTeX installation (TeX Live, MiKTeX, or MacTeX).

entries.heading: Figure Preview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:18] Hover over =\includegraphics{...}= to see: - Image preview (PNG, JPG, SVG, GIF, WebP) - File path and size - Last modified date PDF and EPS files show file information without preview.

entries.heading: Rename Symbol
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] Rename a label and automatically update all references across the project: 1. Place cursor on a =\label{name}= or =\ref{name}= 2. Press =F2= or right-click  "Rename Symbol" 3. Enter the new name 4. All =\label{}= and =\ref{}= commands using that name are updated Works across all files in multi-file projects.

entries.heading: Supported Reference Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] Rename works with all reference variants: - =\label{...}= - the definition - =\ref{...}=, =\eqref{...}=, =\pageref{...}= - =\autoref{...}=, =\cref{...}=, =\Cref{...}=

entries.heading: Reference Validation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] Automatic validation of label references: | Issue                    | Severity | Description                           | |--------------------------+----------+---------------------------------------| | Undefined reference      | Error    | =\ref{name}= but no =\label{name}=    | | Unused label             | Warning  | =\label{name}= with no =\ref{name}=   | Diagnostics appear in the Problems panel and as squiggles in the editor.

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latex.validateReferences": true  // Enable/disable (default: true) } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Inverse SyncTeX
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] Click in PDF to jump back to the corresponding source location.

entries.heading: Setup
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:25] Run the command =Scimax LaTeX: Show Inverse SyncTeX Command= to get the configuration command for your PDF viewer. | PDF Viewer | Configuration                                               | |------------+-------------------------------------------------------------| | Skim       | Preferences  Sync  Preset: Custom; Command: =code=        | | SumatraPDF | Settings  Options  Set inverse search command             | | Zathura    | Set =synctex-editor-command= in

entries.heading: URI Handler
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] The extension also registers a URI handler for =vscode://= URLs: #+BEGIN_SRC text vscode://file/path/to/file.tex:42 #+END_SRC This allows PDF viewers to communicate directly with VS Code.

entries.heading: Document Formatting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:17] Format LaTeX documents using =latexindent=: | Command                    | Key Binding | Description              | |----------------------------+-------------+--------------------------| | scimax.latex.format        | C-c C-q     | Format entire document   |

entries.heading: Format on Save
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] Enable automatic formatting when saving: #+BEGIN_SRC json { "scimax.latex.formatOnSave": true,          // Auto-format on save "scimax.latex.latexindentPath": "latexindent"  // Path to latexindent } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Requirements
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] =latexindent= must be installed: - *macOS*: Included with MacTeX, or =brew install latexindent= - *Linux*: =apt install texlive-extra-utils= or =cpanm YAML::Tiny File::HomeDir Unicode::GCString= - *Windows*: Included with MiKTeX/TeX Live

entries.heading: Customization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] Create a =.latexindent.yaml= file in your project to customize formatting rules. See the [[https://latexindentpl.readthedocs.io/][latexindent documentation]] for options.

entries.heading: LaTeX-Aware Spell Checking
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] The extension provides infrastructure for LaTeX-aware spell checking that skips commands, math, and comments.

entries.heading: Regions Excluded from Spell Check
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] | Pattern                          | Example                      | |----------------------------------+------------------------------| | Commands with arguments          | =\textbf{word}=              | | Inline math                      | =$x^2 + y^2$=                | | Display math                     | =$$..$$= and =\[..\]=        | | Environments                     | =\begin{...}...\end{...}=    | | Comments                         | =% comment text=

entries.heading: User Dictionary
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-19 Mon 09:12] Add words to your personal dictionary: | Command                        | Description                        | |--------------------------------+------------------------------------| | scimax.latex.addToDictionary   | Add word at cursor to dictionary   | The dictionary is stored per-workspace and persists across sessions.

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] Scimax VS Code provides comprehensive BibTeX file editing support with speed commands, batch operations, and intelligent author name handling. This complements the citation management features in [[file:19-references.org][References and Citations]].

entries.heading: Features
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] - *Speed Commands* - Single-key commands when cursor is at the start of an entry - *Entry Operations* - Clean, format, and transform individual entries - *File Operations* - Sort entries, apply batch transformations, validate files - *Smart Author Parsing* - Proper handling of particles (von, van der), suffixes (Jr., III), and corporate authors - *Journal Abbreviations* - Toggle journal names between full and abbreviated forms using 50,000+ abbreviation database

entries.heading: When to Use This
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] This document covers editing =.bib= files directly. For inserting and managing citations in org/markdown/LaTeX documents, see [[file:19-references.org][References and Citations]].

entries.heading: Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:27] BibTeX speed commands are single-key shortcuts available when your cursor is at column 0 of a line starting with =@= (an entry definition line like =@article{=).

entries.heading: Enabling Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] Speed commands are enabled by default for BibTeX files. The context =scimax.atBibtexEntryStart= is automatically set when appropriate.

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] | Key | Command                      | Description                    | |-----+------------------------------+--------------------------------| | n   | scimax.bibtex.nextEntry      | Jump to next entry             | | p   | scimax.bibtex.previousEntry  | Jump to previous entry         | | j   | scimax.bibtex.jumpToEntry    | Jump to entry by key (fuzzy)   | | ?   | scimax.bibtex.help           | Show speed command help        |

entries.heading: Entry Formatting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] | Key | Command                     | Description                                    | |-----+-----------------------------+------------------------------------------------| | s   | scimax.bibtex.sortFields    | Sort fields in standard order                  | | d   | scimax.bibtex.downcaseEntry | Lowercase entry type and field names           | | t   | scimax.bibtex.titleCase     | Convert title to Title Case                    | | S   | scimax.bibtex.sentenceCase

entries.heading: External Resources
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] | Key | Command                     | Description                      | |-----+-----------------------------+----------------------------------| | o   | scimax.bibtex.openPdf       | Open associated PDF file         | | u   | scimax.bibtex.openUrl       | Open URL field in browser        | | N   | scimax.bibtex.openNotes     | Open/create notes file for entry | | g   | scimax.bibtex.googleScholar | Search entry on Google Scholar   | | x   | scimax.bibtex.crossref

entries.heading: OpenAlex Integration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:19] | Key | Command                        | Description                        | |-----+--------------------------------+------------------------------------| | C   | scimax.bibtex.showCitingWorks  | Show papers citing this work       | | R   | scimax.bibtex.showRelatedWorks | Show related works                 | | r   | scimax.bibtex.showReferences   | Show references cited by this work |

entries.heading: Clipboard Operations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:28] | Key | Command                  | Description                    | |-----+--------------------------+--------------------------------| | k   | scimax.bibtex.copyKey    | Copy citation key to clipboard | | y   | scimax.bibtex.copyBibtex | Copy full BibTeX entry         | | K   | scimax.bibtex.killEntry  | Delete entire entry            |

entries.heading: Using Speed Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:28] 1. Open a =.bib= file 2. Move cursor to column 0 of an =@entry{= line 3. Press a single key from the tables above 4. Press =?= to see available commands Example: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE @article{smith2020machine,    <-- cursor at column 0 here author = {John Smith}, title = {Machine Learning}, year = {2020} } #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Entry Operations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:28] These commands operate on the entry at the cursor position.

entries.heading: Clean Entry
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:28] Command: =scimax.bibtex.cleanEntry= (speed key: =c=) Cleans the current entry by: - Normalizing whitespace (single spaces, trimmed) - Lowercasing field names - Sorting fields in standard BibTeX order - Removing duplicate outer braces (={{Title}}=  ={Title}=) - Preserving inner braces for case protection (={DNA}= stays as-is) Before: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @Article{Smith2020, AUTHOR = {  John   Smith  }, TITLE = {{A Machine Learning Approach}}, Year = {2020}, Journal =

entries.heading: Title Case
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 13:22] Command: =scimax.bibtex.titleCase= (speed key: =T=) Converts the title field to Title Case while preserving: - Braced content (={DNA}=, ={NASA}=) - Small words (a, an, the, and, but, or, for, in, of, on, to, etc.) Example: - "the effects of machine learning on {DNA} analysis"  "The Effects of Machine Learning on {DNA} Analysis"

entries.heading: Sentence Case
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.sentenceCase= (speed key: =t=) Converts the title field to sentence case (only first word capitalized) while preserving braced content. Example: - "The Effects Of Machine Learning"  "The effects of machine learning" - "Analysis of {DNA} Sequences"  "Analysis of {DNA} sequences"

entries.heading: Generate Key
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:25] Command: =scimax.bibtex.generateKey= (speed key: =K=) Generates a citation key based on a configurable pattern. The pattern is set via the =scimax.bibtex.keyPattern= setting.

entries.heading: Pattern Configuration
entries.content: Setting: =scimax.bibtex.keyPattern= Default: ={lastname}-{year}-{title}= Available placeholders: | Placeholder  | Description                                     | |--------------+-------------------------------------------------| | {lastname}   | First author's last name (lowercase)            | | {Lastname}   | First author's last name (capitalized)          | | {year}       | Publication year                                | | {title}      | First significant word from title               | |

entries.heading: Pattern Examples
entries.content: | Pattern                    | Result                           | |----------------------------+----------------------------------| | {lastname}-{year}-{title}  | kitchin-2015-machine             | | {Lastname}{year}           | Kitchin2015                      | | {lastname}-{title:2}-{year}| kitchin-machine-learning-2015    | | {lastname}-{year}-{keywords}| kitchin-2015-catalysis          |

entries.heading: Author Handling
entries.content: | Author          | Year | Title                           | Key (default pattern)    | |-----------------+------+---------------------------------+--------------------------| | Smith, John     | 2024 | Machine Learning for Science    | smith-2024-machine       | | van der Berg    | 2023 | Deep Neural Networks            | berg-2023-deep           | | {NASA}          | 2022 | Space Exploration Report        | nasa-2022-space          |

entries.heading: Sort Fields
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.sortFields= (speed key: =s=) Reorders fields in standard BibTeX order: 1. author, title, journaltitle/journal, booktitle 2. editor, edition, volume, number, issue, pages 3. publisher, location/address, year, date, month 4. doi, url, urldate, isbn, issn 5. eprint, eprinttype, archiveprefix, primaryclass 6. note, annote, abstract, keywords, file 7. Any remaining fields

entries.heading: Downcase Entry
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.downcaseEntry= (speed key: =d=) Lowercases the entry type and all field names: - =@Article=  =@article= - =Author = =  =author == - =JOURNAL = =  =journal ==

entries.heading: Wrap in Braces
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.wrapBraces= (speed key: =b=, keybinding: =Cmd+Shift+]=) Wraps the current selection or word in curly braces for case protection. Use this to protect: - Acronyms: DNA  {DNA} - Proper nouns: Python  {Python} - Chemical formulas: H2O  {H2O}

entries.heading: Strip Braces
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-22 Thu 21:25] Command: =scimax.bibtex.stripBraces= (speed key: =B=, keybinding: =Cmd+Shift+[=) Strips all internal braces from the current entry. Useful for cleaning up entries where braces have been overused. Before: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{smith2024, author = {John Smith}, title = {{A} {Study} of {Machine} {Learning}}, journal = {{Nature}}, year = {2024} } #+END_SRC After: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{smith2024, author = {John Smith}, title = {A Study of Machine Learning},

entries.heading: File Operations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 12:56] These commands operate on the entire BibTeX file.

entries.heading: Sort Entries
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.sortEntries= Sorts all entries in the file. Shows a menu to choose sort order: | Option    | Description                                  | |-----------+----------------------------------------------| | By Key    | Alphabetically by citation key               | | By Year   | Oldest to newest (secondary: key)            | | By Author | Alphabetically by first author last name     | |           | (secondary: year, then key)                  | The command preserves any pream

entries.heading: Apply Operation to All Entries
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.applyToAllEntries= Applies a transformation to every entry in the file. Shows a menu of operations: | Operation           | Description                                           | |---------------------+-------------------------------------------------------| | Clean Entries       | Normalize whitespace, sort fields, lowercase names    | | Title Case Titles   | Convert all titles to Title Case                      | | Sentence Case Titles| Convert all titles to sentence c

entries.heading: Standardize Keys Warning
entries.content: The "Standardize Keys" option shows a confirmation dialog because it can break existing citations in your documents. It also: - Handles duplicate keys by adding suffixes (a, b, c, ...) - Reports how many duplicates were resolved

entries.heading: Validate File
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.validateFile= Validates the BibTeX file and reports: - Total number of entries - Entry types and counts - Syntax style (BibTeX vs BibLaTeX vs mixed) - Duplicate keys - Missing required fields - Syntax errors Results are shown in an output channel with severity indicators: -  Errors (must fix) -  Warnings (should fix)

entries.heading: Show Statistics
entries.content: Command: =scimax.bibtex.showStatistics= Shows a quick overview of the BibTeX file: - Total entries - Entries by type (article, book, etc.) - Syntax style detection - Field usage statistics

entries.heading: Author Name Handling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:55] Scimax uses the citation-js library for proper BibTeX author name parsing, handling complex cases that simple parsers miss.

entries.heading: Standard Formats
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:56] | Input                  | Parsed As                              | |------------------------+----------------------------------------| | Smith, John            | Family: Smith, Given: John             | | John Smith             | Family: Smith, Given: John             | | Smith, John and Doe, Jane | Two authors                         |

entries.heading: Particles (von, van der, de la)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:56] | Input                  | Display Last Name   | Key Last Name | |------------------------+---------------------+---------------| | van der Berg, Hans     | van der Berg        | berg          | | Hans van der Berg      | van der Berg        | berg          | | de la Cruz, Maria      | de la Cruz          | cruz          | | Ludwig van Beethoven   | van Beethoven       | beethoven     |

entries.heading: Suffixes (Jr., III)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:56] | Input                    | Parsed Components                               | |--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------| | Smith, Jr., John         | Family: Smith, Given: John, Suffix: Jr.         | | King, III, Martin Luther | Family: King, Given: Martin Luther, Suffix: III |

entries.heading: Corporate Authors
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:56] Corporate or institutional authors should be wrapped in braces: | Input                          | Parsed As                                  | |--------------------------------+--------------------------------------------| | {NASA}                         | Literal name: NASA                         | | {National Academy of Sciences} | Literal name: National Academy of Sciences | | {World Health Organization}    | Literal name: World Health Organization    |

entries.heading: Key Generation with Authors
entries.content: When generating citation keys, the first author's last name is used: - Particles are stripped for the key (van der Berg  berg) - Corporate names are cleaned (NASA  nasa) - Accents are normalized (Mller  muller)

entries.heading: Entry Formatting
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] 1. *Use consistent case* - Run "Downcase Entries" on your file 2. *Sort fields consistently* - Use "Clean Entries" or "Sort Fields" 3. *Protect case-sensitive text* - Wrap in braces: ={DNA}=, ={Python}=, ={NASA}= 4. *Include DOIs* - Enables OpenAlex integration and hover previews

entries.heading: Key Naming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] Recommended format: =author-year-keyword= or =authoryearkeyword= Good keys: - =smith-2024-machine= or =smith2024machine= - =vandenberg-2023-neural= (note: particle stripped) - =nasa-2022-report= Bad keys: - =ref1=, =paper2= (not memorable) - =ML_Paper_2024= (inconsistent format)

entries.heading: File Organization
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] - One bibliography file per project or topic - Use =@string= definitions for common journals - Keep entries in consistent order (by key or year) - Regularly validate files for errors

entries.heading: Before Sharing
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] 1. Run =scimax.bibtex.validateFile= to check for errors 2. Run "Clean Entries" via =scimax.bibtex.applyToAllEntries= 3. Optionally sort entries by key or year

entries.heading: Journal Abbreviations
entries.content: Scimax includes a comprehensive journal abbreviation database that allows you to toggle between full journal names and their standardized ISO 4 abbreviations.

entries.heading: Data Sources
entries.content: The abbreviation database is sourced from the [[https://github.com/JabRef/abbrv.jabref.org][JabRef Abbreviation Repository]], which aggregates abbreviations from multiple authoritative sources: | Source              | Description                                    | Entries | |---------------------+------------------------------------------------+---------| | General             | Cross-discipline abbreviations                 | ~1,900  | | ACS (Chemistry)     | American Chemical Society journal

entries.heading: Important: Use Version Control
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] Before making batch changes to your bibliography files, ensure your files are under version control (git). This allows you to: - Review changes with =git diff= - Undo changes with =git checkout= if something goes wrong - Track the history of modifications #+BEGIN_QUOTE *Tip*: Commit your .bib file before running batch abbreviation operations. If anything goes wrong, you can always revert. #+END_QUOTE

entries.heading: Single Entry (Speed Key: A)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] Command: =scimax.bibtex.toggleJournalAbbreviation= (speed key: =A=) Toggles the journal field between full name and abbreviation: Before: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{smith2024, author = {John Smith}, title = {A Great Paper}, journal = {Journal of the American Chemical Society}, year = {2024} } #+END_SRC After pressing =A=: #+BEGIN_SRC bibtex @article{smith2024, author = {John Smith}, title = {A Great Paper}, journal = {J. Am. Chem. Soc.}, year = {2024} } #+END_SRC

entries.heading: All Entries
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] | Command                                | Description                            | |----------------------------------------+----------------------------------------| | scimax.bibtex.abbreviateAllJournals    | Abbreviate all journals in the file    | | scimax.bibtex.expandAllJournals        | Expand all journals to full names      | These commands: 1. *Validate syntax* before starting - warns if parse errors exist 2. Process every entry in the file 3. *Validate re

entries.heading: Undo Behavior
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:58] All batch changes are applied as a *single edit operation*, so: - Press =Ctrl+Z= (=Cmd+Z= on Mac) *once* to undo all changes at once - You cannot undo individual journal changes within a batch operation - For more granular control, use the single-entry toggle (=A= speed key) instead For single-entry toggles (speed key =A=), each toggle is a separate undo operation.

entries.heading: Searching Abbreviations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] Command: =scimax.bibtex.searchJournalAbbreviations= Search the abbreviation database by full name or abbreviation: 1. Enter search query (e.g., "chemistry", "J. Am.") 2. Browse matching results 3. Select an entry to copy the abbreviation to clipboard

entries.heading: Custom Abbreviations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] You can add your own journal abbreviations that override the built-in database.

entries.heading: Adding Custom Abbreviations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] Command: =scimax.bibtex.addJournalAbbreviation= 1. Enter the full journal name 2. Enter the abbreviation 3. The mapping is saved to your VS Code user storage Custom abbreviations take priority over the bundled database, so you can correct or override any entry.

entries.heading: Managing Custom Abbreviations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] Command: =scimax.bibtex.manageJournalAbbreviations= View and remove your custom abbreviations.

entries.heading: Updating the Database
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] Command: =scimax.bibtex.updateJournalAbbreviations= Downloads the latest abbreviation lists from the JabRef repository: 1. Select which sources to download (multi-select) 2. Wait for downloads to complete 3. Abbreviations are immediately available Use this to get the latest additions and corrections.

entries.heading: Statistics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] Command: =scimax.bibtex.journalAbbreviationStats= Shows the number of abbreviations loaded from each source.

entries.heading: Speed Command
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:59] | Key | Command                                  | Description                    | |-----+------------------------------------------+--------------------------------| | A   | scimax.bibtex.toggleJournalAbbreviation  | Toggle journal abbreviation    |

entries.heading: Related Standards
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 08:00] - *ISO 4* - International standard for abbreviating serial titles - *ISSN LTWA* - List of Title Word Abbreviations (56,000+ words in 65 languages) - *CASSI* - Chemical Abstracts Service Source Index (chemistry-specific)

entries.heading: Entry Commands (require cursor in entry)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 08:00] | Command                                 | Speed Key | Description                   | |-----------------------------------------+-----------+-------------------------------| | scimax.bibtex.nextEntry                 | n         | Navigate to next entry        | | scimax.bibtex.previousEntry             | p         | Navigate to previous entry    | | scimax.bibtex.jumpToEntry               | j         | Jump to entry by key          | | scimax.bibtex.sortFields

entries.heading: File Commands (operate on entire file)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 08:00] | Command                                  | Description                           | |------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------| | scimax.bibtex.sortEntries                | Sort all entries (by key/year/author) | | scimax.bibtex.applyToAllEntries          | Apply operation to all entries        | | scimax.bibtex.validateFile               | Validate file and show report         | | scimax.bibtex.showStatistics             |
