entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:10] The document template system provides yasnippet/skeleton-like functionality for quickly creating new documents or inserting pre-defined content. Templates support: - Multiple formats: Org-mode, Markdown, and LaTeX - Tab stops for quick navigation between placeholders - Auto-fill variables for dates, author, filenames, etc. - User-defined templates stored in a configurable directory - Built-in templates for common document types

entries.heading: Insert a Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:10] 1. Open a file (org, markdown, or latex) 2. Press =C-c C-t i= or run =Scimax: Quick Insert Template= 3. Select a template from the list 4. Tab through placeholders to fill in values

entries.heading: Create a New File from Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:10] 1. Press =C-c C-t n= or run =Scimax: New File from Template= 2. Select a template 3. Enter the filename 4. The file is created and opened with the template content

entries.heading: Access via Hydra Menu
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:10] Press =C-c C-m= (Hydra menu), then =t= for Templates submenu.

entries.heading: Org-mode Templates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] | Template         | Description                                    | |------------------+------------------------------------------------| | Article          | Basic article with title, author, and sections | | Research Notes   | Problem, approach, experiments, results        | | Meeting Notes    | Attendees, agenda, discussion, action items    | | Project Plan     | Goals, milestones, tasks, risks                | | Literature Review| Paper review with key contri

entries.heading: Markdown Templates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] | Template              | Description                          | |-----------------------+--------------------------------------| | README                | Standard project README              | | Blog Post             | Blog post with frontmatter           | | Technical Documentation| Step-by-step technical documentation |

entries.heading: LaTeX Templates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] | Template            | Description                           | |---------------------+---------------------------------------| | Article             | LaTeX article with standard preamble  | | Beamer Presentation | Beamer slide deck                     | | Letter              | Formal letter template                | | Equation            | Numbered equation environment         | | Figure              | Figure environment with caption       | | Table

entries.heading: Tab Stops
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] Tab stops mark positions where the cursor should stop when pressing Tab: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE ${1:First placeholder} ${2:Second placeholder} $0  # Final cursor position #+END_EXAMPLE After inserting, press Tab to move between placeholders.

entries.heading: Auto-fill Variables
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] These variables are automatically replaced when the template is inserted: | Variable            | Description                           | |---------------------+---------------------------------------| | ={{date}}=          | Current date (configurable format)    | | ={{time}}=          | Current time (configurable format)    | | ={{datetime}}=      | Date and time combined                | | ={{year}}=          | Current year (yyyy)                   | | ={{month}

entries.heading: Named Variables
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:14] Named variables prompt the user for input: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE ${title}           # Prompts for "title" ${title:Default}   # Prompts with default value #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Template Directory Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Tue 11:30] User templates are stored in =~/scimax/templates= by default (under =scimax.directory=). You can override this with =scimax.templates.directory=: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE ~/scimax/templates/  org/     my-article.org     weekly-report.org  markdown/     project-proposal.md  latex/  thesis-chapter.tex #+END_EXAMPLE

entries.heading: Template File Format
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:16] Templates can include metadata in header comments:

entries.heading: Org-mode Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:16] #+BEGIN_SRC org #+NAME: Weekly Report #+DESCRIPTION: Weekly status report template #+CATEGORY: Work ,* Week of {{date}} ,** Accomplishments - ${1:Accomplishment 1} ,** Next Week - ${2:Plan 1} ,** Blockers ${3:None} $0 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Markdown Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:16] #+BEGIN_SRC markdown <!-- NAME: Project Proposal --> <!-- DESCRIPTION: Proposal for new projects --> <!-- CATEGORY: Work --> # ${1:Project Name} ## Overview ${2:Brief description} ## Goals - ${3:Goal 1} $0 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: LaTeX Template
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:16] #+BEGIN_SRC latex % NAME: Thesis Chapter % DESCRIPTION: Chapter template for thesis % CATEGORY: Academic \chapter{${1:Chapter Title}} \label{chap:${2:label}} ${3:Introduction paragraph} \section{${4:Section Title}} $0 #+END_SRC

entries.heading: Create Template from Selection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:17] 1. Select text in the editor 2. Press =C-c C-t s= or run =Scimax: Create Template from Selection= 3. Enter a name for the template 4. Optionally add a description 5. The template is saved to your templates directory

entries.heading: Commands
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:17] | Command                                | Keybinding  | Description                          | |----------------------------------------+-------------+--------------------------------------| | =scimax.templates.quickInsert=         | =C-c C-t i= | Insert template (auto-detect format) | | =scimax.templates.insert=              |             | Insert any template                  | | =scimax.templates.insertOrg=           |             | Insert org-mode template

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:17] | Setting                          | Default                    | Description                           | |----------------------------------+----------------------------+---------------------------------------| | =scimax.templates.directory=     | ={scimax.directory}/templates= | Directory for user templates      | | =scimax.templates.defaultFormat= | =org=                      | Default format for new templates      | | =scimax.templates.dateFormat=    | =yyyy-MM

entries.heading: Date Format Reference
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:17] The date and time formats use [[https://date-fns.org/docs/format][date-fns format strings]]: | Pattern | Description          | Example   | |---------+----------------------+-----------| | =yyyy=  | Full year            | 2024      | | =yy=    | 2-digit year         | 24        | | =MM=    | Month (2 digits)     | 01-12     | | =MMM=   | Month abbreviation   | Jan       | | =MMMM=  | Full month name      | January   | | =dd=    | Day (2 digits)       | 01-31     |

entries.heading: Hydra Menu
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:17] The template system has a dedicated Hydra submenu accessible from the main menu (=C-c C-m t=): | Key | Action              | |-----+---------------------| | =i= | Insert template     | | =o= | Insert org template | | =m= | Insert markdown     | | =x= | Insert LaTeX        | | =n= | New file            | | =O= | New org file        | | =M= | New markdown file   | | =X= | New LaTeX file      | | =l= | List all templates  | | =s= | Save selection      | | =e= | Edit t

entries.heading: Project-Specific Templates
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:18] Create a =.scimax-templates= directory in your project for project-specific templates: #+BEGIN_EXAMPLE my-project/  .scimax-templates/     org/         experiment-notes.org  src/  docs/ #+END_EXAMPLE Then configure =scimax.templates.directory= in your workspace settings.

entries.heading: Template Libraries
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:18] Share templates across projects by: 1. Creating a Git repository for your templates 2. Cloning it to =~/scimax/templates= (or your configured templates directory) 3. Pulling updates when templates change

entries.heading: Combining with Capture
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:18] Templates and capture serve different purposes: - *Templates*: Create complete documents or insert large content blocks - *Capture*: Quick notes appended to existing files Use templates for new documents, capture for quick additions.

entries.heading: Related Topics
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:18] - [[file:15-capture.org][Capture]] - Quick note capture system - [[file:14-journal.org][Journal]] - Date-based journaling (uses templates) - [[file:07-source-blocks.org][Source Blocks]] - Code execution in org-mode - [[file:22-hydra-menus.org][Hydra Menus]] - Menu system navigation

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:07] When writing academic papers in LaTeX, e.g. with Overleaf, it is common to organize figures into a separate directory, and sometimes to include files in directories to keep the main directory well-organized. Some publishers do not like this, however, and it is extremely annoying to have to manually copy all the files into a single directory with simple names, inline the bibliography, and flatten all the =\input= and =\include= commands into a single =.tex= file. Th

entries.heading: Flatten Manuscript
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:07] Command: =scimax.manuscript.flatten= Opens from Command Palette: "Scimax: Flatten Manuscript for Submission" This is the main command that: 1. Optionally compiles your document to generate/update the =.bbl= file 2. Flattens all =\input{}= and =\include{}= commands 3. Inlines the bibliography (=.bbl= content) 4. Renames figures sequentially (=1.pdf=, =2.png=, etc.) 5. Detects and copies local support files (=.sty=, =.cls=, =.bst=, data files) 6. Creates a timestampe

entries.heading: Preview Flattening
entries.content: Command: =scimax.manuscript.preview= Opens from Command Palette: "Scimax: Preview Manuscript Flattening" Shows what would happen without making changes: - Number of included files - Number of figures to rename - Support files to copy (=.sty=, =.cls=, =.bst=, data files) - Whether compilation is needed - Any warnings

entries.heading: Flatten to Directory
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:07] Command: =scimax.manuscript.flattenToDirectory= Opens from Command Palette: "Scimax: Flatten Manuscript to Directory" Same as flatten, but lets you choose the output directory.

entries.heading: Output Structure
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Given a project structure like: #+begin_example paper/  main.tex  sections/     intro.tex     methods.tex  figures/     plot1.pdf     results.png  refs.bib  main.bbl #+end_example After flattening, you get: #+begin_example paper/  submission-2026-01-20/     main.tex      # Flattened, all paths updated     1.pdf         # was figures/plot1.pdf     2.png         # was figures/results.png  (original files unchanged) #+e

entries.heading: Figure Naming
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Figures are renamed sequentially with smart padding based on the total count: | Total Figures | Naming Pattern            | |---------------+---------------------------| | 1-9           | =1.pdf=, =2.png=, ...     | | 10-99         | =01.pdf=, =02.png=, ...   | | 100-999       | =001.pdf=, =002.png=, ... | This ensures correct sorting in file managers.

entries.heading: Support Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] The module automatically detects and copies local support files that your document needs:

entries.heading: Style Files (.sty)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Custom LaTeX packages in your project directory. Detected from =\usepackage{...}= commands.

entries.heading: Class Files (.cls)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Custom document classes. Detected from =\documentclass{...}=.

entries.heading: Bibliography Style Files (.bst)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Custom bibliography styles. Detected from =\bibliographystyle{...}=. Standard styles (plain, unsrt, alpha, IEEEtran, etc.) are not copied since they're available on most LaTeX installations.

entries.heading: Data Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Files used by packages like pgfplots: - =\pgfplotstableread{data.csv}= - =\DTLloaddb{name}{data.csv}= - =\input{data.dat}=

entries.heading: Bibliography Handling
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] The module supports both traditional BibTeX and biblatex:

entries.heading: BibTeX
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] - Replaces =\bibliography{refs}= with the contents of =main.bbl= - Keeps =\bibliographystyle{...}= in place

entries.heading: Biblatex
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] - Replaces =\printbibliography= with the contents of =main.bbl= - Comments out =\addbibresource{...}= lines

entries.heading: Compilation
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] Before flattening, the module checks if your =.bbl= file is up-to-date by comparing modification times of: - The =.tex= file - The =.bib= file(s) - The existing =.bbl= file If compilation is needed, you'll be prompted: - **Compile first** - Runs =pdflatex= + =bibtex=/=biber= to update the =.bbl= - **Use existing .bbl** - Uses the current =.bbl= as-is The module auto-detects whether to use =bibtex= or =biber= based on your document's packages.

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] | Setting                          | Default      | Description                                            | |----------------------------------+--------------+--------------------------------------------------------| | =scimax.manuscript.autoCompile=  | ="ask"=      | When to compile: =always=, =if-needed=, =never=, =ask= | | =scimax.manuscript.pdflatexPath= | ="pdflatex"= | Path to pdflatex executable                            | | =scimax.manuscript.bibtexPath=

entries.heading: Workflow Example
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] 1. Open your main =.tex= file 2. Run "Scimax: Flatten Manuscript for Submission" from Command Palette 3. Choose whether to compile first (recommended if you've made recent changes) 4. Wait for processing 5. Find your submission-ready files in =submission-YYYY-MM-DD/=

entries.heading: Included
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] - =\input{file}= - Content inserted directly - =\include{file}= - Content inserted with =\clearpage= before and after - =\includegraphics[opts]{path}= - Figures renamed and paths updated - =\bibliography{refs}= - Replaced with =.bbl= content - =\printbibliography= - Replaced with =.bbl= content (biblatex)

entries.heading: Ignored (Not Processed)
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] - Commands inside =% comments= - Commands inside verbatim environments (=verbatim=, =lstlisting=, =minted=) - =\input= commands that can't be resolved (warning issued)

entries.heading: Warnings
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:08] The module issues warnings for: - Missing included files - Missing figure files - Missing =.bbl= file - Circular includes (A includes B, B includes A) - Maximum include depth exceeded (default: 20 levels) Warnings are shown after flattening completes. You can review them by clicking "Show Warnings" in the success notification.

entries.heading: Limitations
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] The module handles most common manuscript scenarios but has some limitations:

entries.heading: Not Supported
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] | Feature                 | Description                                          | Workaround                                       | |-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------| | =\graphicspath=         | Custom figure search paths are not parsed            | Use relative paths in =\includegraphics=         | | Custom fonts            | Font files (=.ttf=, =.otf=) are not cop

entries.heading: Encoding
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] The module assumes UTF-8 encoding for all files. Non-UTF-8 files may cause errors or produce garbled output.

entries.heading: Figure Detection
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] Only =\includegraphics= commands are detected. Other figure inclusion methods are not handled: - =\pgfimage= - =\pdfximage= - Raw PDF includes via =\pdfpages=

entries.heading: Path Resolution
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] - Paths are resolved relative to the directory of the file containing the command - Absolute paths are not modified - Paths with special characters may not resolve correctly

entries.heading: Bibliography Edge Cases
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] - Multiple =\printbibliography= commands: only the first is replaced with content; others are commented out - =refsection= environments (biblatex): not handled, may produce incomplete bibliographies - Custom =.bbl= locations: the module looks for =.bbl= alongside the main =.tex= file

entries.heading: Support Files
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-21 Wed 07:09] Standard LaTeX packages from TeX distributions are not copied (they're assumed to be available). The module only copies files that exist in your project directory.

entries.content: - [[file:10-export.org][Export]] - Exporting org documents to LaTeX - [[file:11-latex-preview.org][LaTeX Preview]] - Live preview of LaTeX documents

entries.heading: Dired - Directory Editor
entries.content: Dired (Directory Editor) provides Emacs-style file management in VS Code. It displays directory listings in a webview panel where you can navigate, mark files, and perform bulk operations using familiar Emacs keybindings.

entries.heading: Opening Dired
entries.content: | Keybinding | Command                      | Description                                          | |------------+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------| | ~C-x d~    | =scimax.dired.open=          | Open dired (prompts for directory or uses workspace) | |            | =scimax.dired.openCurrent=   | Open dired for current file's directory              | |            | =scimax.dired.openWorkspace= | Open dired for workspace root

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: Once in the dired panel, use these keys to navigate: | Key                  | Action                       | |----------------------+------------------------------| | ~n~ or ~j~ or ~Down~ | Move to next file            | | ~p~ or ~k~ or ~Up~   | Move to previous file        | | ~RET~ or ~o~         | Open file/directory          | | ~^~                  | Navigate to parent directory | | ~g~                  | Refresh directory listing    | | ~<~                  | Go to first entry            |

entries.heading: Marking Files
entries.content: Mark files for batch operations: | Key   | Action                            | |-------+-----------------------------------| | ~m~   | Mark current file and move down   | | ~u~   | Unmark current file and move down | | ~U~   | Unmark all files                  | | ~t~   | Toggle all marks                  | | ~d~   | Flag file for deletion            | | ~% m~ | Mark files matching regex pattern | Marked files appear with ~*~ indicator. Flagged files (for deletion) appear with ~D~ indicator.

entries.heading: File Operations
entries.content: Operate on marked files (or current file if none marked): | Key | Action                                                  | |-----+---------------------------------------------------------| | ~D~ | Delete marked/flagged files (moves to trash by default) | | ~C~ | Copy marked files (prompts for destination)             | | ~R~ | Rename/move marked files (prompts for destination)      | | ~+~ | Create new directory                                    |

entries.heading: Actions Menu (M-o)
entries.content: Press ~M-o~ (Option+O on Mac) to open an actions menu for the selected file: | Action                  | Description                     | |-------------------------+---------------------------------| | Enter Directory         | Enter the selected directory    | | Open in Editor          | Open file in VS Code editor     | | Open in Finder/Explorer | Reveal in system file manager   | | Copy Path               | Copy full path to clipboard     | | Copy File               | Copy file to destinatio

entries.heading: WDired Mode (Writable Dired)
entries.content: WDired mode allows you to rename files by editing their names directly, like editing text: | Key       | Action                                    | |-----------+-------------------------------------------| | ~C-x C-q~ | Enter wdired mode (names become editable) | | ~C-c C-c~ | Commit renames                            | | ~C-c C-k~ | Cancel and exit wdired mode               | In wdired mode: 1. Edit filenames directly in the listing 2. Changes are highlighted 3. Press ~C-c C-c~ to apply all re

entries.heading: Sorting and Filtering
entries.content: | Key | Action                                         | |-----+------------------------------------------------| | ~s~ | Cycle sort field (name, size, date, extension) | | ~.~ | Toggle showing hidden files (dotfiles)         | | ~/~ | Set filter pattern (regex)                     |

entries.heading: Display Format
entries.content: Each line shows: #+begin_example drwxr-xr-x  4096  2024-01-15 10:30  Documents/ -rw-r--r--  1234  2024-01-14 09:15  file.txt lrwxrwxrwx    12  2024-01-13 08:00  link -> target #+end_example - First column: file permissions (d=directory, l=symlink, -=file) - Second column: file size - Third column: modification date/time - Fourth column: filename (directories end with /)

entries.heading: Configuration
entries.content: | Setting                      | Default  | Description                                       | |------------------------------+----------+---------------------------------------------------| | ~scimax.dired.showHidden~    | ~false~  | Show hidden files by default                      | | ~scimax.dired.confirmDelete~ | ~true~   | Show confirmation before deleting                 | | ~scimax.dired.defaultSort~   | ~"name"~ | Default sort field (name, size, mtime, extension) |

entries.heading: Security
entries.content: Dired includes security protections: - Path traversal prevention (no ~..~ in filenames) - Filename validation (no path separators in names) - Delete operations use system trash by default - Regex patterns are validated to prevent ReDoS attacks

entries.heading: Find File (C-x C-f)
entries.content: Find File provides Emacs-style file navigation in VS Code. It displays a filterable directory listing in a webview panel where you can quickly navigate directories, open files, and perform actions like inserting file paths or org-links.

entries.heading: Opening Find File
entries.content: | Keybinding | Command                    | Description                                         | |------------+----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------| | ~C-x C-f~  | =scimax.findFile=          | Open find-file (starts in current file's directory) | |            | =scimax.findFileHome=      | Open find-file in home directory                    | |            | =scimax.findFileWorkspace= | Open find-file in workspace root                    |

entries.heading: Navigation
entries.content: | Key                   | Action                                              | |-----------------------+-----------------------------------------------------| | ~Up~ / ~C-p~          | Move selection up                                   | | ~Down~ / ~C-n~        | Move selection down                                 | | ~Tab~                 | Enter selected directory                            | | ~Backspace~           | Go to parent directory (or delete filter character) | | ~Enter~

entries.heading: Filtering
entries.content: Simply type to filter the file list. The filter uses fuzzy matching - characters must appear in order but don't need to be consecutive. | Key             | Action                                                  | |-----------------+---------------------------------------------------------| | /any character/ | Add to filter                                           | | ~Backspace~     | Remove last filter character (or go to parent if empty) | | ~C-u~           | Clear filter

entries.heading: Toggle Hidden Files
entries.content: | Key | Action                                 | |-----+----------------------------------------| | ~.~ | Toggle showing hidden files (dotfiles) | Only works when filter is empty.

entries.heading: Actions Menu (M-o)
entries.content: Press ~M-o~ (Option+O on Mac) to open the actions menu. Then press a speed key to execute the action, or click on an action. | Key | Action                                  | |-----+-----------------------------------------| | ~o~ | Open file (default)                     | | ~j~ | Open in split (side-by-side)            | | ~p~ | Insert relative path at original cursor | | ~P~ | Insert absolute path at original cursor | | ~l~ | Insert org-link with relative path      | | ~L~ | Insert org-link w

entries.heading: Path Insertion
entries.content: When you invoke find-file from an editor, your cursor position is remembered. The insert actions (~p~, ~P~, ~l~, ~L~) will insert the path at that original position. Example workflow: 1. In an org file, position cursor where you want a link 2. Press ~C-x C-f~ to open find-file 3. Navigate to the target file 4. Press ~M-o l~ to insert an org-link with relative path Result: =[[file:relative/path/to/file.org][file.org]]= is inserted at your cursor.

entries.heading: Clickable Status Bar
entries.content: All status bar items are clickable: - Click ~Tab~ to enter directory - Click ~Enter~ to open - Click ~M-o~ to show actions menu - Click ~Backspace~ to go up/clear filter - Click ~.~ to toggle hidden files - Click ~Esc~ to quit

entries.heading: Display Format
entries.content: Each entry shows: - Icon (folder or file) - Name (directories end with /) - Size (for files) Directories are sorted before files, both alphabetically.

entries.heading: Quitting
entries.content: | Key   | Action                | |-------+-----------------------| | ~Esc~ | Close find-file panel |

entries.heading: Overview
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:15] This document outlines the comprehensive documentation plan for Scimax VS Code, a scientific computing extension for Visual Studio Code inspired by Emacs Scimax. The documentation will be written entirely in org-mode format and will cover all features, keybindings, configuration options, and usage patterns.

entries.heading: Documentation Goals
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:16] 1. *Complete coverage* - Document every feature the extension provides 2. *User-friendly* - Progressive disclosure from basics to advanced 3. *Task-oriented* - Focus on what users want to accomplish 4. *Reference material* - Quick lookup for keybindings and commands 5. *Examples* - Show practical usage patterns

entries.heading: Target Audience
entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:16] - Scientists and researchers doing literate programming - Note-takers and knowledge workers - Developers using org-mode for documentation - Users migrating from Emacs org-mode/Scimax

entries.content: CLOSED: [2026-01-16 Fri 21:16] - Each major section should have an introduction - Include practical examples where appropriate - Show keybindings in tables or inline with key - Use `command-name' for VS Code commands - Cross-reference related sections with links

entries.heading: Generate Review Agenda
entries.content: Run this block (C-c C-c) to generate the current review agenda from docs/*.org files. #+begin_src sh echo "* Review Agenda" echo "" total=0 for file in *.org; do [ "$file" = "review-agenda.org" ] && continue # Find lines with  or  headings matches=$(grep -n "^\*.*\|^\*.*" "$file" 2>/dev/null || true) if [ -n "$matches" ]; then count=$(echo "$matches" | wc -l | tr -d ' ') total=$((total + count)) echo "** [[file:$file][$file]] ($count items)" echo "$matches" | while IFS=: read -r linenum

entries.heading: Current Review Status
entries.content: :PROPERTIES: :VISIBILITY: folded :END: The results from running the above block will appear here after execution. Items link directly to the source file and line number for quick navigation.

entries.heading: Workflow
entries.content: 1. Run the source block above with `C-c C-c' 2. Click on any item link to jump to that heading 3. Review the content 4. Change the heading's TODO state from  to  when satisfied 5. Re-run the block to update the agenda

entries.heading: Legend
entries.content: | State | Meaning                       | |-------+-------------------------------| |     | New heading, needs review     | |     | Changed heading, needs review | |     | Reviewed and approved         |

entries.heading: Add Review Markers to Unmarked Headings
entries.content: Run this block to add  to all headings that do not have a TODO state. #+begin_src python :results output import os, re TODO_STATES = ["", "", "", "TODO", "DONE", "NEXT", "WAITING", "CANCELLED"] def has_todo(line): m = re.match(r"^\*+\s+(.*)$", line) if not m: return True first = m.group(1).split()[0] if m.group(1).split() else "" return first in TODO_STATES total = 0 for fname in sorted(os.listdir(".")): if not fname.endswith(".org") or fname == "review-agenda.org": continue with open(fna

entries.heading: Add Review Markers (TypeScript API)
entries.content: Uses the scimax org modification API to add  markers to unmarked headings. #+begin_src typescript :results output import { org } from './src/parser/orgModify'; import * as fs from 'fs'; const TODO_STATES = ['', '', '', 'TODO', 'DONE', 'NEXT', 'WAITING', 'CANCELLED']; let total = 0; for (const fname of fs.readdirSync('.').filter(f => f.endsWith('.org') && f !== 'review-agenda.org')) { const doc = org.parseFile(fname); let changes: string[] = []; org.mapHeadlines(doc, h => { if (!h.properti
